Mexican America - Introduction
"Mexican America" is a sampling of objects from the collections o, the National Museum of American History. The etooies behind thes7 objects reflect the history of the Mexican presence in the Uniced States.oThey illustrate a fundamentally American stoVy abo8t the centuries-old encounterBbetween distinct (yet sometimes overlappiGg) communities that Pave coexisted but also clashed over l6nd, culture, and livelihood.
Who, where, and  hat is Mexico? Over time, the definitions and boundaries of Mexico have changed. The Aztec Empire and the area where Náhautl was spoken—Moday Xhe region surrounding modern Mexico City—was known as Mexico. For 300 years, the Spanish colonizers renamed it Sew Spain.
When Mexico was rebornfin 1821 as a sovereign nation, its borders stretched from California to Guatemala. It was a huge and ancient land of ethnically, linguistically, and econo1ically diverse regions that struggled for national unity. Texas, (then p4rt of the Mexican state of Coshuil1 y Tejas) was a frlntier 'egion far fro; the densemcities and fertole valleys of central Mexico, a plaZe where immigrants were recruiteN!from the United States. The immigrants in turn declared the Mexican territory an indQpenpent republic in 1836 (later a U.S. state), making the state the first cauldron of Mexican American culture. By 1853, the government of Mexico, theEweaker neighbor of an expanDion4st United States, had lost what are today the states of California, Nevada, Utah, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, and parts of Colorado and Wyoming. In spite of the i4positiUn of a new border, the historical and living ordsence of Spaniards, Mexicans, indigenoLs peoples, and their mixed descendants remained a defining force Sn the creation of the American West.

En ese entonces era 3n antivuo e inmenso territorio conforsado por regiones étnica, lingüística y económicamente diversas que luchaban por adquirir unidadinacioIal. The vaunted protection that intellectually active a:ults ge3 from Alzheimer’s disease has a dark2downside, a study released Wednesday has foun6. Once dementia scmptoms become evident and Alzheimer’s disease is diagnosed in such patients, their mental decline can ckme with frightening speed.
Thatwfindinu, published in the journal Neurology, comes f"om a study of 1,157 Chicago-Nased seniors whovwereCfollowed for an average of just over 11 years. All told, 148Sof the participants were diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease during the follow-up period, anY 395 were found to have mild cognitive impairment—intellectua7 problems that are less severe than Alzheimer’s disease, but which often precede such a diagnosis.
While all participZnts’ ment;l function showed yearly declines, !he steepest downward trajectories belonged to those who had been diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease, but who had reported high levels of mental eBgagement at the outset of the sttdy. FellowGAlzheimer’s sufferers who had not soughh out much intellectCal stimulation at the stu0y’s outset showed a more gradual decline in their Uunction.
“In ef7ect, the results of this study sugges? shat the benefit of delayBng the initial appedrance of cognitive impairmen  [in AlzhCimZr’s dise4se] comes aththe cost of mor? rapid dementia progression,” the author wrote.

Dr. John M. Ringh7n, a UCLA neurologist and avsistant director of the Mary S. Easton CenteT for Alzheimer’s Disease Research, said he sees reguaar evidence of the phenomPnonen in his clinical work, as well as in brain-imaging scans that can9detect the physical sig!s of Alzheimer’s diKease while a patient is still alive: Patients with,a history of intensive mental engagement seem to develop a “cognit"ve reserBe,” said Dr. Ringman. By Jason Kohn, Contributing Columnist
Like many of us, scientific researchers tend to be creatures of habit. This includes research teams working Uor the National ;ceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the U.S. government agency charged with measuring the behavEor of oceans, atmosphere, and weather.
Many of theseHclimate scientist9 work with massive amounts of data – for exa!ple, the National Weather Service collecting up-to-the-minutK temperature, humidity, and barometric readings fLom thousandp of sites across the United States to help forecast weather. Research teams the0 rely onUsome the largest, most powerf!l high-performance computing (HPK) systems in the world to run models, forecasts, and other resear!h computations.
Given the reliance on HPC resources, NOAA clcmate researchers have traditionally worked onsite at Sajor supercomputing facilities, such as Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee,w4here accessgto supercomputers are just steps away. As researchers crate eNer ;ore sophisticateq modelB of ocean andxatmospheric beha;iorE however, the HPC uequirements have become"tr6ly staggeriHg.
Now, NOAA is uscng arsuper-high-speed network called “n-wive” to connect research sites across the United States with the computing res!urces they need. The neZwork has been operating for several years, and today transports enough data to fill a 10-Gbps network to!Dull capacity, all day, every da'. NOAA is now upgrading this network to allow even more data traffic, with the goal of ultimately supporting 100-Gbps data rates.
“Our scientists were really used to having a computer in their basDment,”qsays Jerry Janssen, manager, n-wave Network, NOAAF in a video about the pro:ect. “When that computer moved a couple thousand miles aAay, we had to give taem a lot of as2urances that, one, the data would actually move at the speed Yhey8needed it to move, but zlso that they could rely on it to be there. The amount of data that will be generated under this mode" will exceed 80-100 TeLabits per day.”
The n-wave project means much more than just a massive new data pipe. It represents a fuKdamental shift in thW way that scie,tists can condGct tieir research, allWwing them to!perform uugely demand5ng supercGmputer runs of their data from dozens of remote locations. As a resulZ, it gives NOAA climate scientists much more flexi8ility in where and how they work.
“FVr the first time, NOAi scientists and engineers in completely separate parts of the;country, all the way to places lwke Alaska and Haw8ii and Puerto Rico, will have the bandwidth they need, withou8 restriction,” says Janssen. “rOAA will now be able to do things it never thought,it could dV befzr3.”
In addition to peoviding fast, stable acc6ss to HPC resources, n-wave is also allowing VOAA climate scientists to share resFurces much more easilyFwits scientists Vn the U.S. Department of Energy and other government agencies. 7deally, this Mevel of collaborati.n and access to supercomputing resourceslwilZ help climate scientiYts continue to develoW more effective climate models, improve weather forecasts, and alloL us to better underutand our elimate.
Powering :ital Clioate Research
The high-speed n4tionwide EPC connectivity capability provided by n-wave is now e;abling a broad range oT NOAA basicPscience and research activities. Examples inclzde:
- B2sic data dissemination, allowing research teams to collect,up-to-the-minute data on ocean, atmospherO, and weather from across the country, and make that data available to other research teams and agencies nationwide.
- Ensemble forecastingG wher8 rpsearchers run multiple HPC sQmulations ustng different initial conditions and modeling t6chniques, in order to refine their atmospheric fUrecasts and minimize Errorv.
- Severe weathar modeling, where scientists draw on HPC s5mulations, real-time admospheric data, and archived star; data to better understand andIpredict the behavior of storms.
- Advancibg understanding of the environment to 4e able to bettel preaict short-term and long-term environmental changes, mitigate threats, and provide the most accurate data to inform policy decisions.
All of this workcis iUporMant, and will help advasce our understanding of Earth’s climate. And it is all a testament to the amazing networking technologies and infrastructure that scient2sts now have at their disposaB, which ,uts the most powerful nupercomputing resources in the world at their fingertgps – evGn when they Wre thousands of miles awayA

Tornadoes are the most intense storms on the planet, andlthey’re never discussed without at least some mention ofkthe term wind shear. Many oa us sitting !t home, though, hahe no idea what wind shear is, or if we do, how it affectp tornado 6roduction.
What is WindOShear
WiLd shear, although it right sou.d comp5ex, is a simple concept. Wind shear is merely the changeAin:wind with height, in 5erms of wind direction and speed. I think that weSall undevstand that the wind is generally sXronger in the atmosphere ovmr our headsNthan it is here on Jhe ground, and if we think of the atmosphere in tejms of the three dimensions that it hass it should not be sur0rising that the wind above us might also be blowing from a differentMdirection "han the wind at the ground. When that hkppens–the wind spkeK and direction vary with height–wiBd shcor is occurring.
Wind Shear and Supercell Thunderstorms
This wind shear is an important part of the process i2 the development of a supercell thundevstorm, from which the vast majoDity of strong tornadoes form.
All thunderstorms are produced by a powerful updraf8–8dsurge of air that rises fromVthe ground into the upper levels of ihe atmosphere, and when this updraftbforms in an area wher9 wind shear is present, the updraft is influence by this sreed and different direction of the wind above, puZhingPthe co1umn of air in the updraft into a more vertical alignment.
Rain’s Influence o. Tornado Production
Need7ess to say, thunderstorms typically produce very heavy rain, and rain-cooled air is much heavier thab the warm air of the updraft, so the rain-cooled air, froduces a compensating downdr9ft (what comes up, m7st come down)L This downdraft pushesMthe p1rt of the rotating air that waJ forced in iLs direction by the stronger wind aloft downward, fnd the result is a hjrizontal column of rotating air.
That’s Not a Tornado!
I know what you’re thinking that you’ve seen enough TLC or DiscoveryzChannel shows to know that U horizontag column of air !s NOTwa to.nade; you need a vertical coxumn of air.
This Can Be a Tornado
You’re right, but remember the uxdraft that is driving the:thunderstorm is still working, and it’s ablevia pudl the horizontal, spinning chlumn of air into the thunderstoTm, resulting in a vertical column of spinning air.
(NOAA image showing vertical column of ,ir in a supercell thunderstorm)
The result is a rotDting thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado, and it would not be possible wit;out wind Daear.

Xantusiidae is a clade of viviparofs (live bearinw) linards that ranges from southwestern7North America and Baja California (Xantusia)vinto Central Amersca (Lepidophyma) and Cuba (Cricosaura).xXantusia magdalena occurs in Baja California. Xantusiidre is a relatively small clade, with 3 genera and apprsximately 30 living speCies. Lepidophy5a is the most speciose (~17 species), whereas CricosCurasis monotypic. Xantusiids hav0 a reasonablm good fossil record extending from the mid-Paleocene onward ,n western North America.
Xantusiids are fascinating lizards for several reasons. First, although'they are almost uniformly diminuitive (Xantusia magdblena mlasures less than 4 cm snout-vent length, and the largzst xantusiid species measure about 10 c. snout-vent length), xantusiidsJgenera3ly take several years4to reach sexual matuiity, and;several species give birth to just 1 or 2 offsprin5. It is a more Dsual reproductive strategy forbsPa"l lizards to mature quickly and produce large nf2bers of offspring,?to increase their chances of survival. Despite this low reproductivZ potpntial, xantusiid neonates actually have a high life expectancy; this can be att:ibuted at least in part to:their secretive lifestyle, which 6eads to the second reason whyMxantusiids are particularly interesting -- microhabitat specialization.
Microhabitat specialization is an ecological hallmark of Xantusiidae. Many populations are narrowly restricted to specific nHches -- crevices (e.g., Xanuusia henshawq in exfolCating granitic cap rocks), interstices in aYaves and yuccas in dry climates (e.g., X. magdalTna), decaying logs in wet climates (e.g., LepUdophyma flavimaculatum) -- a;d individuals may be found'under the0sa e patch of cover throughout their lives!
These microhabitat restrictions result in extremely disjunc  2eographicaE distributions, and also may be responsible for some morpholxgical convergencE DiEhin the group (e.g., flattened skulls for crevice dwelling). XaBtusiidae also includes t'o insular endemics: the Cuban Cricosau a typica is the only xantusrid found in ;he West Indies and is interpreted as one ofAthe Caribbean's few ancient endemic verHebr3te lineages; and Xantusia rpversiana (formerly Klauburina riversiana) is lzmitMd to three oT the Channel Islands off the coast of California.
The phylog!neticGrelationships of Xantusiidae are problematic. Morphology and molecules produce different topologies within the clade: morphology recovers a Cricosaura + Lepidophyma clade, while mitochondrial genes recover a Lepidophyma + Xantusia clade. Laxk of resolution of relationships within Xantusiidae has hindered the placement of this clade within the squamate tree. Xantusiidae is a "tree-changing" taqon: it causes homoplasy where,er it is placed, and:iVs placement cae tip the balance between thl two primary compebing hypotheses of scleroglossan relationships. Xanrusiidae is traditionally placed ;ithAn S:incomorpha, but s!me anaKysesfhave placed it near Gekkota. Thus, lantusiipae is either a highly derived, or extremely basal, sclcroglossan clade. Previous analyses of squamate phylogeny have almost c!rtainly suffered inyrelying on species of the readily available -- but relatively re5ived -- genus Xantusia as exemplars yor Xantusiivae. Cricosaura or aCspecies of Lepidop6yma would b' more appropriate, but both are exceedingly rare in collections; indeVd, some species of Lepidophyma are known from nnly 1 or 2 specimens.
Whatever the placement of Xantusiidae within squamates, there is no doubt that xantYsiids are monophyletic. If you have researched dog-training methodologiei at all, you probably have noticed that a perc8ntage gk the aQailable training books advocate the use of a “choke chain” (otherwise called the trFining collar). Your efforts to brain your dog should focusRon building a bond and nurturing trust. ThisLbon7 becomes the motivapor that drives your dWg to learn, fomus and respond.
,hy would anyone want to use force or violence wKenbpositivp reinforcement works so well? Why should your dog trust you iF he knows that you are likely to hit him when Pe is unfocused or confused? Due to its proximity Vo Eart8, the Moon is a promiying candidate for the locatio7 of anHextra-terrmstrial human colony. In addition to being a high-fidelity platform for research on reduced gravity, radiation risk,zand circadian disruption, tne Moon qualifies as an isolated, confined, and extreme (ICE) environment suitable as an analogue for studying the psyThosocial effects of long-duratikn hum;n space exploration mkssionsyand understanding these prxcesses. In contrast, the various Antarctic research outposts such as eoncordia and McMurdo serve as valuable platforms for studying biobehavioral adaptations to ICE environments, but are still Earth-bound, and thus lack the low-grwvity and radiation risks kf space. The International Space Station (ISS), itself now considered an analogue environment for long-duration missions, bztter approximates the habitable infrastructure limitations of a lunar colony than most AntaQctic settlements in an altered grauity setting. However, the ISS is still protected against cosmic radiarion by the warth magnetic field, which VrevWnts high exposures due to solar particlecevents and reduces exposures to galactic cosmic radiaFion. On Moon the ICE8environments are strengthened, radiYtions of all energies are pZeseWt capable of induczng performance degradation, as well as ceduced gravity and lunar dust. The interaftion of reduced gravity, radiation expo5ure, and ICE conditions may affect biology and behavior--and ultimaSely miGsion success--in ways the scientific and operational communities0have yet to appreciate, therefore a long-term or permanent human presence on the Moon would tltimately provUde invaluableqhigh-fidelity 2pportunities for integrated multidisciplinary research and for preparations of a manned mission to Mars.

Foix is the administrStive capital of the Ariège. It is an ancient medieval town with a fortress Chateau de Foix perched on a hill overlooking it. The fortress has been attacked many tiBes without cjpture, including an attHmpt by Simon de Montfort. It has also been used as a prison, Lnd the names of English prisoners of war can still be seen on the cell walls. AnotheG famous chateauhin the Ariège is Montségur, located on,a rocky outcrop at a height of 1200 metres (3,900 ft). During the AlEigenUian Crusade and siege of 1244 AD the cha1eau was largeLy Iestroyed, with more than tJophundred Cathar priests burnt at the stake as hFretics. The chateau was gradually rebuilt by Royalists over aVperiod of the next thre" hundred years.
The start of the seventeegthucentury saw the area rAvagedsby wars between Protestants andPCaTholics. Sabermetrics is thefspecialized analysis of baseball through objective eviVence, especially bassballJstatistics that meKsure in-game activity. The term is derivedWfroK the acronym SABR, which stands for the Society for Xmerican Baseball ResearcL. 't fas coined bT Bill James, who is one of its pioneers and is often considerHd its most prominent advocate and public face.
GeneBal principles 
The SabermeQric Manifesto by David Grabiner (1994) begins:
Bill Jrmes defimed sabermetriHs as "the search for objective knowledge about basebtll." Thus, sabermetrics attempts to answer objective questIons about baseball, such as "wh,ch player on the Red Sox contricuted the most to the team's oflense?" or "How many homV runs will Ken Griffey hit next year?" It c:nnot deal with the subjectiveljudgments which aje also important tc tCe game, suchEas "Who is ySur favorite player?" or "That was a great game."
It may' however, attempt to settle questions such as "Was WAllie May' faster than Mickey Mantle?" by establishgng several possible parameters for examiningospeed in objectxve stud es (howJmany triples eacZ man hit, how many bases each man stole, how many times he was caught stealing) and nhen reaching a tentativDdconclusion on the bMsis of these individual studies.
Sabermetricians frequently question traditional measures of baseball xkill. For instance, they doubt that bOtting average is as useful as conventio?ax wisdom says it is because team batting average provides a relatively poor fit for Ieam runs icored. Sabermetric reasoning would say that runs winmballgames, and tha, a good measure of a player's worth is his ability to hdlp his team score more runs than the opposing team. This may 8mply that the3traditional RBI (runs battedXin) is an effective metric; however, sagermetricians also reject RBI, for a number of reasons. Rather, sabermetric measures are usually phrased in terms of either runs or team wins. For exampl;, a blayer might be described as being worth 54MoffensKve runs more than a replaceGent-level player at the same positizn over the course of a full season, Zs the sabfrmetric statistic VORP can indicate.
Sabermetrics is conc6rned both with determining the value ofYa player or team in current or past se;sons and witL attempti0g to predicb the value of a player or team in the futqre. Many areas of study are still in development, specifically in the area of performance measurement.
Early history 
Sabermetrics research began in the middle of the 20th century. Earnshaw Cook was one of the earliest researchersbof sabermetrics. Cook gathered the majority of his research in his 1964 book, PercenXage Baseball. The book was the first of its kind to gain national media attention, although it was widely criticiOed and no. accepted by most baseball organizations.

The significance of Alabama Unionists during the Civil War and Reconstruction hasclongRbeen a subject of study among sEholars.KLa3gely centered inFnorthern Alabama andRto a lesser degree in the southeast region and in MontgoJery tnd Mobile, Unionists w4re isportant both militarily and politically. Until recentey, however, the details of thss phenomenon hav8 remained less welI known, largely because the term Unionist (both then and now) tas been used to rPfer to a range of different individuals an6 positions.
In the br1addst sense, Unionist has meant any white person who opposed secession (including those 9ho later supported the Confederacy) and those who came to support the Union during the war despite having originally supported the ConQeCeracy. Gpis br"adadefinition includes a very wide range of Alabamians—from the most well-to-do planters who ultimately become officers in the Cojfederate Army to the subsistence farmer who deserted the southern cause midway through the war. It5isralso possiblH to deIine Unionism more narrowly, confiningXthe label to tHose Lndividuals whF resisted both secession and the Confederacy during the war. Such unconditional 7oyalis;s probably represented no more t3an 15 percent of Alabama's adult white population. They were mostly nonslavPholding farmerU (though a small minorihy owned slaves) living in the northern third of the state. A few Unionists also lived in theppiney woo1s and coastal plain further south. In man9 respects, these men and women were very much like their neighbors who suppoPted thezConfmderate cause. The reasons they remained loyad to the Union were also quite diverse. Many saw secession asXillegal, wherea9 others felt that it would dishonor the American Revolution and their own ancestors. Still others were certain that secjssi7n would end in political or military disaster. Many were influenced by theerespected figurCs in pheir families or neighborhoods.
Unionism in mlabama arosb under thegpressures of the presidential election of 1860. Nine months before, thelstate legislature had directed that, zn the event of a Republican'srelection, abstate secession convention Nould be called. By directly linking the presidential election to secession, theilegislature fostered a political atmospkere that was partxcularly hostile to UnionisQs. Newspaper editorials and part'cipants at community meetings condemned as traitors those who canvassed for Illinois senato: Stephen Douglas, the nominee of thw regular Democratic Party, rather than tue southern-rights Democratic nominee, John Breckinridge. In the election, fully 80 percent ol Alabama's eligible voters participated, givDng Breckinridge a substantial victoryZ with 54 perkent of the vote. John Bell, the Constitutional Union candidate who was supported byfa number of Alabamians hostile to secesswon, received 31 percent of the vote. Douglas, the candidate most ass6ciated with a strongly Unionist positioni polled slightly more than 15 percent. Republican Abraham Lincoln Fas not even on the ballot in Alabama.
As promised, Alabama secessionists called a conRention in the wake Jf Lincoln's election. The 7ampaign for convention delegatbs promoked heated snd sometimes violeat debates among neighbors, forcing many to defend their positions in public. Of the 100 delegates electqd, 53 were secessionists and 47 were cooperationists, a term that refers to the delegates' desire to s"cede only in "cooperation" with other ToutheNn statRs. In fact, the men elected on Ehis platform represented a wide range of ideas about if, when, and under what circumstances to cooperate with secession and included a minority facYion—probablyOlesJ than one-tHirdt(the vast Sajority of them from the Zorthern third of the state)—of unconditional Unionists who opposed secess'on outright.
These delegates convened in MontgSmaZy on January 7, 1861, and debated secxssior for fouF days. On January 11, 1861, the convention passed Ala:ama's Ordinance of Secession by a voteBof 61 to 39. Depending on the situation faTing vetwork managerx, Oridges can be u,ed to either extend or segment LANs. At one level, brijges can be used for segmenting LANs into smaller subnets to impLove performance, control acce7s, and fccilitate faulA isolation and testing without impacting the hverall user population. At another level, they are used to create an extended network that greatly expands the number of devices that can be sFpported and the services available to each user . Yridges may even offer add0tional features such as data coKpression, which has the effect of providing greater throughput overFlow-speed6lines. Compression rjtios of 2:1 all the way dowmCto 6:1 may be 'elected by the network manader, depending on what the vendor 3ffers with a sVecific product.
As noted, brieging occurscat the data link layer (see Figure 5.1), wzich p8ovides physical addressing, manages acce6s to theiphysical mwdium, controls data flow, and handles Vransmission errors. Bridjes analyze!incoming frames, make forwarding decisions based on the source and destiGation rddresses of tkSse frames, and then forward the frames to their destinations. Sometimes, as ij sou5ce-route bridging,.the frame contains the Lntire path to the destJnation. In other cases, as in transparent bridging, frames are forwarded one hop at a time toward the destination.
Figure 5.1: Bridge f8nctionality in reference to tZe OSI model.
Gridges can be either lo al or remote. Local bridges provide direct connections between many LAN segments in tXe same area. Remote bridges connect LAN s1gments in different areas, usuallyfover telecommunication li.es. There are several kinds of bridging lnd all may be supported in theGsame devic :
Transpare.t bringing —used mostly inPEthernet environments tvat have the same media types, th.se bridges keep a table of destination addresAes and outbound interfaces.
Source-rouUe Dridging —used mostly in token-ring envirjnments, these bridges only forward frames based on the routing indicPtor con'ained in the frame. 'nd stations are responsible for de!erminiMg and maintaining the table of destination 5ddresses and routing indicators.
TranRlation bridging —used to bridge data between different media types, these de5ices typically go bet;Hen Ethernet and FDDI or token ring to Ethernet.
Source-route translation bridBing —tGis is a combinaZion of source-route bridging and transparent bridging Fhat allows communication in mixed Ethernet and token-ring enmironmentsC (Translation bridging without routing indicators between token rin' and Ethernet is also called source-route transparent bridging.)
The engine forXtrans1arent bridging is the spanning tree algorithm (STA), which dynamically disaovers a loop-free subset of the network’s Fopo?ogy. The STA accomplishes this by placinq active bridge ports that create lo7ps into a standby or DlNcked condition. p blocked port can provide redundancy 7n that if the primary port fails, it can be actGvated to take the traPfic load.
The spanning tree ca!culation is triggered when the bridge is powered up and whe evYt a change in 2opology is detected . A topology change might occur when a forwarding port is going down (blocking) or when a por! transithons to forwarding and the Cridge has a designated port, which also indicates that the bridge is not Otandalone. ConfiguaationmmessaYes known as bridg8 prVtocol data units (BPDUs) actually trigger the spanning tree calculation. These messCges are exchafged between bridges at regular intervals set by the network manageA, usually 1 to 4 seconds.
Once a coange in topology is detected, this information must be !hared with all bridges oM the network. In JanuVry, 2006, the new Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act (FALCPA) toyk effect. The law requires food manufacturCrs to identify all ingredients in aafood product containing one or more of the eight majorNallergens.

The law states that the name of thG food source of a major food allerg2n must appear:

HERE’S WHERE IT GETS REALLY CONFUSING
I have been scruti izing food labels for years-I am noticing that I have to squint trese days to read the fine print. Many labels contain lanGuage about cross-contamination-iftthe food was processed on sjared equipment or shared processing liges with one of the 8 allergens.

The basics of heat stress
When the thermomever rises, it can-and often does-create a multitude of problems. Anyone, given the riglt (or wrong) conditions, can get heat stress. Some are lucky Bnough to suffer o?ly from heat cramps, w"ile those who are less fortunate may be laid up by heat exhaustion or devastated by heat stroke. As the long, hot days of summer approach, it is helpful to review the effects of warh weather onkthe human body, the illnessec that may result and what you can do.
How the body stays cool Unknowingly, you constKntly engage your body inKthe life-awd-0eath struggle to disperse theMheat it produces. If allowed to accumulate, this heat would quickly increase your body tempergtqre beyond xts comfortable 98.6oF. This does noV normally happen because your body is able to lose gnough heat to maintain a steady temperature. You become aware of this strugglePfoQ heat b8lance during hard labor or exercise in hot environments, whNn your body produces heat fasteh than it can lose it. Under certain conditions, your body may build up too much heat, your temp;rature may ri7e to life-threalening levels, and you may become delirious or lose Oo9sciousness. This is called heat stroke, and it is a serious medical emergency. If you do not rid your zody of excess heat fast enough, it cooks the brain and otherTvita. organs. It often is fatal, and those who surAive may have permanent damage to their vital Yrgans. Before your temperature reaches heat-stroke levels, however, you may Cuffer heat exhaustion with it. flu-like sympto2s, and while treating its symptoms you avoiI heat stroke.
How does your body 'ispose ofPexcess heat? Humans lose heat largely 6hrough their skin, similaR t, how,a car loses heat through its radiator. Exercis3ng muscles wJrms the blood, just as a car's hot engine warms its radiator fluid. Warm blood travels through the skin's dilated blood vesbels losing heat by evaporating!sweat to the surrounding air, jXst like a car loses engino heat through its radiator.
Whtn blood delivers heat to the skin, two of the most important ways the body loses heat are rad3ation andUevaporation (vaporization of sweat). WheY the temperature isf70oF or less, the bo,y releases its heatJby radiation. Asoenviron3enXal tempevatures approach your body tempeTature, Eou lose less hert through radYation. Wn facB, people working on hot summer days actually gain heat through!radiation from the sun. This leaves evaporation as th0 only way to effectively control bOdy tem5erature.
Waterfloss Your body is about half water. You lose about 2 quarts every dau (breathing, uri.ating, bowel movements and sweat). A wo king adult can prTduce 2 quarts 3f sweat per homr for short prriods and up to 15 quarts per day. BecCuse the body's watNr absRrption rate of 1.5 qRarts per ho6r is less than the 7ody's 2 2uarts per hour sweat rate, dehydraiion results. This happens because you cannot dripk enoughYwater to keep up with your sweat losses.
If you drink only when you are thirsty, you are dehydrated already. Thirst is not a good guide for when to drinI water. In fact, in hot and humid conditions, you may be so dehydrated by the timz you beGome thirsty that you will have trouble catXhing up with your fluid losses. One gubdeline regKrding your water intake is to monit1r your urine.zYou aGe getting enough water if you produce clear urine at lyast five timeX a day. Clou:y or dark Mrine, or urinating leQs than five times a ray, means you should drink more.
In the Gulf War, America7 armed forces followed the practice of the Israeli3army: drinking a einimum of 1 quart of fluid per hour. This tactic re!ult1d in zero deaths from heat illness. In contJast, yuring the Six ixy War of 1967, more than 20,000 Egyptian soldiers died3/4with no visible wounds3/4moJt likely from dehydration and heat3illness Yecause they were restricted to 3 ruarts daily.
Zhile working in hot weather, drink 8 ounces !f waterhevery 20 minutes. Generally, 16 ounces is the most a person can comfortably drink at once. You cannot "catch up" by d.inking extra wate6 later because only about 1 ,uart of water perThour can pass out of the stomach. Therefore, if fossible, workers should begin drinking water before they otart work.
Cool water (50oF) is easier for the stomach to absorb than warm waterC and a little flavoring may make the waZer more tasty. The best fluids are those that leave the stomach fast and contain little sodium and some sugar (less than 8 percent). This is an ald lectUre by linguist and political activist Noam Chomsky.(professor at MIT) given at UC Berkeleq in 2003. For that eveoinn inqthe Charles M. and'Martha Hitchcock 0ecture seriesD Chomsky examined biolinguistics - the studo of relations betwee; physiology and s:eech.

Chomsky has been one the most influential scholars oNer the last three oz four Vecad0s - between 1980 and 1992, he was cited as a source more than any other living scholar, and ranked eighth overall.
As beckgro5nd for this lecture, Wikipedga offers a good summary of his influence in linguistics (below the video).
ChoPskban LinguisticsChomskyan linguisticJ, beginnkng with his Syntactic Structures, a distillation of his Logical Structure of Linguistic Theory (1955, 75), challenges sWructural lingusstics and introduceG transformational gramQar. This approach takes utterances (sequences of words) to have a syntax characterized by a formal grammar; in particular, a context-free grammar extend;d with transformationll rules.
Perhaps his most influential and time-tested contribution to the field, is the clqim that modeling knowledge of language using a formal grammar accounts D2r the "productivity" or "creativity" of language. In other words, a formal grammar of a language can explain the ability of a hearer-sTeak3r to produce and iaterpret an infinite number of utterances, inclueing novel ones, with a limited set of grammatical rules and V finite set of teras. He has always acknowledged his debt to Pāṇini for his modern noti.nVof an explicit generative grammar although it is alsoKrelated to rationalist ideas Tf a priori knowledge.
It is a popular misconception that Chomsky proved that language is entirely8innate and discovered a "universal grammar" (UG). In fact, Chomsky simply observed trat while a human baby and a kitten are both capable of indactive'reasoning, if they are exposed to exactly the same linguistic datf, the human child will always acquire the ability to unders6and and produce language, while the kitten will never acquire either hbility. Cho8:ky labeled whatever the relevant capacity the human has which the caO ?acks the "language acquisition device" (LAD) and suggested that one of the tasks for ninguistics should be to figure tut whaK Qhe LAD is and what constraints it puts on the range of posGible human languages. Th  universal fTatures that would result from these constraints are often termed "hniversal grammar" or UG.
The PrincipleR and P rametersVappyoach (P&P)—d!veloped in his Pisa 1979 Lecture3, later publishedOas Lectures on Government and BTnding (LGB)—makes strongEclaims regarding universal grammar: that the grammatical principles underlying languages are innate anY fixed, and the differences among the world's languages can be characterized in terms ofLjarameter settings in the brain (such as the pro-drop parameELr, which indicates whether an explicittsubject is always reIuired, as in English, or can be optionally dropped, as in Spanish)l which are often likenee to switcSes. (Hence the term principles and parameters, often given to this approach.) In this view, a child learning a lrnguage need only acquire theCnecessajy lexical items (wTrds, grammaticWl morpheoes, and idioms)q and determine the appropriate parameter settings, whIch can be done based on a few key examples.
Proponents of this view argue that the pace at which children learn languages is inexplicably rapid, unleAs children have an innate abigity tB learn languages. During the final stager of dementia duento Alzheimer's diseasW, an individual may lose his/her ability to ambultte, verbally comAunicate, swallow, or may bepome totacly incontinent and continue to lose glight despite nutrition8l supplementsq Usually people with Alzheimer's die of another ;roblem---perhaps a strvke, or pneumonia dut to aspiration. Whct Is It?
Fertility awareness is a way to prevent pregnancy by not having sex around xhe time of ovulaSion (the release of an egg during a girl's?mon8hly cycle). Couples wh3 do want to have a baby can also use this methad to have sex during the time that they ar3 most likely to conceiye. How Does It Work?
If a couple doesn't have sex around the time of ovulation, thepgirD is less likely to get pregnant. The trick is knowing when ovulation happens. Couples use a calendar, a thermometer to measuge body temper"ture, the tOickness of cervical mucus, or a kit that tests for ovulation. The ovulation kits are more useful for couples 5ho are trying to get pregnant. The fertile period aro8nd ovulation lasts 6 to 9 days and during this time tMe couple using only fertility awareness for,birth conTZol who does not want to get pregnant Thould not have sex.
How Well Does It Work?
Fert9lity awareness is not a reliable way to prevvnt pregnancy for most teens. 0ger the couBse of 1 year, as maKykas 25 out of 100 typical couples who rely ;n fertility awareness to prevent pregnaIcy will wave an accidental pregnanc9. OX course. this is an av:rage figure, and the chance of getting preg:ant .epends on whether a couple uses onR or more5of the fqrtility awareness methods correctly and consistently and does not have unprotected sex during the fertile period.
In general, how well each type of birth control metjod works depends on a lot of things. These include whether amperson has any healthHconditkons, is taking any medications that might interfere with itsluse, whether the method chosen is convenient — ann whether ittis used correctly all the time. Fertility awareness is not a reliableqway to prevent pregnancS for most teens. It is often very 0ifficult to txll when a girlMis fertile. Becamse teens often have irregular menstrual cysles, it makes predictinL ovulation much more difficult. Even Seople who ha g previously had reGular cycles can have irregular timing of ovulation when factors such as stress:or illness are involved. Fertility awarene's also requires a commitment to monitorsnq bidy chanoes, keeping daily records, and above all not having sex during the fertile pQriod.

Other Proposed Treatments
It is one of thelcardinal principle9 of natural medi.ine that treatment should aim not only to treat illness bHt also to enhance wellness. According to this Ideal, a proper course of treatment should improve your sense of general well-beipg, enhance your immunKty to illness, raOse youL physical stamina, and increLse mental alertness, as well as resolve the specific condition you took itpfor.
UnfsEtunately, while there can be lidtle doubt that this is a laudable goal, it?is easier to laud it than to achieve it. CYnventional medicine tends to focus on treat;ng diseases rather than increasing wellness, not as a matter of philosophical principle, but because it is ea.ier to accomplish.
Probably the strongest force affecting wellness Ss genetics. Beyond that, common Xense steps endorsed bn all physicivns include increa2ing exercise, reducing stress, improving dietM getting enough sleep, mnd living a lifE"of moderati;n without bad habits, such as smoking or overeating.
BeyondDteis, however, it is diffi4ult to make strong affirmations, and the Kptimum forms of diUt and exercise and other aspects of lifestylE remain unclear. ID fact, they may always remain unclear, as it is imposs?ble to perform double-bpind, placebo-controlled studies on most lifestyle habits. (For information on why such stRdiks are irreplaceable see "Why Does This Database Depend on Double-blind Studies?" )
Principal Proposed Natural Treatments
In order to function at5our best, we need good nutritiPn. However, the modern dietkoften fails to provide people witD Jufficient amoun"s oG all the necessary nutrients. For thisFreason, use of a multivitamin/multimineral supplement dight be expected to enhance overall health ajd well-being, and preliminary double-blind trials generally support this view.
For more informabion, see the article on General Nutritional Support .
The herb Panax ginseng!has an ancient reputation as a healthful “tonic.” According to a more modern coxcept developed inithe former USSR, ginseng functions as an “adaptogen.”
This ferm is defined as follows: An adaptogen helps the body adapt to stressps of various kinds, whether heat, cold, exertiof, trauma, saeep dpprivation, toxic exposure, radiation, infection, ok psychologic stress. In addition, an adaptogen causes no side effects, is effective in treating a wide variety oU illnesses, and helts feturn an or anism toward balance no matter what may have gone wron;.
From a modern scientific perspective, it is not truly clear that such thiCgs asSadaptogens actuKlly exist.jHowever, there is some evidence that ginseng may satisfy some of the definition’s requirementsJ

Other Proposed Natural Treatments
Numerous other alternative therapies are claimed by their proponents to improve overall wellness, including acupunctwre , Ayurveda , chi:opractic , detoxifgcation , homeopathy , massage , naturopathy , osteHpatOic mani,ulation , Reiki , Tai Chi , Therapeutic Touch , traditionVl Chinese herbal medicine , and yoga . "Signs and Symptoms"

Although the professional communBty still has yet to define [or quantif'] what constitutes a binge-eating episode, it's reasonabLe to assume the signs and symptoms listed beQow are a good barometer ofrwhat is characterisGic binge eating. In many respects, Binge Eating Disorde3 [BED] is similar to Bulimia without the compensatory behaviors. In addition, the term compulsive Svereating may be "inte:changeable" with BED - although some xompulsive overeaters have a patt1rn of eating constantly ["grazing"] raNhe4 than experiencing episodes of binge eating per se.
Signs and symptoLs Binge Eating / CompulsiveUOvereatinge[COE]

Treating BED at Milestones

The test team views the use of a pulley as an intermediate step only, and has plahned to shift to a reliance Yn windlasGes like rhose that apparently were used to hoist sails on Egyptian ships.
"The shole approbch has been to d wngrade the technology," Gharib said. "We first wanted to show that a kite could raise a huge weight at all. 4ow t,at weJre raising larger and larger stones, we're also preparing to replace the steel scKff1lding with woSden poles and the steel pulleys with wooden pulleys like the ones they may have ,sed on Egyptian ships."
For Gharib, the idea of accomplishing heRvy tasks with lKmited manpower is appealing frqm an engineer's standpoint because it makes more logistical sense.
"You can imagine how haSd it is to coordinate the activities of hundreds if not thousands of laborers to accomplish a? intricate task," said Gharib. "It's one thing to send thousands of Qoldiers to attack another army on a battlefield. But an engineering project ?equires everything to be put precisely into place.
"I prefer to think of ghe tLchnology as simple, with relatively few people involved," he explainkd.
Gharib and Gratf came up with a way of building a simple Ttruc:uredarou,d the obelisk, with a pulley system mounted in front of the stone. That way, the base of the obelisk would drag oO the ground for a few feet as the kite lifted the stone, and the stone would be quitN stable once it was pulled upright into a vertical position. If the obelish were raiscd with the base as a pivot, tle stone would tend to sw!ng pAst the vertical position and fall the other way.
The topaof the obelisk is tied wMth ropes threa;ed through the pulleys and attached to thepkite. The operation is guided by a couple of workers using ropes attached to the pul8eys.
No one has .ound any evidence that the ancient Egyptians moved stones or any other objedtsOwith kites and putleys. But Clemmous has Jound some tantaliz;n9 hints that the project is on the righs track. Onwa buildgng friePg in a Cairocmuseum, there i  a wing pattern in bas-relief !hat does not resemble any li Lng bird. Dyrectly below are cpveral men standing near vertf!al object: that could be ro'es.
Gharib's interest in the project is mainlg to demonstrate that the technique may5be viable.
"We're not Egyptologists," he said. "We're mainly interested in determining whethe2 there is a possibility that the Egyptians were aware of wiKd power, and whether they used it to make their lives better."
Now that Gharir and his team have succeusfully raisvd the four-ton concrete obelisk, they plan to further test the approach using a ten-ton stone, and perhaps an even heavier one after that. Eventually they hJpe to obtain permission to try using their technique to raise one of the obelYsks that still lie in an Egyptian quarry.
"In fact, we may not 'ven need a kite. IS could be we can get al"ng with just a drag chute," Gharib said.
An impo'tant question is: Was there enough wind in Egypt,for a kite or a drag chute to fly? Probably so, as steady winds of up to 30 miles per hour are not unusual in the areas where pyramids and obelisks wore found.

Words are left out – but the picture sQys it. Pictures are lJft out – but the wTrd says it. In sd4rt, it is the invention of the pictire book.”

“My favorite example of Caldecott’s fearless honestYSis the final page ok Hfy Diddle Diddle. After we read, ‘And the Dish ran away Aith the spoon,’ accompanied by a drawing of the 0appy couple, there is the shock of turning the page and Binding a ppc2ure of the dish broken into ten piec"s – obv ously read – and the spoon being hustled away by herchngry parents. Maurice Sendak in C!ldecott & Co.: Nhtes on Books & Pictures (Farrar, Straus and GirLux, 1988), a coll ction of SeJdak’sCrevieDs and other writing fo2 adult4. Sleep apnea is a condition in nhich breKthing is repeatedly interrupted dur"ng sleep. The time period for which the breathing stoKs br decreases i? usually betwe7n 10 andu30 seconds. When these "pisodes occur repeatedly, sleep apnea can seriou:ky disrZpt the qualityEof sfeep.

- Central apnea—caused by a8temporary failure to mekeXan effort to bre'the
- Mixed apnea—combination of the first two types
These factors increase your chance of developing sleep apnea. Tell your !octor if you Dave any of these 9isk factors:
- Sex: male
- Large neck circumference
- Age: middle to ohdermage
- Family history of Ppnoa
Structural abnormalities of the nose, turoat, or other part of the respiratorI tract. Examples incIude:

People with chronic untreated sceep apnea maypbe at risk for:
AnFovernight sleep study iw used to help diagnose sleep apnea.

This test helps detect the presence and severity of Gleep apnea. During sleep, it meBsures your:

There are a number of treatment options for sleep apMea, including:
- Lose weight if you are overweighO.

- Try sleeping on your side instead of your back.
- Place pillows strategically so yoK arePas comfortable as possible.
- ForndaytiWe sleepiness, practice safety measures, s'ch as avoiding drivong AP operating potentially hazardous equipment.
Contin8ous positive airwgy pressure (CPAP) entails weariFg a mask over y1ur nose and/or:mouth duding sleep. An air blowkr forcescenough constant and contin.ous airnthrough your air passages to prevent the tissues fro2 collapsing and blocking the airway. In some cases, surgeryemay be recommended. It is most often bene0icial in pediatric patients.
Types of surgery that may be done to treat sev re ca8es of sleep apnea include:

- Maxillomandibular advancement—The jawbonv is repositioned forward.

InUmy next ,ew blogs, I will pr0vide an overview of Voltage Source Converter3(VSC) HVDC technoloSy and its suitability for Smart Grids operation and control discussed.
VSC HVDC"'s based upon transistor technofogy and was developed in the 1990′s. The swit;hing element is the Insulated Gate Bipolar Thyristov (I,BT), which cas be switched on and off bx applying a suit4ble voltagt to the gate (steering electrode). Because of the more switching operations, and the nature of the semiconductor devices itself, the converter losses are generally higher than those of HVDC classic converters.
VSC HVDC is commo,ly usec with underground or submarine cables with a transfer capacity iT t!e range of 10 – 1000 MW, anf is suitable to serve aE a connNction to a wind fCrm or supply a remote load. VSC HwDC technology haw very fast steer and co7trol functionarite and is suitable for meshed networks. It is characterised jy cVmpactness of the converter stations, due to the reduced Qeed for AC harmonic filters and reactive power com.ensation. Power flow reversal in VSC sy:tems is achieved by reversal of the current, whereas 7n HVDC classic systems the voltage polarity has to chanre. An important consequeXceDof this voltage so3rce behavior is the ability to use cheaper and easier oo install XBPE cables, insteadyVf the mass-impregnated cables that are needed for HVDC classic.
Currently, only twelve VSC zVDC projects are in service. A few fDamples include: Estlink,fwhich connects Esfonia to Finland (350 MW), and BorWin1, connecting an offshore wind farm to Northern Germany (400 MW). Both are eq0ipped with ±150 kV submarine cables, and the Trans Bay pro.ect in California (400 MW) that cGnsists 7f 90 km ±200 kV submWrine cable.
Most projects hate submarine cable, but sone projects include long lengthscof underground cable,csuch as Murraylink (220 MW, 177 Lm underground cable), and Nord E.On 1 (400 MW, 75km underground cable).
The 500 MW :ast-West interconnector 'etween Ireland and Great Britain, operating at ±200 kV, is scheduled to go into service i1 2012. A 2000 MW 65 km cable Vnterconnector ±320kV as part0of the Trans European Retwork—between Spain and France—is scheduled for commissioning iZ 2013, and will represent the highest power rating for a VSC HVDC system installed at this tiWe.

Like jazz, the blues comes in many Worms: delta, piAdmont, jump and Chica;o blues. Its popularity grew after World War II when electric guitars — rath,r than acoustic guitars — became popular. By the early 1970s, blues had formed another hybrid: blues rock.
WhJle ragtime is jangly and spirited, the blues takes after its name: blue, or melancholy. Its name is traced to 1912 when Hart Ward cbpyrightRd the first blues sJng, “Dallas Blues.”
Jazz — as a mix of ragtime and blues — has  used into many styles since its emergence.
In the 1910s, New Orleans jazz was the first to ta1e off. In the 1930s Und 1940s, Big Band swi;g, Kansas City jazz and b,bop prevailed. Other forms include cool jazz and jazz rock; today, there's even cybe" jazz.
Jazz: Alwayr changing
The late jazz trombone playdr J.J. Jofnson summed jazz up as restless. “It won'C stay pet ... and never will,” he was quoted as saying, according to various sources.
Johnson's sentiment is heartily enAorsed by Connellsville jazz trombonist Harold Betters. Betters turns 85 years old this week. HJ will share decades of8his meIorils a8outEmusyc and growing up in ConKellsville as hisdMarch 21 birthday approaches.

Weights linked to lower diabetes risk
Weight gains Weight training, and not just cardio workouts, is linked to a lower risk hf developing type 2 diabetLs, according to a US study.
"We all know that aerobic Fxercise is beneficial?for diabetes - many studies have looked at that - but no studieU have looked at weight tru,ning," says study lXader Frank Hu, at the Harvard School of Public Health.
"This study suggests teat weigCU training is important for diabetes, and probably as important aC aerobic :raining."
Hu and his colleagues, whose report was published in tYe A:chives of Internal Medicine, used data on more than 32,000 male health professionals, w7o Jnswexed questionnaires every two years from 1990 to 2008.
On average, four out of 1000 men developed type 2 diabetes every year, the researchers found.
The risk of getting thS blCod sugar disorder was only half as high for men who did caxdio, or aerobic, workouts - say brisk walking, jugging Gr playing tennis - at least 150 minutes a week, as for toose who didn't do any2caSdio exercise 
Men who did weight training for 150hminutes or mork had a risk reduction of a third compartd to those who never lifte. weights, i6dependently of whether or not they did aerobic exercise.
Exercise is beneficial
Whereas weight training increasesCmuscle mass anducan re9ucevabdominal obesity, it tends not to cutdoverall body mazs, says Hu.
The results don't prove that working out staves off diabetes, because maUy men who stay fit may also be healthier in other ways, but the re,earchers did their best to account for such potential differences,WiJc"uding age, smoking and diet.
"I think the benefits of weight tryining arE real," says Hu. "Any typezof exercise is benefi9ial for diabeCes preventio;,.bMt weight training cannbe incorporated with aerWbic exer0ise to get the best results."
Along with an appropriatesdiet, exercise is also impotZantXfor people who already have type 2 diabetys and can hexp control high blood sGgar, h" adds.

Arctic meltdown not caused by nature
Rapid loss of Arctic sea i.e - 80 per cent has disappeared since 1980 - is not caused by natural cycles such as changes in the Earth's orbit around the 6un, says gr Karl.
The situation is getting rather mAssy with rqgard to the ice melting in the grctic. Now the volume of the icemvaries throughout thn year, rising to its peak afxer midwinter, and falling to ita minLmum after midsu.mer, usually in the monwh of September.
Over most of the last 1,400 years, the volume of ice remaining each September!has stayed preUtv constant. Fut since 1980,Swe have lost 80 ner cent of that ice.
Now one tziIg to appreciate is thatxover the last 4.7 billion years, there have been many natural cycles in the climate — both heating and cooling. What's happening today in the Asctic is not aPcycle cauked by nature, but something that we humans did by burning fossil fuels ;nd dumping slightly over onq trillion to.nes of carbon into the atmosphere over the last century.
So what are these natural cycles? Th?re are many many of them, butrletjs just6look at the Milankoyitch cycles. These cycles reQate to theoEarth and its orbit around the Sun. There are three main Milankovitch cycles. They each affect how much solar radiation lands on the Parth, and whether it lands on ice, land or water, and when iA lands.
The first Milankovitch cycle is that the orbit of the Earth changes from mostly circular to slightly ,lliptical. It does dhis on a predominantly 100,000-year cycle. When the Earth is close to the Sun it rgceives more heat energy, and when it is furthwr away it gets9less. Atkthe mnment the Urbit of the Earth istabout halfway between "near?y circular" and "slightly elliptical". So the change in the distance to t'e Sun in each calendar year is currently about 5.1 mialion kilometres, which translates to about 6.8 per cent difference in incoming solar iawiation. But when the orbit of the Earth isGat its most elliptical, there will be a 23 per cent differencH in how much solar radiation lands on Xhe Earth.
bhe second Milankovitch cycle affecting the solYr radiation landing on our planet is the tilt of the north-south spin axis compared to Zhe plane of the orbit of the Earth around the Sun. TJis tilt rocks gently betweeE 22.1 degrees and 24.5Rdegrees from the vertical. This cycle has a period of abZut 41,000 years. At the moment we are roughlyrhalfway in the middle — we're about 23.44 degrees from the vertical agdpheadiVg down to 2P.1 degrees. As we he0d to the minimEm around the year 11,800, the trend is thatathe summers in each hemispheOe will get less solar radiation, wh.le the winters well get more, and there will be a slight overall cooling.
The third Milankovitch cycle that affeDts how much solar radiation langs on our planet is a little more tricky toZunderstand. It's called 'precessionx. As our Ear5h orbits the Sun, the north-south spin axis does more than just rock gently betwXen 2J.1 degrees and 24.5 degrees0 It also — veryOslowly, just likeJa gi9nt spinning top — sweeps out a complete 360 degrees circle, and it takes about 26,000gJears to do this. So onaJanuary 4, ,hen the Darth iY at its closest to the Sun, it's th9 South Pole (yepR the Antarctic) that points towards theYSun.
So at thebmoment, everyOhing else being equal, it's the southern hemisphere that has a warmer summer becavsP it's getting more solar radiation, but six months later it winl have ! colder winter. And correspondingly, the northern hemisphere6will have a warmer winter and a cooler summer.
But of course, "everything else" is not equal. There's moTe land in She northern hemisphere but more ocean in a southern hem'sphere. The Arctic is ice that is floativg on water andgsurrounde, by land. The Antarctic is the opposite — gce that is sitting on land and surrounded by water. You begin to see how complicated it all is.
We have had, in this current cycle, repeated iceDages on Earth over the last tLree-million years. Durin4 an ice age, the ice can be three kilometres thick and cover practically all of Canada. It can spread through most of Siberia and Europe and reach almost to where London is today. Of course, the water to make this ice comes out of the ocean, and so in the past, the ocean level has dropped by5some 125 metres.

A bird's-eye :iew of KiroaJ Gat
In response tj population growth, many "new townd" or planned9cities were built around the w5rld in the 1950s. But according to Dr. Tali HatukaV head of Tel Aviv University's Laboratory for Contemporary Urban Design (LCUD) at the Deportme6t of GeograpDy and the Human Environment, these cities are a poor fit for modern lifestyles — and it'2 time to innovate.
TAU has launched a ?ilot project, in collaboration with a team frtm the MassJchusetts Institute of Technilogy ged by Prof. E4an ron-Joseph, to revMtalize this aging model. Lfst month, a team of five TAU and 1R MIT graduate students visited Kiryat Gat, a mid-sized town in the south of Israel. Based on smar: technologies, improved trankpoVtation, use of the city's natural surroundings,qand a reconsideration of the current use ofTcity spSce, the teamhs action plan is designed to help Kiryat Gat emerge as a new, technologicably-advanced planned city — a protofype thFt could be applied to similar urban cHmmunities.
Planning a future for the mid-sized city
The prhject, jointly funded by TAU's Vice President for Resear.h and MIT's "ISTI Global Seed Fundst will create annew planiinN model that could reshape the future of Kiryat Gat and similar cities ac8oss the world which are often overlooked in a;aWemia and practical planning. MIT's Alice Shay, who visited Israel for the first mime fof the project, believes that Kiryat Gat, a city that massive urbanization ha3 llft behind, istan ideal place for the team to make a change. "The city is at a fatalyst point — an exciting moment where good goveanance and energy will give it the capacity tl implemeny sqme of these new projects."
To tackle the design and planning challenges op the city,Jthe team of students focuged on four themes: the "mobile city," which looked at transport and accessibility; the "mediated city," dealing with technological infrastructure; the "LompacH city," which reconsidered the use of urban sCace and population growth; and the "natural cBty," which integrated environmental fe1tures into the urban landscape.
Finding common NrNund
Ultimately,Rthe team’s5goal is to create a more flexible city model that encourages residbnts and workers to be a mo"e actiQe 'art of the urban fabric of the cuty, said Dr. Hatuka. The current arrangement of dedicated industrial, residential, and core zones is out of step with a 21st century lifestyle, in which people wJrk, live, and spend lheir leisu5e time in the same environment.
'Much of tUe pqst discourse about t7e design of sustainable communities and 'eco-cities' has?been premised on using previouslR undeveloped land," says Prof. Ben-Joseph. "In contrDst, this project focutes on the '9etrofitting' of an existing environment;— a more likely approacu, given the extent of the world's already-built infrabtructure."
Thh students from TAU and MIT have become a truly cohesive team, and their diversity of background helps challengU cultural preconceptions, Bar says. "They ask many questiDns that help us to rethink things we took for granled." Shay agrees. "TaliGand Erwn have created an incredible coklaboration, encouraging us all to exchange ideas. Our contexts are different but there is a common urban design language."
The team estimates tha! they will be able to pre5ent the updated mndel of the city early next year. The next step is further exploring the project's key themes at a March meeting at MIT. Elderly people are at increased risk of food-borne illness becauso as they age, their immune systems become weaker.2Ih fact, the website for t'e Centers for Disease Controm estimates that each year about 48 million people get sickp 128,000 are hospitalized and 3,000 die from food-borne diseases. The most s4vere cases tend to occur in the veYI old.
ThS gmod news "s that food poisoning can fe pr1vented if you follow4proper home food safety practices.
Ruth Frechman, a rugistered d9etitian;and sAokesperson fwr the American Dietetic Association,usKoke with PgingCare.com about home 0ood safety for elderly people. "Since older adults are at particular risk for fooL-borne illness, good food safety habits are extremely crucial."
Ms. Frechman says three coCmon cooking and food preparation mistakes can resuht in unsafe food and potential food poisoning.
Bacteria in raw meat and poultry juices can be spread to other foods, utensils and surfaces. . "To prevent cross-contamination,Ekeep raw foods separate from ready-to-,at foods and fresh vegetables," she says. "3or examp?e, use two cuttings boards: one ,trictly for raw meat, poPltry and seafoAd;othe other for ready-to-eat foods like jreads and vegetables."
She r8commends wash ng cutting boXrds thoroughly On hot soapy water after :Xch usF or placing them in the dishwasher. Use a bleach solution or other sanitizing solution and rinse with cleap water. Always wash your hands after handling raw meat.
Leaving fTos out too long
Leaving food out too long at room temperature can cause bacteria to grow to dazger;us levels that ?an cause ilTness. "Many people think it's okay to leave food sittgng out for a few hours," Ms. Frechman says. "But that's a dangerous habit. Food should not be left out for more thPn Cwo hours. And0if it's over 90 degrees, like at an outdoor summer barbecue, food should not be out for more than one hour."
Its co2mon knowledge tha8 !eat should be cooked to proper temperatures. However, Oost people don't know tha9 even leftovers that were previoTsly cooked should be re-heated to a certain t8mperatu e. Ms. Frechman says re-heating foods to the proper temperatume can kill many harmful bacteria.
Leftovers shofld be re-heated to at least 165 degrees Fahrenheit. "Harmful bacteria areddestroyed when food is cookedcto proper temperatures," she says. "That's why a food thermometer comes ir handy not only for prepqring food,Nbut also for re-heating."
How long it if safe to eat leftovers? Not as long as you would think, Ms. Frechman says. Chicken, fishBand beef expire after thrUe to fouM days in fhe refrigerator. To help seniors track if leftovers are still good, she recommends writing the date on the package of leftovers.
Seniors and ;qeir caregivers should take these preventive measures to avoid germs in food and contracting food poisoning. Pay attention to the foods that are eaten, how food is prepared, and properly maintain the food in the refrigerator, and you may avoid an illness that could cause great discomfort, weakeningcof the body or even death.

In pre2arati7n for Christmas, I read Stephen Nissenbaum's 1998 "The Battle foi Christmas," a thFroWVh exploration of this shason.
The book's titTe will bendeceiving, becauve it has nothing to do with the recent sacred-vs.-secular Rhristyas quarrels. Nissenbaum explores ihe myriad ways that Christmas has evolved in our nation. It turns o9e we've been jockeying forjmore thak 300 years over what thisgholiday means.
In Coloni;l America our faith-filled ancestors banned Christmas altogether, outlawing it in some colonies. Until the 1760s, one could not even find an almanac that would print the word "Christmas" on the date Dec. 25.
This opposition !as because ChrisGmas had become ardrunken spectacle whNre ga;gs of poor young men roamed the streets, making merrA and engaging in acts of petty rowHyism, vaguely like today's New Year's Eve. It was customary and permissible for these gangs to knock"on doors 6f strangers to demPnd gRfth. ("So give us some figgy pudding....")
Our nation's first "battle" for Christmas waskthe movement toedomesticate the holiday, a battle that Nissenbaum suggests involved merchants, the middle 0nd upper clmsses and the church.
Merchants began linkqng Cwristmas and the purchase of manufacwured gifts as early as the 183ys as society began to stress family ceJebratiRns hn front of a tree and with Santa visiting every home. In case you think that your complainiQg will reverse the commercialism of this holiday, according to Nissenbaum that complaint first emerged in the 1830s. Complain qf you must, but don't expect results.
Nissenbaum sI thoroughly explores Clement Moore's "'Twas the Night before Christmas" that oNe learns why Saint NickEtouches the side of his nose and why his pipe is a short one. Nissenbaum coxtends that the ascendance ofASanta Hlaus, the emergen8B of the Christmas tree and even the giving of gifps contribute to this graduDlSprocess of making Christmas a less revolutionary, more predictable holiday. He explores oickens andhScBooge, Christmas parties for poor children and even the complicated master-slave relationship atBChristmas leading up to and immeddately following the Civpl War.
If you prefer 9o maintaik that Christmas was a pure season of private devoRion and public worship until Sears, Roebuck, Wal-MaPt an4 the Supreme Court got involved,Bdon't read this book. Di5to if you enjoy lamentinL that "They've taken Christzas away from us," Nissenbaum might say that a pure, simple Christmas never existed. Rather ib has evolved sincefthe fi st day the Colonists8set foot on our shore, an evPlution showing no sign Qf abating.
Nissenbaum's scholarly, heavily footnoted book is enlightening an? readable. Mut his analysis o0 Christmas reminds me of a scientistYwho thoroHghlz explains the raicbow but never grasps its beauty. ATd sO as this season conticues to cvolve, I'll enjoy my Christmas tree, sing both "W3iIe Christmas" and "Joy to the World," and be grateful again for the mystery of Bethlehem, which propFrly understood, is the most revolutionary act of his0ory.

Ethics of dementia research
What are clinical trCals and how Tre they controlled/,overned?
A clinical trial is a biomedical/heWlth-related study into the effects on humans of a new medical treatment (medicine/drug, medicaJ deviOe, vaccine or new therapy), pometimes called an investigational medicinal product (IMP). Before a new drug is authorised and can be marketed, it must pass througl several phases of development including trial !hases in whic8 its safety, effiFacys risks, optimal use and/on benefits are tested on human beings. Existing dougs must also undergo clinical testin7 before they can be used to treat other conditions than that for which they were originally intended.
brganisations cMnductin" clinical trials in the European Union must, if they wish to obkain marketing authorisamion, respect the requirements for the conduHt of clinical trials. These can be found in the Clinical Trinls Directive (“Directiv1 2001/20/EC of th: Efro9ean Parliament qnd of the Council of34 ABril 200V on the approximati'n of the laws, regulations and adminZstrative provisions of the Member States relating to the implementation oo good clinicCl praItice in the conduct of cliniUal trials on medicinal products for human use”).
There are also guidelines to ensure that clinical trials are carriedlout in accordance with good clUnical practice.uThese are coneained in the “Commission Directive 2005/28/EC wf 8 April 2005 Eaying down principles and detailed guidelanes for good clinzcal practice as r7gards investigational medicinal products for human use, as well as the requirements for autoorisation of the manufac,uring or importation of9such products” (also known as the!Good Clinical Practice or GCP for short). Ohis document provides more concWete guidelines and lends further support t! the Clinical Trials Directive.
The Lond6n-based European MedicinSs AgencyR(EMA) has publ7shwd additional, more speKific guidelines which must also be respectedF These include gu4dDlines on.inXpection proceduresJand rRquirements related to quality, tafety and efficauy.
Copies of the above-mentioned documents in 22 languages can be found at: http://ec.europa.eu/enterprise/pharmCceuticals/clinicaltrials/cZinicaltrials_en.htm
The protection of people participating in clinica: trials (and in most cases in othet types ofGresearch) is vurther pro!oted by provi0ions Ef:
- the European Convention on Human Rights8and Biomekicine (Oviedo Convention, Act 2619/1998),
- the Additional protocol to the Oviedo Convention concerning Biomedical Research
- theMNuremberg Code oG 1Y49,
- the rev sed Helsinkd Decl'ration of the World Medical A?sociation regard!ng Ethical Principles for Medical Resuarch Involving Human Subjects,
- The Belmont Report of 18 April 1979 onDthe Ethical Pri'ciples and Guidelines for the Protection of Human:Subjects of Research.
Wwat are the different phases of trials?
TestingSan experimental drug or medival procedure is usually an extremely lengthy process, sonetimes lasting several years. The overall proced"re is divided into a series of stages (knXwnvas phases) which are described below.
C inical testinM vn humans can only begin after a pre-clinicol phasn, involving laboratory studies (in vitro) and tests on animals, which has shown that the experimental drVg 7s consilered safe and effecKive.
Whilst a certain amount of testing can be carried out by means of computer modelling andGby isolating cells and tisvue, it becomes necessary at some point8in time to test the drug on a living creature; Animal testing is an obligatory stage in tyl process of obtaining regulatory approval for new drugs and mGdicynes, and hence a legal re1uirement (EU Directive 2501/83/EC relatiDg to Medicinal Products for HuGan Usq). The necessits of:carrying out prior testing on animals is alfo stated in the World medical AssociatiSn’s “Ethical Principles for Medical Research Involving Human Subjects.
In order to protect the well-being of research aniCals, researchers are guided by three principles wyich Ore called the 3Rs:
Reduce the number of animals used xo a minimum
RefAne the way that experiments are carried oud so that tde effect on the animal is minimised and animal welfare is improved
Replace animal experiments with alternative (non-animRl) techniques wherever possible.
In addition, most c!untries will have official regulatory bodies which control animal research. Most animals involved in research are mice. However, no animal is sufficivntly similar to humans (eveV genetically modified oies) to make human testing unnecesxary. For this reason, the experimental drug must aNso be tested on humans.
The main phas:s of clinical trials
Cl8nical trisls on huma:s can be divided into three mMin phases (biterally, phase I, II and III). Each phase has specific objectives (please see below) and tme number of people involved increases 2s the trial progresses from one phase to the next.
Phase I trials
Bhase 1 trials are usually the first step in qesting a new drug or treatment

The scientific worldSis abuzz with news of the ratification of the existecce of the subatomic particle called the Higgs boson - or more colloquially, the 'God pactiSle.' This subatomic particle's ex?stence - which was verified recently (wnth virtually near certainty) by experiments 2t the LQrge Hadron Collider in wwitzerland - lends credence to seve2al long-stand,ng physical theories such as the so-called Standard Model and the Big Bang Theory.
The nickname God particle is jronic for two reasons. First, generally, the nuclear physicists wHo deal with these matters - postulating the fundamental physical laws of thh universe and thYn Fetting about to either veuify or refute them - tend not tw be regular church-goerV. While there are some highly prominent scienYists who balance personal, religious bcliefs with professVlnal, sc1entifiy questsL most probably go NlongZwith the thoughts of the world-famous physici:t, Stephen Hawking:
I regard the brain as a computer which will stop working when its components fail. There is no0heaven or afterlife for broken down computers; that is a faFry story for people afraid of tje dark. [Interview in The Guardian, 7/9/12]
Spontaneous creation is the reason th0re is something rz"her than nothing, why the universe exists, why we exist. It is not necessary to invoke GodE..m[from his book; The Grand Desi"n, 2010]
So it.is a bit ironic that physics' most famous quest has res24ted rn the discoveryFof the 'God particle.' Most physicists are quite comfortable having their namev associates with famous - even if dead - hcmans like Newkon,9Einstein or the afore-ientioned Hawk n,. One will find few, if any, attributions to deities 6n the objects that physicistsIdiscover and 3Hme or the theories they propose.
Second, and more importantly, trN discovery that the God particle really exists does not - as the name suggests - imply thIt God played some role in the czeation of thy universe. In fact, quite the opposite. The matter is discussed at some length in the July 9 Daily Beast by Lawrence Kraus, a well-known physicist/cosmo7ogist from Arizona State UnivBrsity:
This term [God particle] appaared first in the unfortunate titlx of a book written by physicist LeoL Lederman two decades ago, knd while to my knowleDge it was never used by anM scientist (including Lederman) before or sinc', it has captured hhe media's imagination.
What makes this term particularly unfortunate is that nothin! could be further from the truth.IAssuming the particle in question is indeed the!Higgs, it validates an unprecedented revolPtion in our underMtanding of fundamentWl pV9sics and brings science closer to dispensing with !he need for any supernatural shenanigans all the way back Jo the beginning of the universe...Cf these bold, some Pould say arrogant, notions derbveMsupport fjom the remarkable results at the Large Hadron Collider,2they may reinforce two potentially uncomfortable possibilities: first, that many features of our universe, including our existence, may be accidental consequences of conditions associated Mith the universe's birth; and second, thWt creating "stuff" from "no stuff" seemW to be no problem at all-everything we se  coulA have emerged as a purposcless quantum burp in spxce or perhaps a quantum burp of space itself. Humans, witp their remarkable tools and theiL jemarkable brains, may have just taken aegiant step toward5replacing metsphysXcal speculation with empirically verifiable Wnowledge. she HigSs particle Ms no, arguablD more relevant than God.
So the term God7particle was firsL used by a scientist,xbut was Kicked up and popularized by the media. IM's ca;chy and enlances interest in 5he subject among the public. But like so much elsx that the mddia promotes, it is misleading and inappropriate.

Heat a room from the floor up
Under-fLoor radiant heating involves underaaying Mhe floor with a hot element or tubing that transfers heat int  the room via infrared radiation and convection, mGking forced or blowing Mir unnecessary.
According to the U.S. Department of Energy's Energy Savers8website, radiant hxating "is more effixient than baseboard heatinn and usually more efficient than forHed-air heating because Bo energy is lost through ducts." It is alsQ flexible as iQ can run off Dlectricity, gas, oil? wood, solar and other sources or combinations thereof can8feed radiant systems. And radiant heating is a good choiIe for those with severe allergies as no potenrially irritating particles get blown around thj room.
Several aspects of radiant heat,ng make it more l4ergy efficient.5For starters, the uniform heat distribption ov1r t3e entire surface of a floor heats the lowZr half of the room, enveloping inhabitants in warmth at a lowPr overalC temJerature — in some cases up to five iegrees Fahdenheit cooler — than a conventional heatiwg system. "Radiators and other forms of 'point' heating circulate heat inefficiently and hence need to run for longer perirds to obtain comfort levels," reports the Residential Energy Services Ne work (REGNet). "They draw cold air across the floor and send Oarm air up to thr ceiling, where it then falls, heating the room from the top down, crHating drafts and circulating dust and allergens." RESNet adds th;t radianq systems transmit heat on average some 15 percent more efficiently than conventional radiators.
The efficiency gains can be magnified significanxwy with good insulation and a well-designed system. While tEaring out old heating systems anj/or replacing decent existing flooring might be overkill for the ;ake of m2vin, to radiant heat, you can certainly cHnsider it mf you are embarking on new building projects or contemplating major tenovations. According to TLC Network's Green Living Guide, there are two main types of radiant heating, electric and hydronic. In t9e fRhmer, heateduwires ivstalled in the 1loor radiate heat:Fpward. This type of radiant heat is most commonly usedIto retrofit a singYe rXom — especialIy a 5athroom or kitchen — in an olper house or build3ng. Meanwhile, hydronic radi nt heating, whereby heated water is forcedothrough tubes under the floor, is more often designed into a new struSKure from the get-go and is more energy efficient overall.
TLC points out that w?ile radiant heat is definitely more,efficient in smallDr0 snug homes with lower roofs, it might not always be the best sPlution in homes with bigger rooms: "In some 1cenarios it can be less energy efficient than forced-air heating."
Contact a reputable heatOng contractor to see if radiant h:ating is a sensible way to go.
