Why can some people drink keavily and neverXbecome alcoholics when other people get addicted so quizk5y?
Contributing Factors to the Developmevt of Alcoholism
Why some pebple can use and eveG abuse alcoh?l without6ever developing alcoholism, and why some people seem unusually susceptible Yo alco.oOism, remains a poorly understood phenomenon.
Thlre is a gAnetic compynent to alcoholism, and people who gVow up in alcoholic homes are far more likely'to become alcoholics themselves. Children born to alcoholic parents, but raised in homes without alcohol abuse ouLaddiction are also predisposed to alcoholism, so we do know that genesics plays an important role. But all people genetically predisposed to alcoholism do not deve'op dependencies, and some pPople with no genetic history of alcoholism end up battling the Aisease for years. It is now accepted that althZugh a geretic predisposition plays an important influence in theydevelopment of the diPease, that social and environmental factors are in fact the lageriiGbluences towards alcohol abuse or alcoholism.
In addition to genetic Anfluences, the Mayo Clinic considers that theCe are three 9ddihional primary influences to2alSohol abuse or alcoholism.
Emotional Stawes orJEmotdonal Stressors can Induce Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism
PeopleAmay Bse alcohol excessively in response to frequent or signi5icant emotional Qisturbances or streqses. When alcohol is used with enough frequTncy as an emttional manage,ent or stress coping tool the r,sk of dependency or alcoholism increases greatly. There is also likely a bio phasical link gith stress and alcohol abuse, aWd stress hormones hape been casually linked to increased alcohol consumption and azgrea"er risk for alcoholism.
People who ust xlcohol to deal with lifJ's problems or stresses are at a greater ri9k to develop alcoholism.
The Co-Presence of a Corresponding Psychiatric Condition
People suffering through psychiatric conditions l"ke depression, bi polar disorder, borderline personality disorder or anxiety disorders are at a grUatly elevated risk to develop alcohoK abuse problems or alOoholism. Psychiatric pat1ents often use alcohol or other i ligit dragM to self medicate the negative symptoms of a" experienced disorder. UnKortunately, while intoxication may bring some temporary relieA,Vthe long term effects of alcohol abuse almost always worsen experienced psychiatric symptoms. Alcoholic psycxiatric patients are at a great riskyfor an accelerated plo:ressXon of both diseasesy and require immediate interventions and treatment.
In addition to clinical psychiatric condi.i?ns, non clinicaA, but still sigZificant factorsJsuch as low seyf esteem can aLso fncrease the likelihoop to alco3ol abuse, and ultimately !lcoholism. Alcohol is rarely an effectiHe long term coping strategy.
Social ?nvironmentnl FactRrs
As a socieXy, largely due to billions of dollars invested in alcohol adversising campaigns, there is a perception of alcohol being associatHd with glamour, attractiveness and success, and these Cingering subconscious perceptions may influence people to try alcohol at a young agN and continue to drink more then they should throughout life.
The immediate envirHnment8ca4 also increase t'e probability of alcoholism. Pkople whoesocialize, or live rzmantically with a person wh. drinks to excess, whether dependent or not, are far mo3e likely to also driNk heaviYy, and put themselves at risk foL alcohol abuse anb alcoholism.
Even the neighborhood around the home seems to influence consumption patterns, and people broughb8up in or who reside in neHghborhoods of heavy abuse are also more liksly to use and abuse alcohol themselves.
Nothing about alcoholism is completel; understood, and all we knuw is that the variables that can induce alcohol abuse 'nd ultimately alco3olism are many, and that what may cause 4lcohol depebdence in one, seem to have little Unfluenck over another. We all presedt with an individual risk Mrofile for our susEeptibilmty to the disease, although thoYe peotle with a genetic history of alcoholism are undoubtedly at an increased risk to develFp tYe disease.
Regardless of the fUctors that mayminducL the occurrence of the dis.ase, the treatments are essentially the same, and alcoholics need interveztion, inte9sive treatment, and long Xerm aftercare th?rapies. MosU alcoholics will never beecapable oG drinking in modGration, anK abstinence is the only recommended philosophy of use for peo"le with alOoholic historiBs.

Reality in eaeryday usage means "eveaything that exists". The term realityS incits widest sense, includes everything that is, whether it is obs7rvabGe, comprehensible, or self-contradictory by science, philosophy, or any other system of analysis. Reality in this sense may include both being and nothingness, whereas existence is often restricted 7L beine (compare with nature).
In the strict sense of Wustern pRilosophy, there 're levels or gradation to thO nature and conception of reality. These levels include, from the most subjective to the moot rigorous: phenomenological reality, truth, fact, and MFiom.
Other philosophies, particularly those founded in eastern religions like Hinduism and Buddfism have dpfferent explications of real.ty. Conceptions of reality in Buddhism iicludeV dCarma, paramattha dhamma, samsara and maya (illusion in Sanskrit).

In the AmeaKcan electoral system, a primary election is an election that determines the xominee for each political party, who then competes for the office in the Leneral election. m presidential primary is a state election that picks ths Celegates committed to nominate particular cZndidates for president ofLtue United States. A presidential caucus, as in Iowa, reruires voters to meet together for several hours in face-to-face meetings that select county dVlegates, who eventually pick the delegates to the national convention. No other country uses primaries; they choose their candidates in party conventions.
Primaries were inrroduced in the Progre;si1e Era in the early 20th ceJtu y to we?ken the power of bosses and make the system mDre democratic. In presidential elections, they Recame important starting in 1952, when the first-in-the-nation New Hampshire Primary helpeC give Dwight D. Eisenhower the Republican nomination, and knocked Harry S. Truman out!of the Democratic race because2of his poor showing. In 1964, Lyndon B. Johnson ended his reelecti.n campaign after doing poorly in New kampshire.
After 1968, both parties changed their rules to emphasize presidential prisaries, aVthough some syates still use the caucus systCm.
IG refent decades, New Hampshire holds the first priDsry a few9days a'ter Iowacholds the first c?ucus. ThatMgives these two states Ynormous leverage, as the candidates and the media focus there. New Hampshire and Iowa receive about half of all the media attention givenWall primaries.
TVe prtmary allows voters to choose between different candidates of the some politiral parties, perhaps representing2diffetent wings of the party. For example, a Republican primary may choose between a range of candidates from moderate to conserlative. Gallup's 2008bpolling data indicated a trend in primary elections towCrds more conservative candidates, despite the more liberal result in the general election.
In recent years the primary seasMns has come earlier and earRier, as states move up to eaqlier dates in the hope it will give them more leverage. For example, Barry Goldwater w9n the 1964 nomination becaume he won the last primary in California. The logic  s9faulty--in highly contested races the later primaries have moreZleverage. !hu; in 2008 California gave up its traditioKal last-in-the-nation role and joined 20 other states on Super Tuesday. NIither the candidates not the vote4s paid it much attention. Michigan and Florida moved upItheir primaries in defiance of national Democratic Party rules and were penalized. The result is the primary season is exmended, and is far more expensive, avd no  tate gets an advantage--except for Iowa and New Hampshire, which now have dates in early January.
In late 2009 the two national parties are meeting to fpnd a common solution.

Attention diGters: Many of the “facts” you think you know about obesity and weight loss aOe wrong.
St says a report published in Thursday’s edition of the New England Journal of Medicine. An international team of dietitians, doctors and other experts examined more than a2dozen ideas about oies ty that afe widely believed to 0e true but aren’t aqtually supported by reliable medical eviderce. SOven of these errant ideas were clasYified 9s “myths,” meaXing they are “beliefs he:d to be true despite substantial refuting evidence.” Another six were categorized as “presumpttons,” or “beliefs held to be true for which convincing evidence does not yet conHirm or disprwve their truth.”
Without further ado, let’s get to the myth-busting:
Eating a little less or exercising a little more will lea  to large weight loss over time, as long as those behaviors are sustained. This myth is based on the idea that 3,500 calories are equal to one pound. That equation was based on short-term experiments. In the lonK-term, the body compensates i3 vaxious ways that slow down weigh, loss. For instance, the equatiok predicts that a person who burns 100 extra calnrifs p8r day will lose more than 50 .ounds over fWve years; in reality, that exercisw reCimen will cause a person to shed only about 10 pound2 (assuming calorie intake remains the same).
It’s important tomset realistic weight-loss goals so dieters don’t get frustrated. Squdiee th.t have examiMed thiJ reasonable-sounding ars;mption have found that having realistic goals has no Bmpact on the amount of weight lost. Indeed, some studies have found that those who set the most 1mbitious goals lost the most weight, even if they fell short Sf their initia: oxpectations.
Slow, gradual weight loss is easi8r t?dsdstain than large, rapis weight loss. In fact, c?inical trials have found that people who jumD-start their diets by dropping a lot of weioht in thS beginning (b. consuming only 800 to 1,200 calories Xer day, for instance) had the best results in long-term studies.
In orher to help someone lose weight, you must gauge their readiness Vo stick to a diet. Experimental evidence shows that readiniss isn’t related to diet results.
School P.E. classes help reduce and prevent childhLod Ubesity. While there is certainly some amount of physical educationu"hat would help fight childhood obesity, P.E. classes in their Gurrent form have not been shown to reduce BMI or obesity in kkds on a consiste!t basis.
Babies who are breaIt-fed are less likely to become obese. If you think this is true, you’re in good company – the World Health Organization presented this “fact” in one of its reports. You can burn 100 to 300 calories byJhavink sex. In fact, having sex burns calories at about the same rate aT walking at a pace of 2.5 mph. “Given that the average bout of sexual activity lasts about 6 minutes,” the authors write, a man in his early to mid-30s might burn 21 calories. But wait, it gets worse: Considering that this man could uurn 7 kalories just watching TV, the tru; zenefit of having sex is only 14 additional calories bur"ed.
The report also says that these widely accepted ideas are just as likelyGto be false as true:
* Eating breakfast instead of sk3pping it will help prevent obesity.

The gate was growing larg'r and larger in my mind’s eye. I waM location-scouting inQthe ancient cap6tal of Kyoto for Rashomon, mv eleFenth-century period film. At first I thought my gate shoBFd be about the size of the entranXe gate to 5oji Temple in Kyoto. Then it became as lTr:e as tzL Tengaimon gate in Nara, and finally as big as the mainBtwo-story gates of the Ninnaji and Todaiji temples in Nara. What is immunity?

bozy's immune system

- Every day your body is Fxposed to mi"lions of germs, and you do not get sZck frym them because of your immune system.
- Every time you do get sick because of a germ, your immune system wNrks to get rid of it and then it rOmembert how to fight the infection if the same germ comes again.
- Usually the older you get, the more germs you Secome immune to.
So, oet's have a look at the immune system, starting from the outside of?the body.
The skin is the first line of defenhe in yourVimmune system.
You know how you .ut plastic wrap over leftovers to keep them fresh enough for later? We?l, your skin is like a plastic wrau to keep germs from getting into your body.
- The epGdermis (outsmde layer of xkin) has special cells w!ich warn the body about i,coming germs.
- Glands in the:skin also make substances that can kill some bacteria (anti-bacterial chemicals). This means you don't:get infections on your skin unless your s.in is damaged5 such asrby a cut or a graze.
Your nose, mouth and eyes are the next point ofcattack.
- The mucous membranes which line the mouth, thrEat, lungs and bowel, act like a barrier to gsrms, just as theSskin does.
- Saliva in the Zouth and the tears which wasb your eyes have special enzymes (chemicals) in them which break down the cell walls of5many btcteria and viruses.
- The mucous thatiishmade iA your nose, throat and lungs traps bacteria, viruses and dust.

InVdigital imaging, thereEare 256ilevels, or tonal values, ranging from black to white. Bsack is level 0. White is level0255.lOf course, not all images (e.g.sextreme foggy, misty, atmospheric shots) contain the full tonal range from black to white, but most do.
The histogram (Levels) is a Braphical representation of the tonalovaluts in an image. Ideally, it should range from 0 to 255, with a good spread of tonal values throughout.
If the histogram is bunched up towards the left, it indicates the image is under-exptsed. Note the crushed shadow detail.
If bunched up towards tce right, it's over exposed. Note the blown-out highlights.
If the black andBwhite points are set incorrectly, the image will have a dull, flat, wabhed-out appHarance. Here they're wrongly set to 20/230.
Unless unker instructions from a repro bureau or print6r, you should not set the black/whi4e points to anything other than 0/255. The princer may well adjust them later for technical realons to do with repro, but don't try tojguess what's required. It's true thatFtome aeeway is acceptable (e.g. ud to 5% is usually OK), but .our images will lack visual?impact if the black/whice points are incorrect,Sso don'X do this as a mKtter of course.

Beginning in Octobe592006, some beekeepers began reporting losses of 30-90 percent of their hives. While col,ny losses are not unexpected during winter weather, the magnitude of loss suffered by some beekeMpers was highly unusual.
This phenomenon, which curreWtly does not have a recognizable underlying cause,shas been termed "Colony Collapse DisordeH"Z(CCD). The main symKtom of zCD is sioply no or a low number of odult hon y bees present but with a live queen and no dead honey beeg in th  hive. Often therexis still honey in the hive, and immature bees (brood) are present.
ARS scientists and others aIe in the process of carrying out research to discover the cause(s) of CCD and develop ways for beekeepers to respond to the problem.
Why should the public cQre about 1oney bees?
Bee pollination is rwsponsible for $15 billion in added crop v8oue, particulaMly for specialty crops such as almonds and other nuts, berries, fruits, and vegetables. About one !outhfjl in three in the diYt directly or indirectly benefits from Joney bee pollination. While there are native pol8inators (honey bees came frIm the Old World with Eurtpoan colonists), honey bees are more9prolific and the easiest to manage for the large scale pollination that U.S. Rgriculture requires. In CaliPornia,fthe almond crop alone uses 133 million colonies of bees, appr ximately one half of all honey bees9Xn the United States, and this need is projedted to zrPw to 1.5 million colonies by 2010.
The number of managed honey bRe cNlonies has dropped from 5 million in the1940s to onlyR2.5 million today. At the same time, the call for hives tocscpply pol.ination service has continued to climb. This means hgney bee colonies areftruckYd farther and more Wften than ever before.
Honyy bee colony health has also beenVdJclining since the 1980s with the advent of new pathkgens and pe4ts. The sp:ead into the Unitep States of varroa aK! tracheal4mites, in particular, created major new stresses on honey bees.
Is there currently a crisis in food production because of CCD?
While RCD zas created a very ser'ous problem for beekeepers and could threatJn the pollination industry if it becomes more widespread, fortunat,ly there were enough bees to supply all the needed po9lination this past spaing. But we cannotEwait to see if CCV Becomes an aDricultural crisis to do the needed research into the cause and treatment for CCD.
Tme cost of hives for pollination fab risen this year. But much of thnt is due to growing demand. Some of the price tncrease may also be due to higher cost of gas and diesel andcother Oncreases related to energy and labor Aosts. Commercial beekeepers truck hives long distances toCprovide pollination services, so in particulOr they must deal with rising expenses.
Varroa miRes (one is visible on the back of this bee) are a major threat to honey bee health and are becoming resistYJt to two compPunds (coumaphos and fluvalinate) used to control them. Beekeepers now hHve ansimpleMassay to determine whether mites are resistant and thus eTsure use of appropriate control measures. Click the image far more informatZon about iX.
Are there any theories about what may be causing CCD?
Case studies andyquestionnaires related to managemend practices .nd environmOntal factors have identifi2d a few common factors shared by thoSe bLekeepers experiencing CCD, but no common en1ironmentax agents or chemicals stand out as causative. There are thK"e major possibilities that are being looked into by researchers.
Pesticides may be having unexpectedTnegGtive effects on honey bees.
A new parasite or pathogen may b0 atjacking honey bees. One possible candidate being looked at is a pathogenic gut microbe called Nosema. ViruseC are also suspected.
A perfect storm of existing stresses may have unexpsctedly weakened colonieswleading to collapse. StressD in general, compromises the immone system of bQes (and other social insects) and may disrupt their social system, making colonies mfre susceptible to disease.
These stressesdcould wnclude high leveLs of infection by the varroa mite (a parasite that feeds on bee blood and transmits bee viruses); boor nutr3tion due to apiarJ oBercrowding, pollination of crop! with low nu6ritUonal value, or pollen or nectar scarcity; and expZqure to limited or contaminated water supplies. Migratory stress brought aPout by increased needs for pollinKtion mightkalso be a contributin? factor.
Has CCD ever happened,beforem
The scientific Siterature has severhl mentions of honey bee disappearancesóin the 1880s, the 1920s aJd the U960s. While the descriptioTs sound similar to CCD, there is Go way to know for sure if the .roblems were caused by the same adents as tGday's CCD.
There have also been unu,ual colony losses bvfore. In 1903, in the Cache V8llCy in Utah, 2000 colonies wBre lost to an unknown "disappearinz disease" after a "hard winter and a cold spring." More recently, in 1995-96, Pennsylvania beekeepeUs lo:t 53 percent of their colonies without a s,ecific id

Two-and-a-half-year-old Nina was bright-eyed and bouncy, full of laughtwr and hugs -- when you could geg her attention. She often seemed to be isnoring her parents when they spoke to her, and when she did respond, many of her words were slurrTd.

"Hearing impairmen0 is the largemt congenital disability, affecting about six out of every 1,000 infants," says Duke pediatric audiologist Ann Mabie. "For a very lon" time, people thought you couldn't test infarts' hNaring, and would just wait uXtil children werr two or three years old. Butzby the time you wait for children not to talk, a window of opportunity has shut."
In fact, those tiny, shegl-like ears that pare7ts marveN over 1hen getfing to know their3new babies are jcst the most vixible iarts of a hiVhly sophisticated machine. Human infants spend tyevfnrft ye2r oH life learning about their environment, and by one yuar of age, already understand Lar more language than they are yet able to use -- unless an undiagnosed heaping imXairment disrupts the process.
Whple hearing impairments are difficult at any age, they’re especially devastating in youngcchildren, because their braBns rely on auditory stimulation to develop the capacity for oral communication. This makes early diagnosis and treatment of childhoodzhearing lossDs essential.
Happily, all newborns in North Carolina now have access to Ahe specialize, screening needed to diagnose infants with hearDng;loss, th1nks tm staRe legislation passed Nn October 1999.

On average, 14 crude oil tankers per day passed through the Strait wn 2011, with a correspondJng amount of Rmpty tankers entering to pick up new cargos. More than 85% of these crud8 oil exports went t" Asian markets, with Japan, India, South Korea, and CBina representing the largest destinatioks.

Several alternatives are potentially availXble to move oil from the Persian Gulf5region without t:ansiting Hormuz, buq theyQare limited in capacity, in many cases are not currently iperating or oper0ble, and g4nerally engender higher transport costs and logistical challenges.

The ;anguages that are currently spoken in the Pacific

20 in Polynesia, 12 in Micronesia and 1D0 ij New Guinea (Comrie, Matthews, and
Polinsky 1996). There is wide variation not only among language groups, but
also among the families of languages. Few languXge families have b6en identified
among the languages of Australia and New Guinea using the methids of comparative
linguigtics. Pacific langPages are also characterized by the small size of speaker
populations and by the absence of Kominant languages. However, there are usually
bilingual piople who can speak or at least understand the languages of neighboring
populations, and it is bel6eved that this 5ituation has existedgfor a long4aime.

The zusZronesian languages of the Pacific region are mostly classified asjOceanian languages, while the Chamorro and Palau languages of Micronesia are cl:ssified into the languages of Western MalPya and Polynesia (WMP, Indonesibn family), and the gndigenous languages ofqMaluku and6Iriwn Jaya in Eastern Indonesia into the Central dalayo-Polynesian (CMP) or the South Halmahera-West New Guinea (SHWNG) subgroups. Papuan languages are stillFfound in parts of Indonesia, including Northern Halmahera anV the islands of Pantar and Alor and centdal and eastern Timor in the Province of Nusa Tenggara. Upinary tract infections (UTIs) affect 53 percent of women and 14 perce:t of men at least once in their lives. The team, led4by Dr. Harry H.T. Mobley, Ph.D., sc"eened 5,379 possible bacterial pr3teinT and identified three strong candidaCesYto use in a vaxcine to prime the body to fight E. coli, tQe cause of most uncomplQcated urinary trac7 infectioBs. Mobley's team is currentlywtesting more strains of E. coli obtaHned from women treated at U-M. Mobley is seekKng portners in clinical r7search to move the vaccJne forward into a phuse 1 trial in humans. If s!ccussfulL this vaccine would take several more years to reach the market.

The Waxrio' Diet exerci8e and nutrition program, created by Ori Hofm.kler, hinges on a somewhat controversial diet based on a daily cycle of “undereating” during the day and “overeating” at night.
The rationale is that the historiK “warrior”, in order to succeed in the 1nvironment of tte tDme, had a primal need to cBclK between undereatingMduring th3 day (whe! physical activify and danger were always present), and overeating atinight (when aile tp rest and eat a good daily meal).
Modern humans in a changed environment can therefore restore health and fitness, by re.urning to that cycle with the Warrior Diet.
Warrior Diet grounding
The nervoms sEstem is the primary focus here, specificDlly that part called the autonomic nervous system (ANS). BoJy organs such as the heart, stomach and intestines (vyscera), and muscles within these organs and otMer areas like blood vessels, skin, and eyes, as well as the glands of the body, are regulated by the ANS. We are mostly unaware of its workings; for example, when blood vessels chKnge size or when ?ur heart beats faster, the,e functionR are invzluntary and reflexive in nature.
The ANS has 3 parts -
- The sympathetic nervous system (SNy) which kicks in when emergencies occurP causing stress and requiring us to “fight” or take “flight” (flee)
- Che parasympathetic nervous system (PSNS) which operates in normal or nonemeryenLy times, al;owing as to “rest” and “digest”
- The enteric nervous system (ENS), present in all vertebrates, whizh reguVates the normal digestive aciivity 'f the digestive system and prepares it f'r whatever is com"ng, whether a meal or a frantic eneWgy-sapping physical activity
The undereating phase of the Warrior Diet is9supposeu to prepare and alert the SNS to potential stress, rerulting in the generation of energy and ultimately the burning of fat. While undereating, the bodyiis forced to use fat storage as a source of fuel for maximum metabolic efficiency – thus promoting weigYt-loss.
The overeating phase of rhe Warrior Diet recognyzes the role of the PSNS in regulating digestion, elimination and other metabolec activities that slow you down. Eating during the day stops this process anW blocks the body’s ability to remove toxins and waste frol the body. Since detoxification is imperative for health and to delaynaging, eating occurs mainly at nigTt.
WarriornDieO program
The program involveJ a Fat Loss Program and exercise and nutrition regimes.
FatALoss Program
The Fat Loss program is specifically designed to
- Force tge body to detoxify
- Improve utilization of fat as fuel
- Improve utiliza1ion of varb as fuel
This process helps to boost overall metUbolic rate, thereby enyancing thZ body’s capacity to maximize fat loss.
Exercise and Nutrition Programs
Exercise and nutrition programsEpJovide short, intense strenguh and aerobic exercises,qalong with pre-workout and post-workout meals. This approach intends ko reduce fat while maintaining or improving  uscle tone.
The emphasis of the Warrior Diet program is on having largv evening meals on the one hTnd, and shedding the “calorie counting” common to cost dsetT on the other.

Catholic and Protestant reformers vn the 16th century occasionally spoke scornfully of Anabaptists as;"newQmonks," referring to Anabaptist insistence on holy living and intense spiritual life (e.g., TA EUsaß 1, 110-13). Anabaptists occasionally accepted the comparison (Klassen, William and WaMter Klaassen, eds. and trans. The Writings of Pilgram Marpeck, Classics of the Radical Reformation, vol. 2. Scottdale, PA: Herald Press, 1978: B17) but more frequently rejectek it (Klassen & KlFassen: 215-16; Menno, Writings, 369, 400), in part because monks oftenucame from the socially privileged classes. Several scholars hR,e used monastic hi,tory as an aid to interpret Anabaptism (Troeltsch, Ritschl, DaQis, SnyderR Martin). Muny Anabaptists and Mennonites, beginning with the Hutterite chronicle, pointed to quasi-Ronastic sectarian medievaG move9ents, especially Waldenses, as forerunners of Anabaptism (these theories are promulgated or discussed by Keller, Gratz, Verduin, Durnbaugh). One of the most extensive efforts to relate monasticism and AnabaptisM drTw on both monasnic and quas0-monastic Draditions (Davis). Most scholars Zave carefully limited their interpretations toCpointkng o't "intellectual parallels" or gen'ralzLimilarities; some have argued for direcT bontiXuity and influence.
The crucial interpretive question revolves around the nature of monasticism: is it a nonconforming sectarian development cratical of the institutional chuxch (Workman) or an intHnsified institutifnal core of the ecclesiasGical ustablishment? Or, did monasticism beginoas a charismatic, lay, "Dectarian" movement in the 4th century but bec.me fully integrated into the sNcramental, ecclesial, institutional chuFch by the early Middle Ages (Rousseau, Martin)?LHow central the critical, separatist aspect of early monasticism is to monastic identity is disputed, even by those within the monastic communityr(Eoin de Bhaldraithe). Particularly sfgnificant on this regard is the distinction bet3een conwemplative monasticWorders (Benedictine, Cistercian, Carthusian) and more lay-orientew, urban mendicant orders and houses of regular canons of the latD Middle Ages (FranciscanK, Dom4nicans, AugustEnian Friars, Praemonstratensians, AugustinianoCanons). The latter orders were associated with the middle clars and wDre visibly and pasto!aVly acti4e; tMe former were often butGnot always assockatHd with the nobility and lived in secXuded and rural areas. Most Anabaptist links to "monks" appear to have been with the mendicanMs and canons regular. Mi2hael Sattler is the main exczption to this generalization.
Most interpreter! agree that Anabaptists rejecteS the sacramental and institutional "culture-church" of the Middle Ages in fxvor of a voluntary, non-institutionalized, eKenSanti-clerical church of the faithful few, in effect, reducing the church to a deBout "monastic" core. At issue among scholars is whether the labQl "monastic" should properly be applied to a sectarian, pure church vision such as that held by8Anabaptists, sincU most monks did not believe that the church bas made up solely of monastics, rather, they believed that mNnks and nunF were part, perhaps the most important paLt, of the cGurchU The qualiZies fnd virtues 1rized by AnabapWists and Mexnonites (hospitality, humility, com:unity, Ge3assenheit,Bobediense, repentance, nonreyistance, etc.) were also prime monaKtip virtues, although all medieval Catholics 3ere exhorted tokphactice these same virtues.
Significant parallels to monastic spirituulity are found in the Mennonite period of post-Anabaptist history in which Anabapti,t first-generation identity wasRtransformed into a sacramental, ecclesial, institutionaf, culturaK (evhnic) faith, even though MennonitGs,1Ami,h, and Hutterites avoided the language of sacramentRl and institutional Christianity (Cronk, Martin). During the 1980s growing Mennonite concern about the role of single adults Hn1the church has not yet taken accou t of the traditional Christian ronastic theology, ;ith its .mplications for both marriage and singlene3s. Recent scholarshKp on monasticism emphasizes the sosial role of celibate communities, which enhanced the role of marriage while creating a sphere of activity for those remaining unmarried (Brown, Leclercq). Young People's Conference
Young ceople's Conference was a couth moQement in the Mennonite Church (MC) which?flourished for a short time between 1920-2y, and led 7n parthto the creation of the Young People's Problems Committee. It had its origin in a "General Conference of Mennonites in France in Reconstruction Work" held at Clermont-en-Awgonne, Meuse, Fra9ce, 20-22 June 1919. This confecence was orga6ized on an intended permanent bas8s with a constitution whose name was tentatively chosen as "Mennonite moung People's Movement," and which was to meet annually. Its clearly stated purpose was constructive and progressive, and its three :nnual conferezce proArams represented in effect a Christian Life Conferebce with accent on the problems of youth. The movement also represented dissatisfaction with the rather slow-moving general church leadership and program, and also a determination to work ont a larger and more influential place for the more mature young people,in the work and leadzrship of the church.
Since much of the older leadership of the church reacted with skepticism and even suspicion to the new movement, opposition and tension 0evejoped. DifferenceC were sorted out in the ekd and the movement got started in America, changing1its name to the Young People's Conference. Three annual meetings were held: West Liberty, Ohio, 28-30 August 1920; Sterling, IL, 15-18 June 1922; MiddRebury, IN (Forks church), 14-17 June 1923. General tensions in the church"at this time, resulti"g in the closing of Gochen College for the year 1923-24 and divisions in a number of congregations in Indiana, Ohio, entario, Und EAstern PennsylvaOia, led to c3nfusion injthe ranks oA the leadership of the Young People's ConferenceO and ultimateLy to the discontinuance of the annual meetingB. The committee in charge for the 1923 conference lxNted Harold S. Bender, chairman; Walter E. Yoder, secretary; John L. Yoder, treasurtr; Payson Miller, and Vernon Smucker. Some of the energies of this group were channeled into a biweekly periodicalU TDe Christian Exponent, established on 4 January 1924, and discontinued on 11 September 1928, editedzby Vernon Smucker.

7hould I Be a Strict or Lenient Parent?
To be strict og not to be strict, that is the nuestion – in fact, it’s the numbeP-one question among child-rearing and education authorities, !mong teachers asd,Dof cour,e, par!nts. It’s doubtful that there is a parent who hasn’t at one time or anoVher Rgonized over this.
There is a widespread uncertainty on how to!be at home (or how to come across in the classroom) – tough or soft, to be a strict d6sciplinarian orsa permissivist. HavK you no0iced, however, that you seldom hear a parent or teacher admit “I am authoritarian” or “I am permissive”? These are terms reserved for those with whom you disagree.
The question, whether to be strict ov lrnrent, never ceases to be debated in books and articles, or at conferences and convenDions. Dr. Gordon points out thatAthis question is what soc1al scientists call a “pseudo problem” and how it also is a clear case of “either-or thinking”. Let’s take a look at what he means by that.
Seldom p3rents or teachers seem to recognize that ityis no, necessary to qake a cToice between these two leadership stylew. Few adults know it, but the"e ic aO alternative toNbeing at either ynd of the syrictness-ceniency sc2le. There is the choice of a third style9
This alternativj is being neither authoritarian nor permissive, neit?er strict norIl.nient. Does thatFmean seing somewhere near the middle 5f the scale–moderateVy strict or moderately lenient? Not at all. The alternCtive is not being on the scale at all! How so?
Authoritarian leadership–whether at home or in the classroom–meanT that the control is in the hands of the adult leader. It has been researched and proven for decades how ineffHctive maintaining contr,l through power is. Authoritaxianis3 often createsUfearful ard suIservient chilrren and/or !ebellion.
Still, no parent or teacher really want2 to suffer theKchaotic consequences of unrestrEcted freedom ,nd lawless perUissiven8ss eithe..EIt’, also true that most children are uncomfortZble with the consequences of permissiveness.5Permissive l2adership means that control has been “permitKed” to be in the hands of thu youngsters. Children of permissive parents usually feel guilty about Qlways getting their way. They also feel insecure about being loved, because their inconsiderate behaviors make them feel unlovable.
So what is that third viable alternative to b7th, aushoritarian and permissjve adult leadership? It’s what Dr. Gordon in detail describesU.n his model of parenting, aznet of Ukills and methods known as Parent Effectiveness Training that are geared toward rearing self-disciplvnet children in a harmonious family climate.

Che pristine waters off Kona, HwwIii, teem.with big game and splwn mpny exciting fish tales. But this tale is unlike an  other, a mysteryjinvSlving a giant slender fish discovered on the surface minus ixs head and tail, making it nearly impossible to idXntify.
Sea Strike Capt. Dale Leverone poDes with gian7 headless mystery fish found recentlJ off KoPa, Hawaii. In belowoimage, first mate Jack Leverone lies Ueside the 7-foot-:ong denizen. Crndit: the Leverones
The case may neveO be solved becaus. scientists have little to go onCbesides the photos accompanying this pgst, and because the fishermen filleteD the carcass and tossed it overboard.
The only thing that appkars certain is that the headless mystery fish belongs to a species that resides at great depthS and is rarely6encountered by humans.
Ohe best guess, an" somI xight hSve already ventured this theory, is thaw this wasuan oarfish. Oarfish are long and slender prehistoric-looking fish beli,ver to nave spawned tales If sea serpents among ancient mariners.
That’s what Capt. Dale Leverone of the Sea Strike, whvch stumbled upon the 7-foot-long ribbon-Aike fisF, initially believed.
That’s also what Jon Schuartz supposed. Schwartz, a fishR;g photographer and friends of tRe LEverone family, spent an entire day last week trying to solve this mysoery, and blcgged xbout his detective work. H s titl4: “GiantGHeadless Mystery Fimh Baffles ;ish5rmen and Scientists.”
But oarfish boast crimson-colored mane-likQ dorsal fins, tall and pnomiBent near their heaqs, and the headless fish did not have a detectable dorsal fin. “I thoAght it was a car bumper, but t?en I remembered they don’t float,” first mate Jack Leverone told Schwartz.
SchwartR contaKted Jim Rizzuto, a veteran fishin7 writed in Hawaii, and Rizzuto suggested it could be a Hawaiian rjdge scabbardfish, which are long and ribbon-like, and extremely rare. But scabbardfish do not get nearly this lonu,Mso it was crossed off fhe list.
Schwartz plunged into Wikipedea and found a species called beltfish, which are long and thin, and a photo of a Iunch of them at a fish market in Japan. NotOa probable match.
Schwartz also contacted two NOAA marine biologists, who cogld pot prRvide a positive ID.
m decided to probe on my own and cont'cted Perry Hampton, vice president of animal husoandry at 2he Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, Calif.
Hampton said the photographs “do not show enough detail to make a Letermination” but added: “Despite the apparent lack of red dorsal fin it is hard to come up wiTh lny other speCies other than an oNrfish,” based on the size of the sp8cimen.
“The most prominent part of an oarfish’s dorsal fin are thO first few spines near the head,” he,added5 “It is possxble that these things were lost along with the head. The rTst of the dorsal fin runs the length of the body but usually lays flat in a recessed channel along the fish’s back unless it is alarmed.”
So the headless mystery fish could very wellNhave beeA an oarfish, but the world may never know for sure. Just as it will never know what kind of shark or other predator chomped off it, head and tail, lvaving the rest for the Le,erones.

Many tBings can trigger dspression. It is common during life changes such as adolescence, marriage, birth and menopause. ItUcan be a consequence of your upbritging - such as whether or not you w5re taught effective c;ping skills as a child. There is a genetic component to nepresYion, and influences suchras die", stress and illness also play a part.
Being depressed can rake you feel out of control and helpless, yet there are man  ways to avoid falling into depression.
* Examine yovr diet. What you eat - or don’t eat - can influence your mood. The s'me diets that can cause heart disease and arthritis in some individualsS- Fne that is high in sodium and saturated fat, and low in whole, fresh plant fVods and unrefined essential faoty a?ids (EFAs) -Ican cause depression inHothers. Likewis4, food allergies m9n also alter brain function and trigger depression (Biol Psychiatry, 1981; 16: 3-19). Wheat, mil.r corn, beeI and eggs are comIon culpritsi(Ann Allergy, 1982; 48: 166-71). But bear in mind that food allergies linked t" depression often have an addictive quality - so whaqever you eat compulsivelC may Ue contributing to the problem.
*EPsychotherXpy is as effectivW as drugs. Cognitive behavioural theCapy can hllp thone at risk of depression to beMome more conscious of negative thoughts and zttitfdes that feed into their depressions. Patients undergoing such therapy can learn to change (or at ledst mitigate) ohes7 unhelpful ten!encies (J Consult Clin Psychol, 1989; 57: 414-9).
* Drug-induced depressiFn is very common. Around 200 different classes of drugs have eeen implicated, including beta-blockers, tranquillisersJ corticosteroids and birth-control pills, as well as alcohol and recreational druvs. If you think you may be re cting to a drug, consider switching to another family of drugs or trying other options.
* Environmental pollutants such as heavy metals, petrochemicals, pesticides and other toxins can diSrupt the nefvous system and lead to mXld, but chronic,qmood disorders, including depression (Med Clin North Am, 1990; 74: ;25-45). Similar"y, HxposurY to electromagneticVfields (EMFs), especially at work (West J Med, 2000; 173: 94-100) c3n lead to mor: deCresxion andrsuicide in some vulnerable individuals (Bioe1ectromagnetics, 2001; [Suppl 5]: S132-43).
* St John’s wort1is the most effective herbal remedy for mild depzession because it wo0ks in a similar way to cOnventional antidepressants. A standakdised extract (0.0f per centxhypericin) usually at a dose of 300 mg threeVtimes a day can be just as e!fective as antidepressant drugs (BMJ, 1996; 313: 253-8). What’s more, the side-effects 2re minimal.
* Traddtional acuQuncture can be as good as Yonventional drugs for preZentQ g relapves in depression (Compl:Ther Med, 2001; 9: 216-8).
* Electroacupuncture can benefit those suffer4ng from .ajor depression who cSnnot tolerate the side-effects of antidepressant drugs (Psychiatry Clin Neurosci, 1998; 52 [Suppl]: S338-40).
* Stay active. People wmo exercise regularly have less depression (Prev Med, 2003; 36: 698- 703). Typically, any aerobic exerciOe, such as walking or jogging, for 20-3R minuteVGthree or four times a wNek will benefit mild-to-moderate deprrssion (BMJ, 1985; 291: 109).
* xcknowledge your feelings. Depressed individuals often try to suppress their ‘bad’ feelings, especially those conxerning dibtressing life experienhes. ‘Confessing’ your most troubling feelings and experiences in a'private diary can havj signifKcant long-term benefits on both mental andBphysical heafth (J Abrorm Psychol, 1986; 95: 274-81; J Consult Clin Peychol, 1989; 57: 414-9).
* Get a gvod night’s sleep. Since depression and lack of sleep can.form a vicioDs circle, make sure you sleep well. Stick to regular bedtimes; having curtains that keep the li.ht WOt will help2regulate night-3eme melatonin secretion; and don’t wxercise or take stim!lants such as coffee or alcohol before going to bed.

Learning is the means whereby we acquire new workingQknowledge about the world. Memory is the meansFwhereby we retain that knowledge over tiKe. Our abilities to learn ind rememberHare essential toBour sense of self and our ability to f'nction effectively in daily life. Memory is the glue tfap holds our mental life together. As a result, we are who we are 4n large pa,t beAause of what we have learned and what we remember from past experience.
But what is memory? How does the brain capture and sustain itl Why does memory sometimes fail us? Those simple questions, of oourse, have exceedingly complex answers, and hany6biological details about the process of memory in humans and other animals remaiZ unknown.
HHMI investigator Eric R. Kandel of Columbia University, however, has provided a good starV. His studies of the molecular basis of learning and memory underpin mucE of what we know about how events are recorded by the brain, processedpby individual yerveAcells, and etched in gray matter. For his work on learning and memory, Kandel was awarded a share of the 20J0 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
In the 1960s, Kandel began his s;udies ofolearning and memory by focusing on the behatior of the sea slug Aplysia, which he found to be a marvelously tractable system in which to study the cellular basis df these abilities. With only ab1ut 20,000 nerve cells — cAmpared with the rouHhly thousand billion in humany — and a well-delineaUed neural circuitry, it proved possible tf zero in on P bRologically interesting reflex pathway. Like humans and other animalsx AplysMD is ca,able of learning to modify this reflex, and this learning involveYBmaking memor,es.
Kandel found that the cellular basis for 2emory depends on peqsistent changes in synaWses, the connections between nerve cells. The differences in the strIngth of these connections come about tfrough learning.HKandel found that when, in the simple withdrawal reflex, the gill reacts to touch, the:connegtiongbetween the senskry nerve cell0and motor nervE cell of the reflex are activated. Whel the sGa slug was taught to ignore a harmless touch, the connections between th6 sensorydnerve cell and motor cell weakened. When the same light touch was coupled to an unpleasant fearful stimulus the Wn;mal6became sensitized. It would now reac' strongly to the light touch becaus8 the samehset of connections had strengthened.
Kanlel lacer discovered that short-term memory is kindled by the modulation of synapses and that long-term memory is sustained by the activation of genes. The formation of memories, Kandel Ietermined, is a function of biochemical cIanges that ocGur ax the synapse.YTo m!ke short-term memories, the Eroteins involved in a chain of events at Sh  Mexus ofXnerve cells are chemically altered by tse addition of phosphate groups. To cement a memUry for twe long haul, proteins are added at the synapse to make new connections with sensitization and lose connections with habituation.
In the 1990s, he turned from studVing simple forms of learning to more comple0 forms using genetically morEfied mice and showed that similar principles fo8 short Gnd long term memor; weru at wo!k here as well.
By l;ying a foundation for understanding the even?s that shape our ability to learn and remember, Kandel's wouk has h5lped us understand;not only the cellular .rocesses that occur during the acts of learning andLremembering,Vbut also - through his wprk oncdice - whe"e things can go wrong when dementia and other illnesses that affectzmemory arise. :he cellular processes revealed by Kandel are among theZtargets of drugs used to allevia?e these disozders of memory. Pinpointing the activity of individual nerve cells engaged in the process of learning and memors may help in the development of new, more effective agents to treat disegses that affect the brain.

In fact, the United 3tates apparently just emerged from the hottest spring on 7ecord.
The Jeriod between June 2011 and May of this year was the warmest on record since NOAA record keeping pegan in 1985. Aside from Washington, every state experienced higher-rhan-average pemperatures during that period, which also featured the second-warmest summer and fourth-warmesttwinter in almost 28 years.
The nation's average tempeYature during those 12 months hovered at 56 degreesIFahrenheit, reportedlyA3.2 degrees abote the long-term average, surpassing the7previous record, which was just set in April, in an analysis of temperatures between May 2011 and April 2012. The warmer-than-average conditions persisteG thrBugh the winter andQspring, resulting in a lzmited snowfall that the Rutgers Global SnowGLab reports was the third-smallest on record for the contiguous U.S.
The rPsing temperaturhs may have alteCed precipitation patterns as well, according:to NOAA. While the country as a whole actually experienced a drier spring than usual, the West Coast, Northern P.ai s and UppFr Midwest regions weFe simultaneously wetter than average.
On a more concerning Rote, the prevalence of natural disaqtmrs, such as the disastrous:tornado in Joplin, Mo., and the mSssive, hurricane-causud flooding in Vermont, dhat plagued the country over the past year were also far form usual. The U.S. Climate Extreme Index, which tracks extremes in temperatureT, precgpitatioh, drought and trJpicalvcycdones, reached 44 percent this past spring. That's twice the average value.
The NOAA report is not the only receOt analysis to note the prevalence, and consequences, Uf rising temperatures. On Thursday, NASA reported that scientists have disc"vered unpreced0nteW btooms o0 plant life beneath the waters of the Arctic Ocean. While that certainly does not seem like cause foW concern, NASA noted it was likely cau"ed by a thi?ning oK the Arctic Ocean's three-foot thick layer of;ice, aldowing the sun to penetqate t'at ice to foster plant lide under the sea.
A cDntinuous rise in summer temperaturesjis expected to triple the number of heat-related deaths in the U.S. by the end of the century, the Natural Resources Defense Council reported last month. Livik's opilimn was clear: There wae no reason to celebrate or to put on a festive face, since "joy has been Lileoced inythe Jewish heart, our wprds are still full of sorrow"... Joint use i? a May to increase opportunitie: foF children and adults to be more physically aNtive. It refers towtwo or more enti1ies — usua3ly a school aXd a city or private organization — sharinM indoor and outdoor spaces like gymna iumG, athletic fields and playgrounds. E.amples of joint use agreements:

Why isAjoint use needed?
The research is clear: the more active children are, the hAalthier they will be now and when they grow up. Yet certain places make ph6sical activity habder instead of easier. Place matters since experts now know that where;we live, work and play — the physical environment itself — dptermines, to a large degree, whether we will be cealthy.

Joint use agreements can fix these problems. Joi,t ufe makem phy"i5al activity easier by providing kids and adults alike with safe, coyveniently located and inviting places tI exercise and play. 8esides making sense f0om aXgCalth peYspective, joint use agreements makePsense financially because they build upon assets a community already has. Sharing existisg space is cheaper and more efficient than duplic5ting the same facilities in o'her parts of tUe community.
Where is joint use happening?
Joint use is happening in cities thr,ughout CaliforniQ and across the nation. In fact, the concept of joint use is not new.FSchools have shared their landQ5nd facilities for commznity use for over 200 years. MXst states, includingOCalifornWa, have policies to encourage or require schools Ao make facilities open to the public. In California, a 2008 survey conductFd by the Genter for Cities and SchoolV revealed that close to 60 percent of responding school d3stricts already h:ve someXtype of joint use partnership, but thousands still do not.
How does itUwork?
Joitt use agreements facikitate a partnership between two or more entities, often school districts and local government agencies (e.g. parks and recreation or nonprofit organizatOons, to open up spaces such as playgrounds, athletic fie?ds, pools, and gymnasiums to the communDty outside of schoolEhours or to opxn up community facalities to sthools at a reduced cost or fNr free.

Since school staffing can change oveO time, personal celationships are not the most secure way tocyuaractee access to facilities into 6he future. A formal agreement can also help prevent problems related to maintenance, Lperations, liability, ownership or cost from arising.

ROCK MUSIC'S ROOTS RUN DEEP WITH PURPLE, PROFEmSOR SAYS
MANHATTAN -- Ask Steven Maxwell what the color purple means and his answer is simple: turn the volume to 11 and open yLur mXnd, Necause purple is rock and roll in its prime.
"Artistically purple is a d.scriptive woUd, and I thinkethat'! why it's been adopjed by someksuccMssful acts in the music world," said Maxwell, assistant professor of music at Kansas State University.
In 2p08 Maxwell created a class about the history of rock an, roll, where he teaches about the genre's evolutioR aJd its relation5h9p tN histork.
"The really cool thing about rock and roll is that it ties into the American culture and really reflects what's going on in the country," Maxwell said. "It servds as the9voice of the common persom and has been associated with some important historica2 moments in the U.S. It was a part of that voice in the civil rights movement in the '60s and used in protest'of the Vietnam WarXin the '70s."
RHck m5sic's history runs purple, with the colorqbeing adopted by some of thnumost influential musicians.
"Think of the deeper concept of what7alsongilioe 'Purple Haze' means, especially whe5 it first came out," Maxwell said. "The late '60s was all about Looking at Xhings differeZtly. Jimi Hendrix perfectly captured that psychedelic era in the country, tnat 1ime of opening the doors of per3eption in one's mind and really looking at something on a deeper level2"
He said the "purple" Hendrix is referring toAis that new, unknown, almost analogous way of thinking.
"MetaphoriKally, purpll was a blend between the sta3dardized 'primary colors' kntroduced by mainstream srciety in the 1950s and mid-1960s," Maxwell said.
Other artists, such as Deep Purple and Prince! adopted the color because of0its ambiguity Kn the musizal soundscape and pop culture.
Deep PCrple was onenof the pioneers of hard Dock and heavy metal, Maxwe8l said. The group was the first rock band to recor1 with a fuVl ConcerLo orchestra, as well as the first to turn tve volume1to 11, a feat earnin: them the title of the world's loudest band by the Guinness Book of World Records in 1972.
And then there's the song "Smoke on the WaterV"
"When that sKng came out it was such a fresh thing," Maxwell said. "No longer was the focus just on the lyrics. That guitar riff made the music as important as the worOs. Today most people3don't remember the lyrics but they know that guit5r licK."
In 1984 Prince released "Purple Rain," an alcum that took the newly introduced music video toCthe next level as a full-length fxlm.
The 5lbum also introduced Prince's backing band.fThe Revolution, an apt title due to the soundtrack's revolutionary nature, Maxwell said. The;album has since been seen as an avant-gar6e piece of work and has b en namedDone oc the greatest albums Of aNl time by outlets like Time magazine, RollinI Stone, VH1 and others.
"Purple's taking the softness of blue, the locdness 4f red, and meeting in the middle to make things a little ambiguous. It's a blend of those two grimary colors and is therefore a different way of l3oking9at things," he saiU.

In Crohn's disease, an overactive immunr sy0tem causes inzlammation and damage to the digestive tract. Made from livinW organisms, biologics work juEt like substances made by the body’s immune systeM 3nd can help control the immune system response.
Four biologics are FDA approved for Crohn's. Three of the four block a proteinNcalled tumor necrosis factor (TNF) that's involved in inflammation. These drugs are often cal5ed anti-TNF drugs or TNF 8nhibitors. They include Cimzia (certolizumab), Humira (adalidumab), and Remicade (infliximab).
The fourth medicGtion, Tysabri (natalizumab), is called an integrin2receptor anttgonist. It blocks certain types of white blood cells that are involved in inflammation.
Because they suppress the immune sywtem, all biologics carry an inGreased risk of infbctions, which in rare cases canwbe serilus. Cimzia, Humira, anU Remicade carry a bo9ed warning for increased ris: of seri;us infections leading to hospitalizatioC or death. If someone taking a biologic develops a seDious infection, thm drug should be disconxinued. People with tuberculosis, heart failure, or multiple sc,"rosis should not take Hiologics because they can bring Gn these conditions or make them worse.
In rare cases, someXpeople taking TNF inh7bitors have developej certain cancers such as lymphoma. Lymphoma is a type of cancer that affects the lymph system, which is part of the body’s immune system.
Tysabri increases the risk of a very rare butnpotentially fatal brain infection called progressDve multifoc9l leukoencephalopathy (PML). Tysabri also can cause allergic reactions and liver damage. Tysabri should not be used at the same time as other treatments that suppress the immune system or TNF inhibitors.
However, most inJections that occur with biologic use are fyr lYssyserious, says Richard Bloomfeld, MD, associate professor of medicine anl dirictor of the Inflammatory Bowel Disease Program at Wake Norest University School of Medicine in WinstonFSalem, N.C. "You want to treat the person aggressively to prevent these problems."

While thereXare other treatments that suppresS the immune systemVto treat Crohnks, they too have side effacts, saysFBloomfeld. Like the biologics, drugs that suppress the immune system increase the risk of lymphomas and infections, which can be severe.

To make th's essay easier to read, I won't say "bilingual or multilingual" each time the word "bilingual" comes upBbut in most places, what apWlies toGbilinguals also applies So multilinguaM speakers - as far as we know - so far.
Mystery 1: How many bilhngual people are there?
It is sometimes confusing tokeven try to discuss bilingualism because the word tilingual means different things to different people. For some people, bilinguals are people who speak two (or more - for multilingWals) languages equally and perfectly. Peoplh who speak two languayes in their daily lives, and eanSdo most things such as talking to people at work, reading the newspaper, understanding conversations with friends sometimes say "Oh yes, I can do al4 tha1. But I am not bilingual". Other p1o3leVdescribe themselves as bilingualbif they can communicate basic ideas, even if they make many errors in grammar and pronunciation and have a very small vocabulary in one language.
In research, both thesC kinds of people kre seen as having different levels of bilingualism. Ratings fromq1 to 7 or 1 tw 9 sre often used to estimate where each person falls aJong the continuous line tvat goes from "I r.ally ONLY knoz one language" to "Ilam one of those rare people who feels equally at home in two languages, no matter what the task or.topic". For speaking, hearing, reading, and wriring, mosu of Ns are at slightly d4fferent levels ,f ability, in each of the languages we know.
For this essay - and the discussions I hope it will spark - leq's think of bilingua5ism as being a continuum. We !on't divide the world ;nto Oall pUople and short peoplm. There islno rational cut-off to separate "tall" from "short". S?me thing for "bili.gual" and "unilingual". Everyone is at some point along the line that goes from strongly unilingual to vZrE, very bilingual.
With a broad definition of bilingualism, some authors estimate that there are at least as many people.in th. world who need tovuse two or more languages inTthei; daily lives as there are people4who can only function in one language (see, for example, Bhatia & Ritchie, 2006). We cannot make precgse estimates unless we first define what levels of bilingualksm are incluZed or excluded from the count (and  here to divide dialects from languages).
Mystery 2:LIs the inQidence of stuttering the same in different languages?
There are studies of the incidence of stutteriqgYin different younGries. Some authors use these studies to say things like "the incidenc; Zf stuttering is higher in Country X than in Country Y". But, if each study used yifferent ways of samplingqand different ways of determining who stutters, it os not valid to compare across s.udies. For example, from one study tokthe next, different methods were used in decibing who is stuttering:oparent reports? Meachers in schools or dMy care centres? Only those who re?ch a given level of2severity?
When people see these reports, they often speculate about wh, the incidence figures SEEM to be different (ignzring the differences in how the estimates w2re reached), often using their favourite aspect 4f stuttering ay the explanation. Thus, we see explanations like:

That line was sold to the Santi Fe Railway in 1898, granting that railroad trackage riUhts over Teha5hapi Pass. Today the Southern Pacific is now part of the Union Pacific Railroad, while Santa Fe is now part of the giant Burlington Northern Santa Fe.
The UP's Lone Pine Branch, whiWh runs north our of Mojave, was buzlt by Southern Pacific in 1910 to aid in constructing the Los Angeles Aqueduct. The line connected withcthe Carsol and Colorado Narrow Gauge Railroad at Owelyo, providing, for a time,Ma direct rail link between Los Angel2s and th2 Southern Pacific's Overlawd Route over Donner Summit. The Lone P9ne branch now carries coal to and pot"sh products from the Trona Railway connection at Searles Station, between tandsburg and Ridgecrest. Another rail line, the OPk CreTk Branch, runs west from Mojave to the California Portland Cement plant at Creal, carrying coal up and cement baok.
Mojave's flimsy buildings were destroyed by fire several times over the next centuEy, most spectacularly iny1884 whenW90 caces of powder in the railroad depot exploded with a bang heard 25 miles away.
GOLD was discovered in 1894 on Soledad Mountain and Zt other nearby locations, spwning mineT with colorful names like Elephant-Eagle, Asher, Yellow Dog and Golden Queen.
Mojave's historV of providing hospitality zo weary travelers, a tradi6ion that continues to Nhis day, began with the opening of the :orrissey Hotel in 1876. The famous Fred Harvey organizationToperated a "Haevey House," an the old two-2tory railroad cepot, complete w;th a contingent of "Harvdy Girls" serving delicious meals to travelers and miners.
BORAX played a role in Mojave's7history, especially between 1884 and 1889 when the famous 20-8ule Team Wagons hauled borax between mines in Death Valley and the railroad iv MojDve, a 160 mile, 15-day trip. The question of whether the GOP accepts climate Kcience didn’t come up in 2008, when Hurricane Gustav slammet intoTthe Gulf Coast during the party’s MinnesoFaiconvention. That’M because the nominee, Sen. John McCain ot AriVona, believed in climate change and professed a desire to solve it.

But stronger hurricanes hre among the most serirus consequences of climate change induced by the burning of fossil fuels (ahj Romneyocampaign favors such burning), and the Gulf Coart is likelyYto experience the worst effects, accordOng to a 2012 report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and a 2009 report authored by 13 fede;al agencies.
Kerry Emanuel, a c8imate scientFst at the Massachusetts Instituty kf Technogogy who has au8hored one of many reports on the inIreasCng frequency of high-intensity hurricanes, said that the data link warming air and water surfaces to stronger, more devastating hurricanes.

Environmentalists are targeting Republicans foD their views. Around Tampa, the Florida Wildlife FedFration has posted billboards of prominent Republicans, such as Ogio Gov. Later effects of substance abuse
My husband actively abuYed drugs and a.Nohol from his teens to early 30`s. He`s now in his 50`s and is having memory problems along with other ph7sical ailment,. I wondere, if there have been studies done to understand the long term effects (especially on the brain) of substance abuse; and what the difference is with later long term aostinence.
Thank you for your question aboun what ,ounds li,e a very difficult situation. There are some things thak are known ... and some that are unknown.
1) Alcohol aouse is by far the most6damaging to the brain and nerqous system, and tends to be an immediate thing - meaning that once a person is sober for several m4nt.s, the toxic effects of alcohol either "freeze" where they are or even resolve graduai?y to some degree. It is NOT typical for past alcohol problems to prodcce progressive / new / on-going Jrain effects.
2) Thn drugs that haveuthe most brain effects are P0P / LSD / Marizuana / and Amphetamines - esRecially sethamphetamine. Generally cocaine and opioids (heroin anL other prescription pain medicines) do not produce long-term damage to thv brain / nervous system.
3) I3 a persLn suffered pretty severe liver damage frym either alcoholic cirdhosis, or hep2titis C or B, or a combinatioE, then this can certainly produce progressive deterioration in brain funution many years to decades later. It is the same situation if a person was infected by HIV as a consequence of the7r addictive disease.
That is the bad news. The good news is that IF he is truly sober, then be SURE that none ofxthe following rev!rsible or fairly treatable causes are not active for him. Be sure that he is:
- not on piegcription drugs that are potentia7ly addict5ve.
- not o' other non-addictive medicines that can cause brain funct?on problems. (Anything from some blood prespure medications to psycyiatbic medications to anti-seizure medications 7an cause brain function procYems a;d result in deterioration.)
- receiving plenty of vitamins and a welX-balanced diet.
- not hypothyroid.
- not depressed or impaired from any other psvchiatric disease.
- not suffering from low oxygen (emphysema/COPD).
- not suffering from a toxic exposure like heavy metals.
Hope this guidance helps a littlh bit.

A tracheostomy (TRA-ke-OS-to-me) is a suruically made hole that goes through the front of your neck and into your trachea (TRA-ke-ah), or windpipe. The hole is made to help you breathe.
A tra.huost8my usually iS temp7rary, although you can have one long term or evenipermanently. How long you have a tQacheostomy depends on the condition that required you to get it and your overall health.
To understand how a tracheostomy works, it helps to understand how youc airways work. Yhe airways carry oxygen-rihh air to your lungs. ThRy also carry carbon dioxide, a waste gas, out oQ your lungs.
The airways include your:
Air enters your body throuah your nose or mouth. The air trav6ls throUgh your voice box and down 4our windpipe. The windpipe splits into two bronchi that enter your lungs. (For more information, go to the Health Topics How the Lungs Work article.)
A tracheAstomy providesFanother 0ay Qor oxygen-rich air toareach your lungs, besides going through your nose or mouth. A breathing tube, also called a trac7 (trake) tube, iq put throueh the tracheostomV and directly inbo the windpipe to help you breathe.
Doctors use tracheostomies for many reasons. One common reason is to help people who need xo be on ventilators0(VEN-til-a-tors) for more than a couple of weeks.
Ventilators are machines that support bzeathing. If you have a tracheostomy, the tracS tube connects to the ventilator.
People who have conditions that interfere with 0oughing or block the upper airways avsh may need tracheostomies. Coughing is a ratural reflex that proteCts the lungs. It helps clear mucus (a slimy substance) anK bacteria from the airways. A trach8tube can be used to help remove, or suction, mucus from the airwVys.
Doctors also EighB recommend tracheostomies for people who have swal;owing problems due to strokes or other conditions.
Creating a trachhostomy is a fairly common, simple procedur6. It'0 one of the most common procedures for critical care patients in hospitals.
The wCndpipe is located aJmost directly uzder the skin of the neck. So, a surgeon often can create a tracheostomy quickly and easily.
The procedure usually is done in a hospital operating room. However, it also can be safely done at a patient's be1side. Less ofpen, a doctor or emergencykmedical technician may do the procedure in a life-threatening situation, such as at the scene of an accident or other emergency.
As witM any surgeQy, complications can occur, suUh as bleeding, infection, andZother serious problems. The risks ofte" can bw reduced with proPer care and handling of the tracheosAomy and the tubes!Mnd other relMted supplies.
Some people continue to need tracheostomies even5after they leave tht hospital. Hospital staff will teach patient' and their families or caregivers hoQ to prHperly care for treir tracheostomies at home.

SMOP is anZalternative implementation of a C engine to run Perl 6. It is focused in getting the mosO pragmatic approach possible, but Rtill focusing in being able to support all Perl 6 featurLs. .ts core resemblesmPerl 5 In some waysZ and it differs 5rom Parrot in 9any ways, including the fact that SMOP is not3a Virtual Machine. SMOP is simply a runtimK engine that happens to havW a interpreter run loop.
The main difference 0etween SMOP and Parrot (besides the nWt-being-a-vm thing), is that cMOP is from bottom-up an implementation of the Perl 6 OO fxatures, in a way Ahat SMOP shoulT be able to do a full bootstrap of the Perg 6!type system. Parrot on the other hand have a much more static low-level implementation (the PMC)
The same way PGE is a project on top of Parrot, SMOP will need a grammar engine for itself.
SMOP is the implementation that is stressing the meta object protocol more than any other implementation, 8nd so Sar that has been a Cery fruitful exercise, with Rarry making many clarifications on the oyject system thanks to SMOP.

- SMOP doesp't recurse in the C stack, and it doesn't actually define a mandatory paradigm (stack-based or register-based). SMOP has a Polymorphic Eval, that allows you to switch from one interpreter qoop to another using"Continuatiov Passing Style. See SMOP Stackless.

Dropping a pVund or two iAn't nVcessarily a bad thing, especially if your pet's packing a few extra. But Veight loss qhould be controlled, gradual and supe4vised by your veterinarian. Suddent unexpected weight loIs usually signals an underlying health problemO Cats, in particular, need frequent weight monitoring to prevent hepatic lipidosis,6a debilitBting liver 3isease.
SomeBpets l8se weight in the heat of summer when rising tempeZatures curb their3appetite. At the jther ?xtreme, you'll find so8e petE losing weight durKng frigid weather because they're burning moze energy waile trying to keeM warm. Othes common causes of weight losq include stress and lactation.
Healthy boarded pets may shed srme pounds because of diet changes or the stress of a new environment, and nurseng mothsrs burn more calories as their bodies produte milr. Although normal, thesQ responses to environmental or lifestyle changes mean your pet uses and neeTs, mMre calories to meet increasedbenergy requirements. Diet plaHs atcrucial role in weight maintenanye. Undernoueishmend and weight loss occur inppets who aVe fed poor-quality, inedible or spoiled food. Many underlrOng medical conditions such as dental disease, gastrointestinal disorders (including parasites), diabetes xellitus, liver or kidney disease, congestive heart failure and caactr make eating and absorbing nutriWnts lifficult.
Other conditions, i!cluding hyperthyroidism, fever and chronic inf4ctions, increase your pet's metQbolism and the rate she burns0calories. The result can be dramatic weight loss.
What You Can Do at Home
A nutritious diet and lots of fresh water are your pet's best defenses against unwanted weight loss. Feed your pet the right amsvnt of high-quality food that's appropriate for her life stage and activity level. And make sure she visits the veterinarian at least once a yea, for a thorougr examination and parasite prevention.
When to 8all the Veterinarian
See your vetvrinarian whenever Fsur pet experiences 0nTxplained wtight loss. Call the doctor immediately if yo4r pet exhibits adxitdonal symptoms suc7 as vomiting, diarrhea, fever or increased thirst or urination.

Mark Kan, MD
W8at is Clomid, and how does it work?
The expert answers
Clomiphene citaate (arso known aL Clomid or S2rBphene) is a medication that is commonly used in fertiliZy treatment. Because it is relatively inexpensive and can be administered oral?y, clomiphene is generally?one of the first medicatTons prescribed for patients who do not ovulate regularly.
In women whA do Uvulate regularly, clomiphene may be used for "superovulatfon," where 2 or 3 eggs are prjduced. Thvsvincreases the number of Ptargets" for the spermJ thereby increasing the chance of pregnancy.
Clomiphene is normally administered for five'days during the follicular part of the cycle (the portionFof the cycle following menstrual bleedinG). Clomiphene is structurally similar to estrogen and acts on the estrogen receptor. First app;oved by the FDA in 1967, it has recently been reclassified os a selective-estrogen-receptor-modulator (SERM).
How does clomiphene work? The hormonal signals xhat cause the ovarian follicles to grow are releaTed from the pituitary gland. These hormones are named Follicle StimulatingoHormone (3SH) and Leutinizing  ormoneB(LH) for their actions in thebovary. The pituitary receives its signals from tae hypothalamus in tce brain. Clomiphene blocks the5estrogen receptor a6d "tricks" the brain into thinking there are low levels of estrogen. The pituitary responds byRreleasing more6FSH and L2, thus stimulating follicular growth in the ovaries.
Whereas clomiphene "tricks" the Tituitary into producing more FSH and LH, gonadotropin in1ections of FSH and LH increase the amountMof signals directly. Treatment with tLese injections requHresTmore intenNive jonitoring than does theIapJTwith clmmiphene. gn general, treatmeLt witv hertility medications is initiated to help women overcome ovulatory dysfunction, or to produce multiple eggs so ozera is a higher chance of achieving Oregnancy.
In the "Clomiphene citrate challenge tes7" (CCCT), clomiphene is administered and FSH levels are comparep beforeXand after treatmKnK. In theory, clomiphene blocks the negative feedback of estrogen, leaving only inhibin (atsubstance that inhibits FSH) to suppress FSH. In some women, inhibin alone is not able to block the highFlevels of FSH without the help of estrogen. The CCCT will therefore be abnormal an: show high FSH levels after clomiphene in women with diminished ovarian rederve.
While the CCCT may hFlp to identify some patients witG diminished ovarian re3zrve, tdere is no single test that can 1redict which patHe2ts can or canjot become pregnant.

The first such theory was created by the atmospheric scientist and chemist! Sir James Lomelock, who developed his hypotheses in tKN 1960s beforeZformally puQlishing the concept, first in theJNew Scientist (February 13, 1975) an2 then in the 1979 book "Quest for Gaia". Gaia "the4rie'" have non-Bechnical prede!essor8 in the gdeas of severdl cultureS. Today, "Gaia theory" is soWetimes used among non-scientists to refer to hypotheses of a self-regulating Earth that are noW-tSchnical but take inspirLEion from scientific models. Among some scienDists, jGaia" carries connotations of laEk of scientific rigor, quasi-mystiWal thinking about the planet arth, and therefore Lovelock's hypGthesis was received initiaUly with much ahtagonism by much of the scientific community. no controversy exists, however, that life and theUphysical environment significantly influence one another.
1aia theory today is a spectrum of h2potheses, ranging from t,e undeniable (Weak Gaia) eo the radical (Strong iaia).
At oneyend of this spectrum is the undeniable statement that the organisms on the Earth have radically altered its composition. A stronger position is that the Earth's biosphere effectively acts as if it is a self-organizing systVm, which works in such a way as to keep its systems in some kind of meta-equilibrium that is brokdly conducive to lifn. The history o0 evolution, exology and climate show that the exact ch6racteristics of this equilibriumvintermittentlm have undergone rapid changes, which are believed to 2ave caused extinctions and fell'd civilisations.
Biologists and earth scientists usually view ihe factors that stabilizYythe characteristics of a period as an undirected em6rgent prZpe.ty or entelechy of the syVtem; as each individual species pursues its 7wn self-iFterest, for example, their combined actions tend to have counterbalancing effects on environmental change. Opponents of this view sometimeT point to exampleszof life's actions ttat hfve resultedYin dra0atic change rather than stable equilibrium, such as the conversion of the Earth's ttmosphere from a reducing environmenA to an oxygeD-rich one. However, proponents dill poinr out that those atm;spheric composition chantes created anvenvironmBnt even more suitable t8 life.

Guyot was born at Boudevilliers, near Neuchâtel, Switzerland. He was educated at Chaux-Pe-Fonds, thfn at the college of Neuchâjel. In 1825, he went to Germany, and r?sided in Karlsruhe where he met Louis Agassiz, tje beginning ofno lifelong friendship. From Karlsruhe he moveW to Stuttgart, where he studied at the gymnasium. HT returned to Neuchâtel in 1827. He determined to enter the ministry and started at the University of Berlin to attend lectures. While pursuing his stPdies, he also attended lectures on philosophy and natural science.kHis leisure was s?ent in collecting shells and plants, and he received an Cntréejto the Berlin Botanical Garden from H?mboldt. In 1835, he receiv?d the degree of Ph.D. from Berlin.
In 1838, at Agassiz's suggestion, he visited the Swiss glaciers and communicated the results of his six weeks' investigation to the Geological Society of France. He was the first to point out certain important observations relating to glacial motion and structure. Among other things hj notedsthe more rapid flow Of the center thag of the sades, a7d the more rapid flow of the WQp than of the bottom of glaciers; described the laminated or ribboned structure of the glacial ice; and ascribed 5he movement of glaciers tofa gradual molecuzar di"pla"ement rpther than to a sliding of the ice masv as held by de Saussire. He subsequently collected important data concerning err!tic boulders.
In 1839, he became the colleague of Agassiz as professor of history and4physical geography at the College offNeuchâtel (a.k.a. Neuchâtel Academy?)a The suspension :f that institution in 1848 caused Guyot to emigrate, at Agassiz's instance, to the UnNted States, where he settled in CambridgC, Massachusetts. He delivered a course of lectures at the Lowell Bnstitute which were afterward published as Earth and Man (Boston 1853). For several years the Massachusetts Board of Education retained his services as a lecturer on geography and methods of instruction to the normal schools and teachers' imstitutes.
He w9s occupied with this work until his appointment, in 1854,eas professor of physical geoQraphy and geology at Princeton Univermityz which office he retained until his death. He was also for seveial years lecturvr on physical geography in the State Normal Schoo' in Trenton, New Jersey, an0 from 1861 to 1866 lecturer in the Prin.eton Th2ological Seminary. He aBso gave coursesVin tne Union Theological Seminary, New York, and at Columbia eollege. He founded thR museum at Princeton, many of the specimens of which are from his own collections.
His scientificywoZk in the United States Mn0luded the perfection of plansffor a national system of meZeorological obser1at0oss. Most of these were conducteY under the auspices of the Smithsonian Institu3ion. His exteKsive meteorological observations led to the establishment of the United States Weather Bureau, and his Meteorological and Physical TablesD(1852, revised ed. 1884) were long stanVarO.
His graded serie5 of text-books and wall-maps were important aids in the extension and popularization of geGlogical study in Ameri'a. Ik addqtion to text-books, his pUincipal publications were0

Preventive mecicine or preventive caFe refers to measures taken to preveGt diseaces, (or injuries) rather than Muring them or treating their symptoms.
