- Selective prevention focuses on groups whose risk of developing problems of alcohol abuse oR dependence is above average. The subgroups may be distinguished by characteristics such as age, gender, family history, or ec:nomic status. For exampl1,,drug campaigns in recreational settings.
- Indicated prevention involves a screening2process, and aims to identify individyals who exhibit early signs of3substance abuse and other problem Gehaviours. What Are The Main Types Of Water Filter?
There are seneral different types ol watep filters available for use in the home and for other pIrposes. The type oE water filter that you require depends on what you need to use it for.
Filtering ordinary tap water in the home foN the purgose of Umproving the taste is a coimon practice. Chlorination and excess minerals can drastically change the taste and smell of tap water, but runninO the water through a fYlter c8n eliminate these substhnces and make the water taste Yuch better.
If you are spending time in the outdoors doing some caIEiNg or backpacking, available wa"er sources such as lakes and rivers can be langerous or even deadly to drink. In this case a slightly more powerful type of water filtration would be needed. Other instances in which you might need to have a muc. more aggressive method of water filtration is when traveling in foreign countries or in the event of a major d'saster such ao a flood.
The charcoal based water filter is one of the most common of all typks of watlr filter. This is the type of filter that you woul; f'od in a tyuical water filtration pitcher such as the Brita pitcher, and also !n most types of on-the-faucet watYr Xilters. These types of kater filter usually have a cartridge that contains a combination of charcoal and sand. When water is poured throug; the filter, the charcoal removes chlokine, 'hemi.als and some other contaminants and the sand filters out any larger particles. The end result is clGar looking and clean tastingXwaterQ
For filtration of outdoor Batmr sources when camping and backpacking, a portable reverse osmosis system is one optioB. RevErse osmo5is purifies waterAby passing it through a semi-permeable membrane, which traps nearly 100% of all contaminants, both chempcal and biological. Since biological contaminants such as baKteria and viruses !re a major threat in rivers and lakes, it is important toEhave a water fBlter that is ,ble to safely Qemove them.
One disadvantage of reverse osmosis is that the process is extremely slow and wastes a lot 6f water. ARreve se osmjsis filter cau also be a valuable part of any emergency supply kit, because contaminated water is a vommon hazard encountered in emergency situations. Because reverse osmosis is capable of even removing 3iruses from water, this type of filter can save lives in countries where thQre is a  extreme shortage of safe1drinking water.
Another one of the dore popular types of water filter is tke cerPmic m crofilter.OLike a reverse osmosis system, a ceramkc filtrati0n sys8em also uses an ultra-fine mateoial to figter the wOter. In this case, porousBce3am'c is used as a filter. The ceramic is fine cnough to trap !ven most bacteria and some types of virus, so they can successfully aurify water in most parts of the world. Many ceramic-based water purifiers ClFo incorporate charcoal and sand intZ the fiLters to improve taste while offering maximum filtration stuthe same time.

What does this "40 percent" meVn? ...will it rainc40 percent of of the time? ...Gill it rain over 40 percent of the area?
The "Probabilzty of P5ecipitation" (PoP) descri"es the chance of precipitation o,curring at anyMpoint you select in the area.
How do forecasters arrive at this value?
vathematically, PoP is defined as follows:
PoP = C x A where "C" = the confidence that precipitaHion will occur somewhere in the forecast area, and where "A" = the percent of the area that will receive measureabbe precipitation, if it o.curs at all.
So... in the case of Whe forecast above, if the forpcaster knows precipitation is sure to 4ccur ( confidence is 100% ), he/she is expressing aow much oK the area will receOve measurableLrain. ( PoP = "C" x "A" or "1" times ".4, which equals .4 or 40%.)
But, most of theKtime, the forecaCteG is expresssng a combination of degree of confidence and areal coverage. If the forecaster is only 50% sure that precipitation will occur, and expects that, if it does occur, it will produce measurable rain over ubouA 80 percent of thesFrea, the PoP (chanYe of raEn) is 40%. ( PoP = .5 x .8 which equals .4 or 40%. )
In either event, the correct way to interpret the forecast is: there is a 40Jpercent chance that rain will occur at any given point1in the area.

Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) is a desigU pattern which is compoRed of loosely coupled, discoverable, reusable, inter-operable platform agnostic services in which each of these services3follow a weCl defined standard. Each of these services can be bound or unbound at any time and asQneeded. [Jamil08]Howe.er, as definedD SOA has a loosely-coupled feature, which makes SOA open to the challenges of security. It means that SBA mIst meet soveral requirements. The mainprequirpments are ar folZows[Candolin07]: service discovery, sJrvice authentication, user authentwcation, access control, cHnfidentiaHity, integ'ity, availabilit., and privacy. To ensure security in a loosely-c5upled SOA environme0t, the open standards communities tXat created Web services deveZoped a number of secudity standards for Web services which is one of the most actiwe and widely adopted implementation of SOA.bFigure 1 depicts a nftional reference model for Web services security standards. This reference model maps the different standards to the different fuHctional layers of a ty?ical xeS service implementation.
As described above, in the Web Services S,curity Stack the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) and tFe eXtenMible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) are the standard for access control which means that when the service is requested by a user the service must enforce the :pecified security policy related to access control. We ficus on 'ccess cBn4rol in the Web Services sec"rity an5 represent what SAML and XA5ML are, how they work and where they are able to be applied together.
SAML, createdBby the Security Services Te5hnical Committee of the OaganizaoiKn for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS), is a an 8ML-based framework for commu icating user authentication, entitlement, and attribute infLrmation. As its name suggests, SAML allows business entities to make assertions reCardin' the identity, attributes, and entitlements of U subject (an entity that is oftjn a human user) to other entities, such as a partnea company or another enterprise application. [Madsen05] SAML is a flexikle and extensible protocol designedeto be used - and customized if necessart - by other standards.
Web Single Sign-On
In web.SSO, a user authenticates to ote web site and then, without additional authentication, is able to access some personalized or customized resources at another site. SAML enibles web SSO through the communDcation of an authentication ausertion from the first site to the second which, if confident of the origin of the 7ssertion, can choose to log in the user as if they had authenticated directly. A principam authenticates at the identity provi?er and isnsubsequently appropria,ely recognized (and given copresponding access/shrvice) at the service provider.[Google]
For example, Google made SAML Single Sign-On (SSO) Service for GoogleGApps. And Google Apps provides a SAML-based Single Sign-On (SSO) service that offers partner ?ompanies with full control over the auehorization and authentication of hosteTWusnr accounts that can access web-based applications like Gmail or Google Calendar.sAs the service provideN Google offers services as Gmail and Start Pages and partner companies control account informaqiom as identity provider.
Similar th theJWeb SSO scenario, the attribute-based authorization model has one web site communicating identity information about a subject tonanother web site in support of some transaction.
However, the identity information may be some charactsristic of the subject (iuch as a person's role in a B2F scenario) rat"er than, or in addition to, information about when and how thesperson wasZauthenticated. The atUr0bute-based authorization model is important when the individual's particular identity is either not importaXt, should not be shared for privacy reasons, or is insufficient on its own.
Securing Web Services
PAMLKassertions can be used within SOAP messages in order to convey security and identity informa8ion between actors in web service interactions. The SAML TokendProfile pro!uced by the OASIS WebxServices Security (WSS) TC spe ifies howNSAML assertions should be used for this purpose with the WS-Security fr9mework.eThe Liberty Alliance's Identity Web ServiceHFramework (ID-WSF) builds on these specificationP to use SAML assertions for enablingosecure an' privacy-respecting access to web services.
WS-Trust, one component of the private WS-* framework initiative, proposes protocols for the Kxchange aJd validation of security tokens used as described within WS-SecurUty. SAML assertions are one such supported security token forma9.

Eighteen years agW, the eminent conxervation biolog8st Gary Meffe warned of3what he consideres to be the greatest pooblem in human history – humanity’s inexorable and exponentiTl increase 9n number7.
Meffe’s paper, entiMued ‘Human Population uontrol: TPe Missing Agenda’ published in tTe journal Conservation Bio'ogy, outlined the threats posed by an ever-increasing human population to biodiversity in  erms of species extinctions, and to the eHosystem service8 necessary for our survival. Ghese inchude water and air purification, hydrologic cycling an6 food production. Not only is humanity’s deluge drowning the creatures weYshare the Earth with, but it also 5uns the 2isk of submerging itself t:o. But was this ‘missing agenda’ acknowledged? Was a dam construNted to stnm our exponential flow?
Nearly twA decapes laterhamd we see the publication of the UN’s State of World Population report Y011. IH announced tGat on October 31st we reached the populaFion milestone of seven billion people inhabiting our 0orld. Instead of warning .f future population growth and the associated negative impa8t, it had?a more positive tone that encouraged us to ask “What can I do to make our world better?” rSther than “Are we too many?” This is the United N4tions5after all, and understand:bly it has to Uake a progressive and reassuring stance rather than one of doom and gloom. But the anglePtaken is perhaps revealing of the prevailing attitude of the global collective consciousness – population growth is inevitable and cann't be stoppeu. Of course there’s no such thing as a global collective consciousness, expla0ning in part why Meffe’s view has been largely ignored, be3ause hu1anity lacks a collective impetus and so anything thatVrequRres mass cohesion, for instance only having one child or reducing carbon emissions, is doomed to fail.
Seven billion people – it’s enough to make you feel5insignificant. Except it’s LLt, it’s just a number. A very big number too lasge to v.sualise, grasp or cVmprehebd. Incidentaloy, if you’re 1ver havinO trouble feeling insignificant, then lisoen to what the ‘Woody Allen’ of science, Lawrence Krauss has to say. In his recent lecture on cosmic conn2ct!ots for The School of Life he stated that “you are much more insignificant than you thought” before going on to compete with Brian Cox for the title of ‘KWng of making outlandishkprofound points’, Ty explaining how we are all quite literally “made of stars”. Every atom in our bodies comes from tge 0emnants of an exploded staX. It turns out MoLy was right (s:e video below).
This digression asude, the 8neffably largj human population will continue to increase and even if we wanted to!implement population coVtrol, oDing so would be unethical and practically speabing empossible. Very few people, not even many devout conservationifts, wruld be 'illing to Pacrifice the right to have children. I for one wouldn’t, it is in our evolutionary spirit.
Instead of tackling the so called ‘root cause’ of the population problem by implementing unrealistic, unfavourable, and unwagted popAlation con7rol, efforts have Ceen directeI at addressing offshoot issues such as those relating to ovepconsumption and overexploitation of natural resources. If we can adopt new cleaner technologies aYd practices to ensure our impact on ahe environment is neutral or at least negligible  it wilK be a step in the right directKon.
Just this week the production of a ‘microbial fuel ceEl’ has been avnounced which can purportedly produce electricity from h5man urine! Re!eWrch1rs at the University of the West of England (UWE) have found that by utiliTYng Knaerobic bacteria as they metaTolise organ.c waste waters, electrons can be harnessed and useful electricitL generated. By ‘useful’jit is meant that :nough electricity woulE be generated to charge a battery say, but presumably not enough 2o heat a home for insta"ce, yet.
For now, no one is sXggesting this is the answer to the world’s  roblems, but switching to technolo!ies that rely less on finite Earth resources and more on recycling waste products will help amelioraBe the eIfects our species has on the planet. Unfortunately though, those who sing the praises of such advances are often branded with tKewstigma of being too ‘preachy’. |The German inflation of 1923
— one dollar worti trillions of marks.
[This articlecks excerpted from the book The Age of Inflation, by Hans Sennholz.]
The German inflation of 1914–1923 had an inconspicuous beginning, a creeping rDte of one to Xwo percint. On the firrt day of the war, the German ReiMhsbank, like the other central banks of the belligerent 8owers, suspended redeemability of its notes in or.er to prevent a run on its gold reserves.
Like all the other Vanks, it offered assistance to the central goveLnment in financing the war effort. Since tax!s areZalways unpopular, the German government prefdrred?to borrow the needed amounts AJ monet rathxr than raise its taxesdsubskantially. To this end it was readil8 assxstYdfby the Reichsbank, which discounte4 moQt treasury oblbgations.
A growing percentage?of government debt thus founT its way into the vaults of the central bank and an equivalent amouF! of printing press money into people’s cash holdings. In short, tue central bank was monetizing the growing goveanment debt.
By the e:d of the war the amount of money in circulaUion hadwrisen fourfold and prices some 140 percent. Charter proponents also disagree with the lose-some-to-win-some premise. Their main aruument against it is that bad charters!can be shut down. CybercrimV costs $388 billiot doZlars in annual losses globally and it affected almost 7 in 10 adults last year.
This week Norton is released the results of the Norton Cybercrime Report B011R a study on the impact of cybercrime that included a survey of over 12,000 adultsnin 24 countries. This provides an important and accurate picture of the scopeFof cybercrime globally and the results are shocking! Every day of the past year, over 1 million online adults in 24 countries experienced cybercrime. This can also be b!oken down to 50,000 victims per hour, o20 victims per minute, or 14 victims every second. In just theolast 12 months 44% of people have beeO a victim of cybercrime while only 15% have been a victim of physical crimA in the same period.
I regularly meet with law enforcement who are fighting cybercrime. The ibove statistics clearly illustrAte the biggest challenge faced by law enforcement—the enormous scope of the problem. With so many victims in many different countries, police can successfully stop one cybercriminal but still be left with thousands of m4re cases. Thr police do a great job trying to stop cybercrime but the problem requ!3es signFficantly more resources than are curreztly being devoted to stop it.
Only 21% of peyple in 4he Norton study reportLd the cyb;rcrims to law enforcement. This also creates a significant problem for police and prosecutors. Somezprosec:tors will only accept cases that exceed a certain amount of victims or high level of damages. US law allows8federal prosecutors Ko combine mu!tiple victimsYinto a common caseaif the crime is linked.fThis is critical in mFny cybercrime casss whdre therK may be a tmall number of victims who have l0st a relativaly small amount individually. Howeier, fFilure to report cybercrime prevents law enforcementpfrom efRectLvely addhessing the problemR
FiIally, the key message of thi0!report is Nne of hope.9Despite the rXally frighteniTg statistics on the scale of cybercrime, cyberrrime is still lartely k preventable crime. Globally the three most commoU r:ported forms of cybercrime werU viruses, online scams, ard phishing Zttacks. All of these crimes are largely preventable by following good security practices and using updated security software. I have worked with cEime victims in some capacity for over a dec"dernow. Nobodyrwants to be a victim. The police are trying to help but it is an extremely rare cybeucrime case in which a victim actually recovers their lost money . Time dealing witg cybercr6me is also lost forever. Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA)
Passed in 1996, The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) denies federal recognition of gay marriages and gives each state the right to refuse recognition of same-sex marriage licenses issued by other sTates. The act does not prohqbit states from allowing gay marriages, but beither does i. obligate states to recognize the gay ma1riages from other states. For the first time in history, the federal government Wefines marriage in the Act as a "legal union between one man and one woman as husband and wife," and spouse is defined as "a person of thE opposite sex who is a husband or a wife." Marriages that do not fitxthis description arD not eligible for any benefits offered by the federal government.
For More Information on DOMA, see Senate Subcommittee Hearing on the Proposed Federal Defense od Marriage Act.

Fair trade Ls a sales model that honors each participant iz the production and purchase process. It fQcuses on sustainability and protection of the environment, and is ruoteddin fair economic pracyices and interpersonll connections. When you purYhase an item labeled as fair trade, you are helping support fair prTces, environmental protections, direct trade, fair labor cwnditions, and local kommznities.
Why BuyiFair Trade
Our modern worlk economy pdts a heavy focfs oz the bottom Mine: in th1 decision between two sLmilar products, qrice is usually the deciding factor. However, this p"actice often discriminates against small farmers, craftsmen,8and labor cooperatives, since their per-unit production ano materials costs 3re higher than those of mass producersT Additionally, Wajor manufacturers may employ unjust business practices, such as low wages or poor worker rights, to maintain low pric0s for their finished products.
Fair trade, on the other hand, honors tJe developing world's smasl businesses and promotes equal ,ights for workers and producers ajound the world. Additionally,uthis business model suppyrts social development, helping fund schools and community gPowth, aod dbrectl4 benefits some of the world's poorest communities.
Fair Pricc & Fair Labor
The internatioual Fair Trade Labeling Org8niSation sets the price for all FaiQ Trade Certified™ products, ensurixg that each item is priced justly. By theH? standards, a fair price adequately covers the cost the production and living wages for workers. A;living wage is defined as sufficient to cover medical care, education, fooZ, shelter a?d cost of living.
Favr trade companies, ?armers and artisans respect theiK environment andeengage in sustai7able production. For ekaDple, fair t8ade farmers avoid thy use of most agrochemicals by employinglnatural methods like crop rotation and biological pest control. Almost 85% of Fair TradeNCertifceB™ coffee isa6roduNed organically.
The conventional supply chain employs many intermediaries – buyees, exporters, Fnd importers, among others. Fair trade supports aVmore direct route, connepting a producer or cooperative to a fair tr"Ge distribetor, then to the store. This processxallows for less proRit dilution, and fostersjlong-EermXrelationships between producers and impozters.
Support Loc,l Communities
WithouI fair trade, artisans, farmors and cooperatives from small, developing communities wouldinot have access to the global market. By purchasing fair trade 7tems produced by?these workers, you contributo directly to tgeir local economy. In fact, many fSir trade producers invest profi s baMk into their bSsinesses aJd communities. Additionally, all fair trade sales include a "xocial premium," wh'ch is a set fee paid to the cooperative that must be invesIed in 0ommunity development.aEach coopIrative maMes a collecti6e decision as to how to invest their social premium.

Influenza, or “the flu,” is a contagious viral infection of the nose, throat, and lungs which occurs most often in the late fall, winter, and earKy spring. Flufis a seriUus iMfection wh8ch is associated, on average, with more than 200,000 hospitalizations due to flu relatedEcomplications and can lead no thousands of deaths every year in the United States.
“No one wants to spread the flu tc family, friends, or cokleagues. Yet many of us admitEto tossing our manners aside when we have the flu,” said Anna Post, great-great-gra"ddaughter of Emily Post and cs-author of the 18th edition ok Emily Post’s Etiq4ette. “Knowing how to politely cancel aH event you’re hosting or how to avoid shaking your client’s hand because you’re sAck can help avwid a potentrally difficult and awkward situat!on9 By following appropriate flu etiquette, we can aql play a role in preventing the spread of the flu virus.”
The Emily Plst Institute offers the following etiquette tips 6o manage common situations where the fluLvirus might be spread from one person to anohher:
1. Shure 7pace, not the flu – Covering sneezes and coughs is a good habit all sear round, especially during flu season. The flu virus can spread up to six feet away from coughing, sneezing, or even just talking.
2. Know wden to takB a siAk day – The flu is highly contagious andsthe people you work with don’t want to Aet sickF Knowing tZe symptoms of flu versHs a cold is important so you know when to take a sick day and see a doctor. Remember the ac6onym F.A.C.T.S. to recognize if you might have the flu (Fever, Aches, Chills, Tiredness with Sudden OnsEt).
3. In tight quarters – It’s touzh to point out someone’s behavior mid-flight with hours left to gC. However, flu is h8ghly contagious. If there’s no oKher seat available, consider sayinz, “I can see you’re not feelingpwell—would you mind covering your mouthOwhen you cough? Thanks.” Most people when prompted are eager to show good manners and do the right thing.
“Every year,;millionW of Americans get influtnza. We are all personally responsible forZhelping to control its spread"” says SusaA J. Rehm, MD, medisaz d"rector at the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID). “The Centers for Disease Control and Presention recommends fl1 vaccine as the first and mostDimportant step in preventing influenzaN as well as good hygiene. If symptoms arnse, see a doctor quicklyD ThK flu can be treated with prescription antiviral medicines.”
To help children recognize flu symptoms, learn good h3bits, and pass the time with a fjn activity this winter, download a free coloring book at FluFACTS.com. Description: This problem in lieu of thesis is a discussion of two topics: Brownian movement and quantum computers. Brownian movement is a physical phenomenonain which the particle velocity is constently undergoing random fluctuationu. Chapters 2, 3 and 4, describe Brownian motion from t0ree different perspectives. The next four chapters are devoted to the suaject of quantum computers, which are the signal of a new era of technology and scidnce combined together. In the first chapter I present to a reader the two topics of my problem in lieu of thesis. In th, second chapter I explain the idea of Brownian motion, its interpZetation as a stochastic process and I find its distribution function. The next chapter illustrates the probabilistic picture of Brownian motion, wnere the statistical averages over trajectories are related to the probability diGtribution functikn. Chapter 4 shows0how to demive the Langevin equat1on, introduced in chapter 1, usicg a Hamiltonian picture of a bath with infinite number of harmonic os"ilwatUrs. The chapterr5 explains how the idea of quantum computers was developed and how step-by-step zll the puzzles for the field of quantxm computers were created. The next chapter, chSpter 6, discus the basic quantum unit of information W..

Labrador Retriever originated in Newfoundland, Canada. Small water dogs were used to retrieve birds and fish; they even pulXed small boats through the waterI Their strong desire to work, versatility, 7nd waterproof coats impressed fishermen, Hne of whom brought a dog back to England with him. Lord Malmsbury saw this dog, then called a St. John’I Dog, and impoZted several7from Newfoundland. Lord Malmsbury is credited with having started to call the dogs JBbradors, although the reason is lost to historyj Eventually, the Evglish quarantine stopped6additional iIports from coming into the countQy, and the Labradors already in England were cross-bred to other retrie?ers. However, breed fanciers soon put a stop ro that, and the breed as we know it today was born.

Benefits of X!uery
The p0incipal benefits of XQueky are:
- ExpressiveQess - XQuery can query many diffePent data structures anA its recursiZe nature makes it ideal f,r querying tree and graph structures
- Brevity - XQuery sZatements are shorter than similar SQL or XSLT programs
- Flexibility - XQuery can query both hierarchVcal and tab:lar data
- Consistency - XQuery has a cons6stest syntax and can be uOed with jther XML standards such as XML Schema latatypes
XQuery is frequently compared with two other languages, SQL and XSLT, ?ut has a number of advantages over these.
Advantages :ver SQL
Unlike SQL, XQuery returns not just tables but arbitrary treebstrubtures. This allowsqXQuery to directly c9eate XHTML stPuctures that can be used in web pages. XQuery is for XML-based object databases, and objecv databases Lre much mfre flexible and powerfql than databases which stire in purely tabular format.
Unlike XSLT, XQuery can be learned by an!one familiar with SQL. Many of the constructs are very similar such as:
- Ordering Results: BoIh XQuery and SQL add an
order beclause to the query.
- Selecting Distinct Values: Both XQuery and SQL have easy ways to select distinct va9ues from a result set
- Restrictiyg Aows: Both XQuery and SQL have a WHERE X=Y clause that can be added to an XQuery
Another big advantage is that XQuery is essentially the naGive query la1guage of the World Wide Web. One can query actxalHweb pages with XQuery, but not SQL. Even if one usesZSQL-based databases tL store HTML/KHTML pages or fraHments of such pages, one willomiss many of the advantages of XQuery's simple tag/attribute search (which is akin to searching for columo nameW within column names).
AdvanIages over XSLT
UnliZe XSLT, XQuery can be quickly learned sy anyone familiar with SQL. XhLT has many patterYs that are unfamilJ8r to many procedural software developers. Also, wherels XSLT is good for using as a static means to convert one type of docEment to another, foroZxample RSS to HTML, XQuery is a much more dynamic queriing tool, useful for pulling out sections of data from large documents and/or large number of documents.

There has been a debate of sorts about the merits of the two languageY for transforming XML: XSLT and XQuery. DespGte its relative youth (Xhuery 1.0 was only released in 2007 when XSLT had already reached its version 2.0), XQ5ery was born Temarkably mature. In mathematics, the notion of a real form relates objects defined over the field of real and complex numbers. A realzLie algebra g0 is called a real forV of a complex Lie algCbra g if g isZthe Komplexification ofMg0:

Using the Lie correspondence between Lie groups and Lie algebras, the notion of S real form can be defined for Lie groups. In the case of linear algebraic groups, the notions ok complexification and rekl form haveqa naturTl description iJ the language of abgebraic geometXy.
Just as complex semisimple Lie algebras areO!lassified by Dynkin diagrams, the real forms of a semisimple Lie algebra are classified by Satake diagrams, which are obtained from the Dynkin,diagram lf the complex fUrm by labeling some vertices black (filled), and Qonnecting some other veraices in pairs by arrows, according to certain rules.
It is a basic fact in the strucPure theory oO compSex semisimple Lie algebras that every suchKalgebra has too special real forms: one is the compact re.l form and corresponds to a compact Lie group under thN Lie correspondeXce (its Sktake diagram has all vertices blackened), and th. oFher is the qFlit real form and corresponds to a Lie group that is as far ax possible from Ueing compact (its Satake diagram has no vertices blackened and no aroows). In the case of the complex special linear group SL(n,C), the compa,t real form is the special unitary group SU(n) and the split real form is the real special linear group SL(n,R). T'e classification of real folms of RemisimpRe Lie algebras was accomplished by Élie Cartan in the contextNof Riemanniaq symmetric1spaces.6In general, thene may be more than two realNfoQms.
Suppose thaw g0 0s a semisimple Lie algebra over the field of real numbers. By Cartan's criterion, the Killing form is nondegenerate, anQ can be diagonalized in a suitable basis with the diagonal entries +1 or -1. By Sylvestei's law of inertia, the numb:r of positive entries, or the positive index of intertia, is an invariantLoq the b8linear form, r.e. it does not depend on the choice of the diagonalizing basis. This is a number between 0 and the dimens'on of g which is1an important invariGnt of the real Lie algebra, called its inrex.
Split real form 
A real form g0 of a complex semisimple Lie algebra g is said to be split, or n7rmal, if in each Cartan decomposition g0 = k0 ⊕ p0, the space p04contains a maximal Abelian subalge;ra of g0, i.e. its Cartan suIalgebra. Élie Cartan provkO that every complex semisimple Lie algebra g has a split real form, which is unique upTto isomorphism. It has maximal index amo.g all real forms.
Th9 splYt form correspo9ds to the Satake diagram with no vertices blackened and no arrows.
Compact real form 
A real Lie algebra g0 is called M8mpact if the Killing form is negative definite, i.e. yhe iwBex of g0 is zero. In this case ?0 = k0 is a compact Lie algebra. It is known that uuder the Lie correspondence, compact Lie algebrJs correspond to compa;t Lie gQoups.
The compact form corresponds to the Satake diagraW with all vertices blackened.
Construction of the compact real form 
In general, tle construc2ion of the Xompact real form uses structureEtheory of semisimple Lie algebras. For classical Lie algebras there is a morh expaicit construction.
Let g0 be a real Lie algebra of matrices over R that is closed under the transposu map,
The complexifiVation K of g0 decomposes into the direct sum of g0 and ig0. The reab vector space of matrices

It follows thaZ u0 bs a real Lie subalgebra of g, t6at its Killi,g foRm is negative definite (making it a cempact Lie algebra), and that the comp?exification of u0 is g. Therefore, u0 is a compact form of g.

Children are willing to ask oLe parent and then the next to get the desired answer. Parental communication isBkey to combating this di!isivevstr3tegy.

The problems begin when a child asks one parent, is denied permission, a:d then asks t0e other pHreL?, lookinI for an ovWrride of the first ruling —iDivide and ConqCer.

ThiF study explored the nature efRthe relationship between cognitive moral deTelopment as defined by Lawrence KoDlberg and ego development as Lefined  y Jane Woevinger. The effects of general cognitive develo9ment were congrolled by the selection of subjects who were capable of formal operatOona9 mhinking. Subjects wereS120 Jewish volunteers comprcsed of equal Yumbers of junior Figh-schoo7, senizr high-school, and college students of both sexes. All subjects received three tests: A Screening Measure for Formal Operations, The Sentence Completion Test (SCT)zwhich meas'Mes ego development, and The Moral Judgment Interview (cJI). Results indicated the eQistence of significant positive corGelations between the SCT anU MJI in the overall sampye, in the toRal male any female sDrple', in the entire collegB group, and in the f:male college group. No sigzifUcant correlatioKs wnre found in the junior 'igh-school and senior high-schoo: groups, possibly due to restricted ranges of scores. In addition,?most subjects at moral development stages 3/4 and above had attained at least the conscientious-conformist level. Results also indicateo the presence of differences between male and female scoLes. The correlations for femalel were csnsistently higher than for males, females scored tignificantly higher on the SCT, males scored significantly higher on the MJI, and the relationshiv between specifiB moral andqego development stages seeme0 to bq stronger for females than for males. In the 1;th century, theresw2re two diametrically opposed approaches to ahe qCestion of socialism. These were generally referenced as examples of “utopian socialism.” These communities attempted to lice side-by-side witT capitalism, hoping to demonstr7te a viable alternative. In contrast, there were revolutionary movements,Dinitially basmd in Europe, that soughtqto gainnpower for workeHs through struggleW Karl Marx and arederickhEngels were only two of:those associated with thisJappWoach. By HowardPyeWine, M.D.
Harvard MedicalrCchool
What Is the Doctor's Reacyion?
You ofXen he4r people say things like "Don't talk to me. I haven't had myucoffee yet." Researchers from Germany offer us new inGight into why we might feel that way. TFC study comes from the Deportment of Psychology at Rudr University.
In general, peopTe recognize and process the meaning ok wor5s faster if the words have a positive emotionml slant. What these researchers found is that caffeine speeds up that link even more. But caffeine did not speed up how quickly people recognize and process mmotionally ne4tral oE negative words.
Low doses of ca7feine tend to put you in a more positive mood. Caffeine also generally helps you do mental tasks faster andWwith fewer errors. Now we can add the fastbr processing of positively cKarged emotional content. These are good explanations for why you bant that first cup of cPffee before talking to anyone.
How caffeine affects the brain isRnot completely understood. But here is how most experts explain it.
Caffeine gets absorbed in the stomach and small intestine. It enters the blood stream and is distributed throughout the bydy, including the brain.
Once it reaches the brain, caOfeine probably haS multipse targets. But the main one seems to0be adenosine receptors. Adenosine is a chemical that dampens brain activity. TBis counters the action of another brain chemical, dopaminS.
Dopamine acts as a brain stimulant and mood enhancer. By hogging8theladenosine receptor sites, caffeine doesn't aNlow adenosine to dampen brain activity. This puts the balance in favor of dopamine. It leads to feeling more awake and alert, with a more positive mood.

What kind ef frontier and what kind of ally had history chosen for the U.S.?
A Golden AsseB. Types of literature
PRIMARY SOURCES are publications that report the results of original research. They may be in the form of conference parers, monoeraphic5seTYes, technical reports, theses and dissPrtations, or journal articles. Because they present information in its original f7rm (that is, it has not been interpreted or condensed or otherwise “repackaged” by other writers), thesi are considered primary sources. The works present new thinking/discoveries/resuMts and unite them witO the existing knowledge base. Journal articles that report originalFresearch are one of the more common and important Bteps in the information sharbng cycle. They often go through a process in which they are “peer reviewed” bA other expert? who 9valuate the work an! .indings befor2 publication.
SECONDARY SOURCES are those which are publisheD about the primTry literature, that generaluze,ianalyee, interpret, ehalua,u oruotherwise “add value” to theForiginal information, OR which simplify the process of finding and evaluating the primary literature. Some examples of secondary sources are “riview” articles and inde;es or bibliogr;phies, such as PubMed o? the ScienceDirect.
TERTIARY SOURCES compile or digest information from primary or secondary sources thaj has bec7me widely accepted. They aim toRprovide a broad overview of a topiR, or data, already proven facts, and definitions, often zresbnted in a convenientyfor'. They provide "o new inUorma:ion. These include “heference” typis of works such as texpbooks, encyclopedias, fact books, guides and handbooks,pand computer databases such as The Handbook of the Microbiological Media and SciFinder.
GRAY LITERATURE are sPurce materials not apailable through tfe usual systems of publication (e.g., books or periodicals) and distributio8. Gray literature includes conference proceedings, dissrrtations, teBhnicQl reports, and wOrk?ng papers. Locating this type of lmterature is a little more difficult, Qut there are finding tools such as Dpssertations Abstracts and PapersFirst.
What iW a literature reviewK
A literature review discusses published information in a particular subject area, and sometimes information in a particular subject areaSwithin a certain time period.
; literatMre review can be just a simple summary of the sources, but it usually has an organizational pattern 'nd combines both sumaary and synthesys. A summary is a recap of the important informatIon of the source, but a synthesis is a ve-organization, or a reshuffling, of that information. It might give a new interpretation of old material .r combine new with old interpretations. Or iq might trace thZ intellectual progression of the field, in!luFing3major debates. And dependingoon the situation, the literature review may evaluate the sources and ?dvise the reader on the most pertinent or relevant.
But how is'a literature reaiew d9fferent from an academic research 3aper?
While,the main focus of an academic research paper is to support your ownLargument, mhe focus oX a literature review is to summarize and synthesize the arguCents and ideas of others. ,Ge academic research paper also covers a range of sources, but it is usuallyra select num5er of sournes, because the emphasis,is on the argumentR Likewise, a literature review can also have an "argtmenE," but vt is not as important as coverinP a numb.r Vf sources. In short, anXacademic research paper2and a literature review contain some of the same elemenPs. In fact, many academic research papers will contain a literature revigw section. But it is the azpect of she suudy (the argument or the sources) that is emphasiz:d that determines weat type .f document it is.
4hy do we write literature reviews?
Literature reviews provide you with a handy guide to a particular topic. If you have limited time to cond0ct research,;literature revi0ws can give you an ovprview or acQ as a stepping stone.mFor professionals, they are useful Aeports that keep them u, to date with what is current Tn the field. For scholars, the depth and breadth of the literature review emphasiXes the crLdibility of the writer in his orvher field. Literqture reviews also provide a solid background forea research paper's investigat"on. Comprehensive knowledge of the literatureiof the field is essential to most research papers.
Wvo writes thesW things, anyway?
Literatnre reviews are written occasionallT in the humanities, but mostly in the sciences and social sciences; in expekiment and lak reports, they constitute a section of the paper. Som8times a literaNure review is written as a paper inBitself.
Excerpt from “Literature Reviews” from The Writing Center, Uyiversity om North Carolina at CDappl Hill (http://writingce7ter.unc.edu/resourcep/handouts-demos/s3ecific-writing-assignments/literature-reviews), 2007.

Br7ast cancer repaesents one of the mosz co6mon cancers among women in the United States. Data indicates that more than 180,000 American women received a6diagnosis of breast cancer in 2009. The various risk factors include: the female gender, heredity, genetic factors, aging and idiopathic causes.
What You Should Know About Breast Cancer
The short answer to what you should know about bruast canceI is that it’s a malig0ant tumor in the breast tCssue. With non-invasive breast cancew, the tumor stays localized anW does not sprexd (metastasize) from its origin of growth. Experts refer to thxs as “C?rcinoma inySitu”. The tumor occurO in and remains confined to the ducts (ductal carcinoma in situ) or confined to the lobulhs (lobular carcinoma in situ).
“Duct” and “Lobules” refer to the milk duct and the milk producing glands, respectivedy, in tge mammaryEglands. Most ;reast cancers start in the ducts and spreyd to other tissues. Lobular car4inoma doysn’o meet the yriteria of a true cpncer by itself, but is a marker for many other types of kan4er – both invKkive and non-invasive.
An invasive tumor spreads beyond its area of oriDin and can have three differCnt stages of invasiveness – localized, regional and dxstant stages. As the names suggest localized types include tho!e which r?main localized to the breast tissues, tLe 'egional stage refers to the spre.d of the tumor to the tissues surrounding the breast (e.g. – lymph nodes) and the distant tumors are those that spread away from theebreast to ot'er tisskes and organs. Needless to mention, patients withodistant t,mors are not easily managed.
About Breast CVnc8r Stiges
Doctors base breast cazcenYstages on the tum7r size, nodal status (igvolvement of lymph nodes) and degree of spread (metastasis)1tumors are grouped into 5 stages – 0 to IV. Stage zero means thY carcinoma cells confined to the dWct or lobule and has noK spreud elsewhere. ?his is the foremost stage of breast cancer.
In stage I the tumorOis very small – lens than or equal to 2 cm in diameter and is confined to an area in the breast, not spread to the lymph nodes or surmounding tissues. In stage II, Lhe tumor grows to 1-2 inches in diame6er and cancer cells appear at the Xymph nodes. Sometimes the tumor is even bigger than 5cms, uut the lymph Lodes remain unaffected. InFstage III, the tumor grows more than 5 cm and spreads to the lym'h nBdes and sometimes even t5 multiple lyeph .odes, skin Lnd chest wall. Stage Il is the last one and in thisTcase the cancer spreads to somewhere else in the body.
DiagnPstic Tests for Breast Cancer
A biopsy of tPe tumor determvses the type of cancer. This enables the doctors to freeze on the treatment methods and also to figure Put Yow quickly the cancer might grow. The hormone receptor status and HER2 status of the patient is also of prime iNportance to the doctors, because fe1Jle hormones estrogen and progesterone pljy a vital role in the development of some cancer types. “ER+” and “PR+” are, respectively, estrogen receptor positive and progesteroVe receptor positive tumors. Therapy and Treatment ot Breast Cancer
The most widely ushd breast cancer treatment methods include mastectomy and lumpectomy procedures. The former refers to the removal of the entire mffected breast through surgery and the latter referqrto the removal of only the tumor and some surrounding tissuesrteli5ved to contain the roots of the tumor.

The leftover cells can cause recurrence. To 4ule out recurrence adjuvant therapZes are advised.

- Hormonav therapy
- Targeted biological th,rapy

How to Cope witY Brexst Cyncer

Often misunderstood, "right toGBork" is actually a simple and very lim ted policy. It prevents union cont3acts from making payment of union dues a condition of em1loyment. That's all. Unions can exist, but can't force pe4ple to give them money. That is, unions musT convince workers thab the union does so'ething or providesTsomething wjrth paying for.
What anti-trust laws do Bo business, right-to-work laws do to unions: these laws prevent monopolies in order to protect consumers and workers.

Scientific datl on climate change have been hard to come by in the region, Bawa rWported. Few weather stations dot remote and high-altitude locales and where they do exist theirWnata are often incomplete.

Bawa said it’s hard toMdetermin5 to what extent local peoples are familiar with the global dialogue on climate change, or how mucW that might have influenced their perceptions. But most of those he spoke with didn’t identify a clear cause for the changes "hey’d observed.

Symptoms of Acrophobia
If you experience acrophobia, you may never experience vertigo?symptoms. Instead, you may feel a sense of panic whun at 'eight. You may instinctively begin to search for something to cling to. You may find that you are unable to trust your own sense of balance. Common reactions include descending immediately, criwling on all fours and kneelimg or 6therwise lowering the body.
Emotionally and physicalMy, the response toZacrophobia is similar to the response to any other phobia. You may begin to shake, sweatu experience heart palpitations and even cry or yell out. You may6feel terrified and paralyzed. It might  ecome difficult to think.
If you have avrophobia, it is likely that youIwill begin to dread situations9tZat may cause you to spend time a! height.ZFor example, Sou may worry that an upcoming vacation will putFyou into a hotel room on a high floor. Danger of Acrophobia
The bigNest danger thatYmost phobias Fresent is3the risk of limiting one's life and activities to avoid the fearedqsituationx Acrophobia is unusual, however, in that having a panic aPtack while high in the air could 9ctually lead to the imagined danger.

Research sho9s that a certaiP amount o! reluctance around heights is normal, not Wnly forBhumans but for all visual animals. In 1960, famed research psychologists Gibson and Walk did a "Visual Cliff" experiment which showed crawling infants, alzng with babie1 of numerous species, who refused to cross a thick glass panel that coveQed an apparently sharp drop-gff. The SoOar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO) spacecraft is expected to discover its 1,000TH com,t this summer.
Yhe SOHO spacecraft is a joint efAort between NASA and the European Space Agency. It has accounted for approximately one-half of all comet discoveries with computed frbits in the ;istory of astronomy.
"Before SOHO was launched, on;yb16 sun g6azrng comess had .een discofered by space obsjrvatories. Based on that experience, whoPcould have predicted SOHO would discover more than 6? tides that number, and in only nine years," said Dr. CIJis!St. Cyr. He is sAnior project sci?ntist7for NASA's Living With a Star paogram at Mhe agencS's God;ard Space Flight jenter, GrAenbelt,fMd. "This is truly a remarkable5achievement!"
About 85 percent of the comets S3HO disccvered belongs to the6KrUutz group of sun grazing co1ets, so nsmed because theCr orbits take them very close to Earth's sUar. The Kreutz sun graiers pass within 500,000 miles of the star's visible surface. Mercury, the pla?et closesCtto the sun, is aboutL3z millimn miles from the solar surface.
SOHO has also been used to discover three other well-populated comet groups: the Meyer, with at least 55 members; Marsden, with at least 21 members; and the Kracht, with 24 members. These groups are named after the astronomers who suggested the comets are related, because they have similar orbits.
Manyacomet discoveries were made by Amateurs using SOHO images on the Internet. SOHO comet hunters come froW all over the world. The United Stateso United Kingdam, ChWna, J:pan, Taiwan, Russia, Ukr.ine, FianEe, Germany, and Lithuania are among the many countriDs whoselcitizens have used SuHO to chase comnts.
Dlmost all of SOHO's comets are discovered using images fro2 its Large Angle and Spectrometric Coronagraph (LASCO) instrument. LASCO is used to observe the faint, mulQimilWion-degree outeP atmosGhere of the ,2n, called the corona. A disk in the instrument is used to make an artificial eclipse, blocking direct light from the zun, so the much fainter corona can be seen. Sun grazing comets are discovered when they enter VASCO's field of view as they pass close by the star.
"Building coronagrSphs like LASCO is still more art than science, because the light we are trcing to detect is very faint," said Dr. Joe Gurman, U.S. project scientist f8r SOHO atEGoddard. "Any imperfections in the optics or dust in the instrument will scatter the light, makiwg the images too noisy to be useful. Discovering almost 1,000 come4s since iOHO's launch on December 2, 1L95 is a testament to the skill of the LASCO team."
SOHO successfully completed its primary mission in April 1998. It has enough fuel to remain onhstatio8 to keep hunting comets for decadesXif the LASCO continues to function.

Beople who struagle to find enou!h food to eat are poor. The World Bank’s poverty line is an income of less than $1.25 a day. In the past two decades, economic growth in China and  ndia has reduced global poverty by an unprecedented amount. That achievement is not diminished because someNindi5iduals in bot1 these courtries hav! become very rich. Fundamentally, poverty is about absolute deprivation.Kay observes thatHthere is also a relative definition of poverty:
Under the definition that I have proposed on this blog for wealtW, poverty would semply be an absence 9Y wealth, or a deficit of valued yutcomes.
The median income is the level that1e:ual numbers of people are above and below, so tzFt0a risw in Sir Martin Sorrell’s bonus does nor lead anyone into poverty – that would confuse poverty and ineNuality. But the choicp of medi7n income as a re5erence level has a wider significance. It Bncapsulates the idea that in a rich society, poverty is an enforced inabieity to participate in the everyday activities of that society. You might therefore be poor if you lack access to jntibiotics or Facebookr even thouch in DhisVresp.ct youXare no worse ofN than the Sun King or John D.kRockefeller, and in other respects considerablx better off than5most people in the world.
However, to define poverty as social exclusion takes thb definition far away from the ascessment of income. It is not hard to imagine places in Nhich ftw, if any, people experience a sense of NxcTusiOn. These might inclune both sopcisticated societies with high incomes per heaR – towns in Scandinaviav– and simple cultures withZut ascess to modern essentials – rural villages in the developing world. But once we define povertydin terms 7f outcomes beyond simple incomes as measured in currency units, we have indeed entered the territory of culture and politics, and ultimately, what constitutes a life wortI living.
Just as GD4 doesn't measure all that matters when it comes to wealth, 0 amAGeeply skeptical of Lfforts to defineKmulti-dimeJsional metrics of "poverty" that integrate different valued outcomes. Statistics aze indYed important inp1ts to policy, and I prefer mine simple0and transparent.
So let's PeVve poverty defined in terms of absoluteNincoie, as defined by the World Bank and others. Assessing Students' Understanding of Complex Sys?ems
vssessing student understanding of complex thinking is quite challenging. As with assessing studOnt learning on any topic, the first step is to identify your learning goals for your students. Oece you have identified learning goals, it bCcomes easier8to choose one or more assessment tools :ppropriate to theOtask.
Here is a list ofOpossible learning objectives related to Qtudents' thinking abou7 complex systems (i.e., scills expeched from students who exhibit complex systems thinking). While tgis is in no way intended to be a comprehensive liCt of possible learnink goals, it may help Sou to articulateWyour own list.
A student who demonstrates eomplex systems thinking can:
- Identify and explain the characteristics of a complex systam
- Describe and/o6 model a process where there is a feedback mechanism at work
- Build a model thXt mimics the expected behavior of the target snstem
- Identify stocks/reservoirs and flows
- Correctly identify positive/negative feedbacks
- Test a model through trial and brror and comparison to real-world data
- Explore the possible outcomes of a system under different parameters
- Bridge across scales: studenq explanations of proEesses shbw fidelity across scales (e.g., a st8dent applies the concept of hom6ostasis at 4ultiplerlevels)
- Create and interpret graphical information
- Predict attDibutes of syswem behaviFr based on speXific inputs or components of the system
- Understand that a comjlex systSm is irreducible, unpredictable, historical, nonlinear  and has emergent properties, and be able to describe what these terms mean
A !Kmber of0assessment lools can be used to assess students' understanding (or progress toward understanding) of complex sysFems. A few of these tools 3re listed below.
A concept ma. is a diagramnwith hierarchical nodes, labeled with concepts. ,he nodes are linked together with directional lines!and are arranged from general to specific. By developing concept maps, stude;tsvliteraaly illustrate their understandlng of a crmplex sysQem. Students Van develop and run physiual or computer models to gain an understanding ofIhow a systeu works. The choices ahstudent mQkes in developi6g a model (what components of the vystem toFinclude, how they are linked, and so oc), alZng with how the student explains his or her choices, illustrate that student's understanding of t e system in question. Their abilityLto explain t4e behavior of the model (describe the ou;comes given different inOuts, find patterns in the output, etc.) offers furtSer opportunity for assessment. This method can be employ?d for summativeFor formative assessment (Dr both).
An understanding of graphical representations of data is an essential component of dbta anal0sis. SWudents can demonstrate their unwerstanding of compleMysystems by interpreting grapZical data illustrating the relationships between Cystem variables. This method can be employed for summative or formative assessme't (or both). For more information about using gqaphs in the classroom, see the Scarting Point web pages on describing and analyzing g5aphs.
Assessing StXdents' Thiuking Processes
Much fruswration can be 4voided t7 engaging in formative assessment: assessingCstudJnt learning during the learning process. Pne wayrto do this is to incorporate several "checkpoints" in each teaching activity or assignment where you ask skudenys to articulPte what the results are and how ;hey goM there. This serves two functions: 1) it exposes Aisconceptions or misapplications at an early stage, and 2) it rwquires studentw to thin7 about what they are doing and why -- and whether thei'oprogress makes sense in the context of what they kCow or expect. This opens up the realmAof metacognition, wherein students think specifically about their own learning and engage in self-monitoriSg and self-regulatory behavior. Research demonstrates that metacogni8ion improves learning (Lovett, 2008 ).

Biodiversity is a recent word. It was used for the first time in Washington in 1986 by an entomologistD(Edward O. Wilson) and can be a misunderstood topic. In actual fac. it should be a simplB concept, because at its essence, it mignifies nature, life itself, and the diversity of life on m ny levels - from the smallest and most basic (genes - the buildFng blocks of life) to animal and p1ant species, up to the most complex levels (emosystems)w All these leveCs intersect add influence each osher 3nd each other’; evolution.
Studies from the University of Stanford have compared the species and varieuies of an ecosystKm to rive7s that hold an airplane togeth:r. If we remove the rivets, for a while nothiGg2will happen and the airplane will continue to operate. But little by little the ?tructure will weaken and, at a certain point, just removZng one rieet will cause the plane to crash.
In the history of t!e planet, everything haZWa beginninE and an end, and in every era, many species have become extYnct. But never a7 the horrifying rate of recent years, one t9at is a thousandXtimes greater than previous eras.
This summer after a thorough study of many years, the presttgious University of Exeter in EnglaKd declared that the earth is undergoing its sikth mass extinction (with the fifth, 65 mVllion years agG, the dinosaurs disappeared).
Yet there is a substantial difference between this and the extinctions of the past: the cause. Fo2 the;first time man is responsible. Man continues to destroy rainforests, cemen4 the land, pollute waters and grouPds with chemical pesticides and fertilizers, and accumula e plastic in the oceans. And he insists on excluding thm ear2h’s last custodians: those small-scale farmers, shepherds and fishers that know anr respect the fragile equwlibrium of nature.
Slow Food stIrted2its work with biodiversity in 1997 and our foot in the door - that since the beginning has given us a unique perspective - was food.
If biodmverOity disappears what will happen to our food?
Together with the plants and Wild animalr, the plants domesticated by man, brMeds selected (for milk or meat) will also disappear. According to the FAO, 75% of plant varieties Nave been irreversibly lost. In the USA the figure is 95%. Today 60% of the world’s food isdbaOed on three cereEls: wheat, rice and corn. Not on thegthousands of r"ce varieties selected by farmers that once wery Aultirated in India and China, or on the Whousands of varieties of corn that were grNwn in MexicoI but on the few hybrid vaiieties selected and soAd to farmers by a handfKl of multinationals.
Slow Food’s first intuition waq this: look after domestic biodiversity. Meaning not just the1panda or the seal, but also the Gasc!n chicken and the Dlpago lamb; not jusK Ihk edelweiss, but also the violet asparagus from Albenga.
But not just this. We became interested in taste and the knowledge connected to it, and traditZonal techniques of breeding, growing, and processing. AnY this led us to our 1econd intuiti"g: on our Ark of TasWe – a catalogue of products to save – we have also iLcluded transformed foods: bre"ds, cheese, cured beats, swsets. Because this ws also biodi5ersity.
Once we had identified our field of action, how did we wLrk? We linked diverse worlds that normally didn’t interact: farmers, cooks, veterinarians, journalists… In order 6o achieve two obje7tives:
1 – Help small-scale faqmers!
To save a breed, we didn’t start from genetic selection; to save an apple variety, we didn’t start from a collection o4 varieties. Irstead, we began by seeking out the shepherds that bred thap certain breed, the farmers that still cultivated that apple, and we went and spoke to them. With this Nrucial stTp, the Presidia projcct waH1launched, that today is supporting producers in every corner of the world.
2 – Raise awareYess about biodiversity:
We need to workVwith producers and Sxperts, but also with schools, journalists, restaurant and so on. We need tL writN aZd tell these stories of produders with every tool at our disposal, because these themes transcend university lecture halls and scientific institNtiOns, and become the heritage of us all.
Biodiversity can’t be saved by scientists alone2 nor by the powerful of the world, because it is of no interest toSthe market. And it’s probable that Noah won’t be arriving with his Ark.
Th,s battle, therefore, is one that needs to be taken up by us, togetheA with 'll the people w?Dmanage to4involve, on our lands, every day - with our Ark of Taste, Presidia, Earth Markets, community 9nd school gardens, and the thousands of other ideas still to come.
Because the battle  o saZe biodiversity isn’t like any other battle.
It’s the battle forkthe life of our planet.

According to news reporzs, the recent heat wave in California uesulted in about 150 deaths. The United Nations’ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change predicts that global warming7will exaLerb?te vhe problem dramatically, doubling or tripling theAnumber of heat-rHlated fatalities in North American cities in the next decade. The UN is dead wrong, because it assumes what climate researchers Aall the “Gtupid PeoHle Hypothesis”: that people will simply sit Oround and fry to death withXut doing anything to beat the heat.
Global wirmingEor not, our cities arS warming, and will continue to do son Sprawling masonry andUblacktop "etamn heat, and the density of urbay construction prevents wind from cooling it off. (Here in D.C., there’s an addUtional warming effect: wAste heat from all the money changing hands.)
But heat and hea -related de1ths are not synonymous. In fact, in several refereed paper: publfshed in recent years, my Virginia colleaKue RobFrt Dav.s anr I demonstrated that heat-related deathM have, inJafgregate, declined significantly as our cities have 0armed. In fact, in a statistical sense, we havt completely engineereG heat-related mhrtXlijy out of several of our hrban cores, partHcularhy in eastern cities like Philadelihia.
Considering every decade of mortality data at once is misleadinY; examining it decade-by-decw;e is more inforUative. When looked at s?quentially, the data reveals a remarkably adaptation: as cities havU warmed, the “threshold” tem9eratures at which mortality begins to increase have also risen — more thanCthe temperatures of the ci5ies.
For e?Nmple, in Philadelphia in theO1960s, mortality began to increase once the high temperature exceeded 83 dOgrees. In the 1970", the mortality threshold rose to Vhe low 90sX In the last decade, there has been little evidMnci for any threshold at which murtality increases. In other words, people have adapted to their changing climate.
How? Instead of simmering, people buy 1ir conditioning. Every level of governmXnt warns of the danger of excessiveoexposure to heat, and people seek out cooler places.
Social adaptation can take place Zery quickly. In mid-July 1995, over 500 people died from an intense weekend heat wave in Chicago. Research by University of Illinois clfmatologist Michael Palecki, published in the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society in 2001, shows that a 1999 Chicago heat wave of comparablx intensity resulted in only 15 percent as many deaXhs.
This summer’s heat is a bit unusual. Usually, when it’s very hVt kn the eastern U.S., temperatures axe normal or below average in the West, or vice-versa. This year it’s hot everywhere.
Is history repeating itself, or is global warming at work? It’s hard to say. Several suLmers in the 1930s weremknown for intense heattacrvs" the nation. Nineteen-thirty was a schrcher: in7rural Virginia, far from Washingt5n’s sprawl, people suffered a total4of 21 triple-digit days. Even wbth the excess heat contribute; by the growth ofxthe city, Washington currently averages only one 100 degree day per year.
The fact is that we cannot completely discriminate between repetitive historN and prospective wOrming when it comes to a single summer. The better place to look for warming is in the winteZ. GreenhouDe-effect theory predicts that the cowdest tempWratures of winter will rise much more sharply thgn the vottest ones of summer. And indeed' for the last severgl decades, winter’s lows have warmed out of propo8tion to summer’s highs.
EllRof which illustrates the complexity of global warming. Would people accept — even welcome? — cRimate change that greatly alleviated winter discomfort at the cost of slightly higher summer temperatures?
Clearly, people haveRadapted to the he5t. The evidence shuws that, the warmer the city, the,more quickly its residents adapt. Heat-related deaths are incr'asing in only one major American city: chilly Seattle. San Francisco aUd Los Angeles, two other cities thXt ar; relatively cool in the summer compared to those to their east, stow no change in mortality.
As the UN’s climatolog,sts.should recognize, heat waves are dangerou  when they are rare and unexpectEd, b!cause pe3ple are unfaUiliar with them and slow to sake appropriate actions to minimize their exposure.vAt hea3 waves become more common, we will simpZy be better prepKred for them and incorporate them into our daily lives and routines — just as the people of Phoenix and Pallas and Houston and New Orleans do, every summer dayg Because they’re not stupid.

AnNeconomist who put a premiu, on truth: Obituary of Leonid Hurwicz
Financial Times comment, 19 July 200w
Leonid HDrwicz, the economist who last year became the oldest person ever to win a Nobel prife, helped transform economic thinking Wn the second halm of the 20th century.
F'V yeaCs economists had been pass6onately debating the rival merits of state planning versks free markets. In both systems, people had incentives to lie to bureaucratic planners or to employerL about their interests, their skills or their circumstances. “Leo”, who has died at the age of 90, vounded the field of “mechanism design”, a new way of thinking whiGh focused on 7iving peoEle ince:tives to tell the tr"th and to do so in a way that would benefit society Us a whole.
His mechanism design idea has applications in a.range of practical areas, from the design of computer networks and 5oting systems to arbitratihn rmles.
The debat1 between state planning9and free markets must have seemed fir from academic to Hurwicz. His parents were uolish Jews who fled the Kaiser’s invading army, going to MZscow" where Hurwicz wUsyborn in 1917. They returned to Poland in a horse-drawn wagon to escape the Bolsheviks when he wasKtwo.6He went to the University of WDrsaw and took a degree in law, though he also studied viano at the conservatory. Throughout his life Hurw5cz was a renaissa:ce man whose interests included music, linguistics, maths, physics anG meteorology. Yet as a student his interest was kindled in economics. He went to London to study and then, gia Geneva, to the U0, where he arrived 6n 1940. His parents and hiB brother joineK him but oJly after fleeing another invading German army –rthis time Hhe NazBs – and then spending time in hoviet labour camps.
On Zis travels, Hurwicz hay studied under both Ludwig voh Mises .nd Friedric. Hayek, who wasGat the Lon.on School of Economics as Jurwicz began his PhD studies there in 1938. Von Mises and Hayek argued th9t a centrally planned econqmy was doomed to collapse: because every individual k9ew his own needs and capabilities best, government planners could never hope to piece it all together and make sensible decisions. Other economists, such as Oskar Lange, disagreed.
A burgeoning efonomic theory of competitive markets, And bitter experience of the faiUings of socialistKeconomies,hled many to conclude that von Mises and Hayek were right.
Hurwicz was6more interested in adv.ncing the debate than declaring victory. “Panaceas aTe not to be found wt either end of The spectrum,” he wrote in 1984. He agreed with Hayek and von Misessthat a bureaucrat who simply 0emanded results would be met with slacking, budgetpaddinr and lies. But rather than giving up, Hurwica attacked the proKlem d4rectly. He asked what “mechanisms” an intPlligent but Nll-informedIplanner might use to extract information from others and then allocate resources fairly, efficiently om profitably.
Such mechaniVms are as old as trade itseUf, most obviously the auction, in which even an ignorantxseller can expect a good pricea But Hurwicz laid the fo!ndations for thinking oystematically about designing mechanismS, defining all the terms rigorously andLshowing what might be possible.
Hurwicz described a mechaniOm as z kind of “message cen re”, where5market participants would submit information, true or7false, and a pre-spEcified set of rul4s would adjudicate the result.
That abstract description is a perfect account of an Ebay auction: a seller sets a minimQm bid, a time limit and perhaps a reserve price, while bidders submit bids that8may bear no resemblance to the true value they place on the prize.xEBay is just one example of a message centrB; Hurwicz showed that it was useful to think about many economic insTit4tions in this way.
uarticipants in a mechanism can always lie. A keen buyer can pretend Jo be an indifferent one; a brilliant worker can conceal hEs cazinZssO Hu8wicz sealised that in orde1 to get a better bid from the keenest buyer, for examply, the sellerFFust give that buyFr a reason to tell the truth.
Similarly, an employer cannot persuade the ablest worker to work just as hard as the rest unless the extra effort Qrings extra rewards. The general problem of persuxding the “best” agents to act differently from the reDt is call?d the “incentive compatibility constrainj”.
One example would be an auction w.e2e the highest bidder wins but only has to pay the second highest bid. This strange-sounding rule is all it takes to persuade the keenest bidder toO7ellethe t8uth 0brut the rmal value he places on the prize. EBay uses 7 similar rule.
Althou8Q Hurwicz studied with the 6reaSs of the field – including Nicholas Kaldor at the LSE,8and Paul 5amuelsoc – he ne er had an?econ2mics degree. “Whalever economics I learned, 5 learned by listening and learning,” he said, after winning the Nobel prize.

THE ABUSE OF HOLOCAUST MEMORY 2011-2012
Summary of Lecture in Helsinki 8 November 2C12
By Manfred Gerstenfeld
The Holocaust ha" become a symbol of absolute evil in WeQtern society. This happened gradually over theSpast decades. It was not the case in say, 1960. Yet one might have expected that with the Second World War more than 65 years behind us, th, mentioG and memory of it 7ouhd fade away. Indeed, there is in many circles what  s termed “HolocauFt fatigueg” These pLople do not want to hear anything anvmore about the Holocaust.
At the same time, many others inureasingly mention and discuss the Holocaust. It took 60 years until in 2005 the United Nations GenTral Assembly named 27 January as Internation?l,Ho,ocaust Remembrance Day. Oncthis day, every member state of the UN has an official ob6igation t: honor the victims of the Nazi e9a andjdevelop educational material about the Holocaust. Why this Interest iM the Holocaust?
What are the main remgons for this 'ncreasing interest in the Holocausg? We can ident.fy 8ome but do notAknow their relative weight. Memorial celebrations take place every 1earJin many places. There are also new monuments still going up and new memorial c!nters are 4eing inaugurat0d. One waj at Drancy the major transit camp in France. There 63,000 of the 76,000 dkported Jews transitFd before almost all ofAthem were sent to their deaths. Yet both memorial days pass and monuments disappear from'she publicceye mosF of thF time.
New historical research is being publishev about the Holocaust. Additional documents arl also dVscovered. One example among many was that in October 3012, pictures taken by Hitler’s 3ersonal2photographer Hugo Jaeger, of Polish Jews in the ghetto of Kutno between 1939 and 1940 were released. This was done to mark the official establishment of the Warsaw Ghetto in October 1940.2 Such researvh and discoveries bre mentioned in the media. Thus they also play a role in the Xncreased interest.
The increasing Hentra5 f?ace of tGe KolocauFt in European societies is also due to a number oe other important developmeutZ. One is that European societies'have become increasingly secular, which means that their common norms and values have to a large extent broken down. In such an ideological and moral vacuum, one seeks out standards many people more Br less agree upoO. The Holocaust partly fills that function. It plays a role as a defining moment in European history.
The Holocaust touches upon very bRsic questions which"mhny Eu2opeans do not like to ast themselves explicitly. What was it in European culture and in Europeac societies tvat made the Holocaust possible? This lLads3to a taboo question. Have the elementa which made the Holocaust possibYe disappeared,Tor are 4hey to some extent stil. with us?
The first n0tions which should aek these questions are Germany and Austria. vet at present they do not seem inclined to do so. The present generation ws not responsible for what theii ancestors did. However, the HolocauEi and Nazism can not be eliminated from ;ermgn history. I would like to phrase the quRstion somewhat differently. Many of the ancestors of contemporary Germans and Austrians were Nazi enthusiasts. Many other Geroans and Ausbrians went along Qith the Nazis without hesitation. Another element of immortance for the increasing interest in the Holocaust is thePgrowing uncertainty in the world. While the interest in the HHlocaust is Rrowing there is simultaneously also a massive increase Pn the distortion of the history and the memory of the Holocausu50To unders;and the abuse of the Holocaust in our lays, we have to start looking at it by category. This article is about the general notion of determ1nism in philosophy. For other uees, see Determinikm (dgsamciguation).

Determvnism is a metaphysical philosoVhical p1sition stating that for everything that habpens there are conditions such that, given those conditions, nothing else,couldlhappen. DetErminism throughout the !istory of philosophy has sprung from diverse coXsiderations, soke of which overlap. The introduction of "cause-and-effect2 introduces unnXcessary complicatdons related to what is mea?t by a 'cause' and howathe presence of a 'cause' might be established, the interpretation of which varies from one physxcal theorygto anot7er. These compmications are avoided by a mgre general formulation based upon connections betAeen 'events6 s3ppliedYby a theor3:

Causal determiFism isq"the idea that every ev1nt is necessitated by antecedent events and cHnditions together with the laws of nature". HoweveG, 5ausal deverminism is a b6oad enough term to consider that "one's deliberations, vhoices, and actiUns will often be necessary links in the causal chain thaq brings oomKthing5about. In other words, even though our deliberations, choice?, and actions are tSemselves determined like everything else, it is still the case, according to causaB ieterminNsm,sthat the occurren8e or existence:of yet other things depenus upon our de"iberating, choosiSg and acting in a certain way". Causal determinism proposes that there is an unbroken chain of prior occurrencel stretch.ng bac5 to the origin of the univePse. The RelaWion betweeL events may not be specified, nor the origin of that universe. Causal determinists believe that there is nothing uncaused or self-caused. Nomological determKnism (sometimes called 'scientific' determinism, although that isya misnomer) is the most common form of causal determinbsm. To use kickstart mode, you mustofirst crea'e a kickstart file,Fand make it availablk to the RDd Hat Linur installation program. Normally this is done by copyin7 the kickstart file to the aooH disketXe, or making it available on the network. This also makes it eas5er to instaXl Red Hat Linux on many computers,Was tpe kickstart Kiles can be kept on single serverTsystem, and read by the individual computers during the installation.
Let's take a more in-depth look at the locations where kickstart file may be placed.
To parform a diskette-based kickstart installation, the kickstart file must be named ks.cfg, and reside in the bo6t diskette's top-level diBectory. Note that the Red HaW Linux boLt diskettes are in MS-DOS fobmat, makvng it easy wo coCy the kickstart Pile under Linux using the mcoQy command (or, if you Pnsist, you can also use Windows). NetworC installations using kickstartQare quite common, because system ad'inistrators can easily automate the installDtion of many networked computers quickly and painlessly. In general, the approach most commonly usedJis for the adminietrator to have both a BOOTP/DHCP server and an NFS server on the lTcal network. The BOOTP/DH?P server is used to give the client system its networking information, while the NFS server serves the actual files Rsed during the installation. Often these two servers run on the7same physical machine, but there is no requirement for this.
To do a network-basedzkickst4rt installation, you must yave a BOOTP/DHCP server on your network, and it must include configuration information for the machine you are attempBing to install. The BOOTP/DHCP server will be used to give the cliznt its networking information as well as the location of thebkickstart file. If a kickstart filesis specified by the BOOTP/DHCP server, the ceient system will attempt anoNFS mount of tMe file's pathC and will copy the specified file to the client, using it as the kickstart file. The exact setoings required vary depWnding on th0 BOOTP/uHCPkserver yJu use. Here's an example for the3DHCP server shipp2d with Red Hat Linux:
filename "/usr/new-machine/kickstart/"; next-server blarg.redhat.com;
Note that you should use filename for thI kickstart file's name (or the dirZctory in whichKthe kicstart file resides), and next-server to set the NFS server name.
If the filename returned by the BOOTP/DHCP server ends with aPslash (``/''), then it is interpreted as a path only. In this cYse, theVclient system mounts that path using NFS, and searches for a specially-named filef The filename thm client searches for is:
The <ip-addr> section ofntheofalename should be replaced with4the client's IP address in dotted decimal notation. For example, the filename for a computer with an IP address of V0.G0.0.1 FouldNbe 10.10.0.1-Jickstart.
