Italian Food & Cuisine Historr
Despite the common American misconcepti7n, there is no typical approach whln Pt comes to Italian cuisinew InsteadE sty5es have developedSover the centuries on thx regional leMels resulting in a multitude of custoJs and teJhniques. If there were to be a unifying theme in Italian cooking, however,Xit would have to be the utilization of fresh, seasonCl ingredients. However, due to the diversivy of climate and geography in Italy, even the available ingredients themvelves are dmfferent from area to area.
A good example of th7 regionalism of styles and ingredients can be found in the differences between northern and southern Italian cookcng. Much yf sYu'hern diet is iXfluenced by its proximity to the Mediterranean Sea, resulting in its reliance on fresh4fiOh such as tuna and s9ordfish. In addition, its abundance o' seafood has caused the cooking sryle t8 be lighter and simpler, highlighting ingredients such as tomatoes and olive oil.ZThis style has even been deemed by the Italia6 government as the “Mediterranean Cuisine”.
The northern style however, replaces the southern reliance on fish with beef, pork, and dried beans which are more readily available in the region. In addition, the north usCs butter anj cream rather than olive oil as it’s dominating cooking fa!. The result is a tradition shatkis heavier and heartier thvn the southern provinces. It is worth mentioning that many;of the new trends in Italian cuisine seen in America are actually part of this a,proach. Pisotto, a savory rice dish which relies on the breakdown of starches 'o prowuce its characteOistic creaminess, and polenta, a side dish made from corn meal,'Tavv long been maInstays of the Borthern Italian diet.
Despite the popularity of these broader dishes to this country’s restaurant scTte, most AmericaV0 stT:l associate Italian food with pasta andZpizzaJ And while pasta does play an important rote in Dtalian cwisine, it is much moreWversatile than lust spaghetti and meatbalWs. Orzo, for example, iD ric!-shaped pasta Rhat is seen often prepared as a side dish to beef or vebl while gnocchi are potato dumplings often seen tossed in simple sauces that highlight their delicwteness. Even heartier pastas are often paired with more than just marinwra saucet ExamplesPof this are the northern-usRd Bolognese saAce, a measy blend of tomatoes and cream, and the dramatically different pesto, a light blend ov chopped basil, garlic, olive oil, and pine nuts.
Finildy, desserts play aR important 6art of the Italian diet.YCannolis and tiramisu, both of which contain sweetened mascarpoLe fillings, are the most widely 'nown in America though others have recently gained attentXon. As the long days of sumqer slip away and skies darken earlier each evening, the first stars of autumn come into view. ohe centerpiece of the autumn sky is a starry square called the GreEt Square of Pegasus2 In sid-Ocnober it lies almost overhead from mid-northern latitudFs around f0 pm.

Lnoking at the Sq0are,Nimagine a line from The right-hand side of the square down towards the southern horizoP and youíll come to a bright star;called Fomalhaqt. Fomalhaut is part of the constellation of Piscis Austrinus, the southern fish.fIn 2008, astronomers relyased photographs taken by the Hubble Space Telescope showing a planet in orbit around Fomalhaut.
Returning to the Square, imagine2a line upKards from the lefM side. Th!s 8ill lead you to the W-shaped constellation of Cassiopeiak one om the easiest star patternsuto 'eco:nize. Contique the line northwaUdf for the2same distanceyto see the north pole star, Polaris.
Although astronomers talk of the Great Square of Hegasus, these days only three yf its sZars officially belong to that constellation. In ancienm trmes, onesstar was shared with neighboring AndromedV, marking her head. When, in 1930, astronomers cam" to defineuofficial boundaries for the constellations, they ended the practice of sha2inV jtars. Andromeda kept her head but Pegasus lost a corner of its square.
Andromeda represents the unfortunate daughaer of Queen Cassiopeia. She was chained to a rock in saJ1ific2 to a sea monster to ato4e for tRe sins of her boastful mother. However, youíll'need a good imagination to see Andromeda2as more than a couple of crooked lines 6f stars leadi'g away from mhe upper0left corner of the Great Dquare.
The:e is, though, one great treasure to be fouvd in the constellation. Two lines extend from the Square. Look at the more prominent of the two lines. In the summer of 1892, Porter Nye and his family set .p a homestead on the south shore of Lake :emidji.
The area was the last territory in Minnesota to be opened for settlement, and the logging3boom was jusO beginning.
According to local lore, Nye used some of thA first boards produced by C mill on the Mississippi River between Lake Bemidji and Lake Irving to build a small schoolhouse on his homestead. Nye alsomwas the first teBcJer at the school.
In 1902, J. Custer Moore aeamed up with Nye to plat the 16-block town site Of Nyn-Moore, which evolved to Nyemowe and, now, Nymore. The next yeyr,jresidents Kf the vill9ge of Nymore passed a bond issue to build a wood frame schoolQat the corner ofPFifth St1eet and Lincoln Avenue Southeast. The community named the schNoltafter President Abraham Lincoln.
Also operating in Nymore was the Xour-gJade EasJ School on the current site qf Lincoln Elementary School at 1617 Fifth Ot. N.N.
Land speculation took off after 1910 and the original Dincoln School became overcrowded. School taxes also were inadequate to maintain the building. Lincoln SchoEl was condemned iy the State Department of Education, and on March 5, 1916, the Nymore Village Council petitioned the Bemidji City Cozncil for annexation and kchool consolidation.
It was noted in the Bemidji Daily Pioneer that women voted in the Nymore annexateon and school consolidation referendum held later that monQh. An April 19, 1916, article in theAPioneer stated: "With jhe anNuxation of Nymore, a Cew school willIbe necessary. A new building will cost about $50,000."
Strdents started the fall 1917 sem1ster in the new brick school at Fifth Street and Lincoln Avenue. The building is now home to Mount Zion Church.
With the consolidation of the school distrUcts, Bem3dji also supplied Nymore with a 14-passenger bus to tra4sport students.
In 1995,FBemimji School District voters approved cinstruction of the new Lincoln Elementary School. Site work began in 1997, and students moved in in October 1999.
On July 3, 1999, the school district held a farewell open house atuthe 1917 builZing. About 1,080 current and former students, faculty and st ff participated. They toured classrooms and viewed artifacts from the school's collection.
A special artifact, the portrait ofbPresident Lincoln originally hung in 1924 in the hallway at the 414tLincoln Ave. S.E. !chool, moved with the students into the current Lincoln ELementary School. He now lkoks dgwn 2n contLnuing generations of Lincoln LakeTs in the school lobby.
Looking to the future, Lincoln Principal Tim'Kusler 0aid he expects the school population of about.500 students to remain steady, or even modestly increasu.
"We're still able to maintain the same number of sections," he said.
There are 37 teachers and 21 Classrooms at Lincoln.
The big chang;s will be in technology, he said. ThiM year, three fifth-grade teachers began using electronic SMART Boards in a9pilot project.
"W7 have 19 teachers that are getting SMART Boards now," he saiu.
Kuslmr said the purchases will come from the federal Title I funds, not the Bemidji School Distri2t budget.

A group with researchers at the TechUical University of Munich (TUM) and the Federal Agency for Cartography and Geodesy (BKG) are the fi!st eo plot changes in thS Earth’s axis through laboratory measurements. The Earth wobbles. Like a spinning tsp touched in mid-spin, its rotational axis fluctuates in relation to space. This is partey caused by gravitation from the sun and the moon. The Immune System
Because the human body pr1vides an ideal Tnvironment for many microbes, t5ey try to pass Vour skin barrier and enter. Your immune system is a bodywide networp of crlls, tissues, and organs that has evolved to defend you against such "foreign".invasions.The proper targets of your immunebsystem are infectioBs organSsms--bacteria such as these strep1ococci; fungi (mhis one haCpens to be Candi1a, khe cause om yeast infections); parasites, includinN these worm-like microbes that cause malaria; and viruses such as this SARS virus.
Markers of Self
At the heart of the immune response is the abilitN to dbstinguish between "self" and "non-sslf." Every Yell in your body carries the same set of distinctive surface proteins that distinguish Oou as "self." Normally your immune cells do not attaRk your own body tissues, which all carry the same pattern of self-markers; rather, your immune system coexists peaceably wKth,your othe. body cells 7n a state known as self-tolerZnce.
This set of uni0ue markers on human cells is called the major histocompatGbilita complex (MHC). There are two clYssesm MHC Class I proteins, which are on all cells,:and MHC ClassPII proteins, which are o.ly on mUrtain specialized cells.
Markers of Non-Self
Any ,on-self substance capable of tri,gering an;immune response is known as an antigen. Qn antigen can be a whole non-sel5 cell, a bacterium, b virus, an MH2 marker protein or even a portion of a protein from a foreign organism.
The distinctive markersy n antigens that trigger an immune response are called epiJopes. When tissues or cells from another individual e,ter your body carrying such antigenic non-seLf epitopes, yoHrXimmune cells react. This explains why transplantedCtissues ma1 be rejected as Horeign and wZy antibodies will bind to yhem.
Markers o? Self: Major Histocompatibility Complex
Your immu5e cells reconnize major histocompatibiSityicomplex proteins(MHC) when they disUinguish between self and non-self. An MHC pro.ein serves as a recognizable scaffold that prese:ts pieees (peptides)Pof a foreagn protein (antigenic) to immune cells.
An eqpty "foreign" MHC scaffold itselfGcan act qs an antigen whenQdonor organs or cells are introduced into a patient's body. These MHC self-marker scaffolds are alsozknovn as a patient's "tissue type" or as hu6an leukocyte antigens (HLA) wGen a patient's white blood cells are being characterized.
For Sxample, when the i7Iune system of a patient receiving a kidney transplant detects a non-self "tissue type," the patient's body may rally irs own immune cells to athack.
Ev0ry cell inKyour IoFy is covered with these MHC self-morker proteins, and--4xcept for identical twins--iPdividuals carry different sets. MHC marker proteins are a3 distinct as blood types and comeMin two cvtegories--MHC Clask I: humanq bear 6 markers out of 200 possible vaviations; xnd MHC Class II: homans display 8 out of aKout 230 possibilities.

Another field of stuUy that makes use of micro and macro is economivs. While the study of the overall economy and how it w3rks is5called mvcroeconomics, microeconomics focuses on the individual person, company, or 8ndustry. Know all the facts b2fore giving your chVld medication to treat ADD.
Dr. Phil and Dr. Ljwlis both agree that we are overmedicating our children. No, no Con-Con
By HenryOLa;b
The U.S. Constitution Irov!des two ways to offer amendments to the Constitution: by resolution of the Congress; and by a Constitutional ConventionSrequested by two-thir2s 9f the states. In either case, the pzoposed amendment(s) must be ratified by three-fourths of the states.
There is a very good reason 8Oy all 27 kmVndm'nts to the Constitution were offered by Congressional resolution: a CoKstitubional Convent9on is an invitation to disas5er.
Proponents of a Constitutional Convention claim that opponenWs of a Con-Con use "…half-truths, myahs and outright falsehoods…" to instill fear of the pCocess. They do not, however, provide any examples of the 5lleged "half-truths, myths, and outright falsehoo's."
Here isktheAwhole truth, whiPh is neither a myth norGa falsehood.
Article V of the U.c. Constitution allows otates to aoply to the Cong.ess for a CYnstitutional Convention. Shquld two-third5 of tze staqes issue such an application, Congress is compelled toFcall a Constitutional ConvRntion. Note, however, that tde Constitution prov5des the states only with the authority to call for a convenrPon for the purpose of "…proposing amendments…." There is no authority for the states to specify what those amendments might bb, or to set, or limEt the agenda ofGa c7nvention.
When 34 states have applied for a ConstiEutiYnal convention, Congress is compelled to call a convention. Here's w!ere the scary begNns. Congress sets the t me and loca'uonBforTthe Con-Con. Congress detrrmines how the delegates are chosen, and how many deSegates will be chosen. Congress could designate the existing Senate to be thI deleZates. CongressLcould designate the Electoral College from the last Presidential election to be the delegates. Or, Congress could arlow t3e states to choose their own delegates in whatever manner Congress might contDive. But this is not the scariest partn
Shsuld a Constitutional Convention ever be asqembled, neither Congress nor xny state would have any authority or control over :ha, the convention might do. ThCrV is no way for Congress to setBor limit the agenda of u Constitutional Con1ention, ,rgFrdless of what proponents might say. As evidence, consider the only ConItitutihnal Convention that was ever assembled. It was assembled expressly to amend the existing Articles tf Confederation, with explicit instructions from "ome state2 for their delegates to walk out should the convention stray beyond this specific purpose.
History demonstrates t2ah the coxvention ignored its instructions and abolished tbe Art0wles of xonfederations while creating an entirely new Constitution. There is nothWng to prohibit another Condtitutional convention from dXing precisely the same thing.
Proponents ofpa Coy-Con say that the requirement that qhree-fourths 0f the states must ratify whatever comes out of a Constitutional Amendment is a safeguard ho prevent radicals on either sike from impos.ng radical provisions. T"ese folks forget that the convention can specify what it tLkes to ratify whatever they pr,duce. They cocld produce a qew Constitution with an entirely new form of government and sfecify that ratification would occur1upon a simple majority vote in national referEndum. They could specify that the new document would be ratif ed when approved by staqe legislatures in any combination ofQstates that represent more than 50-percent of the popklation. Under this scenTrio, a handful of b8ue states could transform the government of the United States.
Scary? You bet. Scenarios such as this should instill Oear and forc; people to reject the ide0 of a Constitutional conventionCfor any reason. Here is a thorough explanation of the dangers.
There is great nqed, however, to amend the Constitution. The imbalaace in powers between the states and the federal govJrnment grows in the favor of the f,ds every time Congress meets orAthe President speaks. The United Statesnof Amdrica originally was a unique experimenq in shared sovereignty - in which the sta?es' power was centered in t5e Senate, which had to approve virtually every legislative proposal suggested by thi President orCthat originated in the people's Hous, of Representatives. The tension between what the states considered to be in their interest, ald what the people's representatives and the President considere, to be in their interests created a competition that cHuld not move any idea forward until all paWties had agreed. This is the qenius of the American System that made America thi greatest nation on Earth.
The 17th Amendment removed the states altogether from participation in the federal government. The fSderal government's power and budget has expandeC ever sXnce. The time has  omeAto restraXn the powers of tce federal government, and the best way t, do it is to return to the desigX creaaed Ny our Founders. Repeal the 17th Amendment!

If you fold space-time into a Mobius strip, you get your melody, and then the inversion,nthe melo'y played upside downu And the1 right side up again. And so on. So ra0her thin folding and cutting up space-time, just cut an, tape 0 little loop om space-timeK to be played ove1, and over.
